column2: LEAD: Even in the off season you knew it would be a year of destiny: ours, theirs, New York's. Both teams had power and speed to burn - the pitching needed only continued health, or a little shoring up. October was in the air before spring arrived. We were ready to tell the commissioner to have Series tickets printed.

LEAD: Why does coffee often appear to be a different color in the pot than in the cup? Why does tea look lighter in a spoon than in a cup, while milk appears to be the same color, no matter what the container?

LEAD: Jeanette Marie Kelleher, an assistant economist at the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, and Gregory Michael Stein, an associate at the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, were married yesterday at the Back Bay Hilton in Boston. Rabbi Allan L. Press and the Rev. John MacInnis, a Roman
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: TRAFFIC on the bridge one recent morning was, as usual, at a standstill. Hundreds of Westchester-bound commuters sat hunched in their cars, watching the rain beat aimless patterns on their windshields.

LEAD: Baedeker's Rail Guide to Europe 296 pages. Prentice Hall. Paperback. $15.95. Europe by Eurail: How to Tour Europe by Train By George Wright Ferguson and LaVerne Ferguson. 639 pages. Globe Pequot Press, Chester, Conn. Paperback. $11.95.

LEAD: Leslie Ann Tishman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Tishman of Nw York and Warren, Vt., was married yesterday to Gary Mark Inman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bobby M. Inman of Mount Airy, N.C. The Rev. Shannon Bernard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Tishman home in New York.
LEAD: On the Border

LEAD: OLD-FASHIONED precautions, including mosquito nets, are the latest thing for the traveler to the tropics. When I recently heard malaria and dengue fever discussed, the physicians stressed not treatments and prophylactic drugs but anti-mosquito measures. I had a kinesthetic memory of wiggling when my Victorian-style grandmother tried to get a hat and a shirt on me in the Carolina Low Country sun and recalled her urging me indoors at sundown.
LEAD: ONCE upon a time, Pennsylvania ran on coal, steam and sweat.

LEAD: Understudies' Big Night May 8 - As understudies, they are usually anonymous, waiting in the wings to perform in place of an absent star. Tonight is their night, as they sing the songs they have rehearsed but usually do not perform each night in ''Phantom of the Opera,'' ''Anything Goes,'' ''Into the Woods,'' ''Me and My Girl'' and other current Broadway shows.

LEAD: Despite a spectacular last-minute offensive to turn the tide against him, President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, heads into Sunday's presidential election favored to win a second seven-year term.
LEAD: MEMORY By Margaret Mahy. 278 pp. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $13.95. (Ages 14 and up)

LEAD: Friday was the 93d anniversary of Theodore Roosevelt's swearing in as New York City Police Commissioner. Friday was also a big day for Sgt. Clement C. Johnson of the 105th Precinct in Queens Village.

LEAD: Dr. Morris Schreiber, a theoretical mathematician and professor at the Rockefeller University, died of congestive heart failure on April 30 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Nancy Ellen Friedman and Robert Jonas Gross, trial lawyers in the torts branch of the Justice Department in Washington, were married last evening at the Annapolis (Md.) Hilton Hotel. Rabbi Stuart G. Weinblatt officiated.

LEAD: HAPPY MOTHER'S DAY Today's the day mothers get their due, and those who want to go beyond the ordinary - the card and the dinner to say you care the most - can take advantage of some offbeat ways to share togetherness on Mother's Day. For example, there's Coe Hall, the restored Gold Coast mansion that sits in the middle of the 409-acre Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay.

LEAD: TO most gardeners, slugs are slimy, voracious pests. To Dr. Alan Gelperin, a research scientist at Bell Labs in Murray Hill, N.J., they are creatures worthy of respect. ''The degree of sophistication and complexity of their biological machinery is awe inspiring,'' he said in a recent interview.
LEAD: It worked for President Reagan in 1984: reinforcing the political image makers with the advertising executives who promoted Alka-Seltzer and Puppy Chow.

LEAD: Ismail Khelil, the Central Bank Governor, deals not from crystal balls, but he does have a dream that one day the poor nations of North Africa will be linked economically by their own version of the European Community.

LEAD: As a member of the medical advisory board of the Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Foundation, I was pleased to read Dr. Stone's article. However, he may have created additional stress for people with lupus. He states that 60 percent of the patients have a rash on the face that is ''similar to the facial markings of a wolf.

LEAD: A WORLD OF RUGS ''The Life, Love and Compassion of the Orient Through Rug Design'' and ''Mystical Icons of Oriental Rug Designs'' are the subjects of two lectures to be given at 8 P.M. Friday and 10 A.M. May 18, respectively, in connection with a sale of hundreds of rugs at the Rye Arts Center.

LEAD: Janice Ann Facibene and Christopher Robert Carpentieri, lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the New York Yacht Club. The Rev. Harris Riordan, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: IT'S nice that Middle America has given its name to all that's average and respectable when it has been the stomping ground of so many weird artists. One of the earliest and weirdest was Ivan Albright, who could make anything -from flesh to flowers - look as if it was in the last stages of putrefaction.

LEAD: Bang - You're Alive! The most enthusiastic shooting in World War II came at the very end, as if all the unexpended ammunition and aggression had to be got rid of at once. This is from ''Flights of Passage'' by Samuel Hynes (Frederic C. Beil/Naval Institute Press).
LEAD: SHE hung up on me. I can't blame her; it was my fault. Now I'm paying the price. Night and day, the same questions whirl through my mind; Who is she? What did she want?
LEAD: THERE is a trend in New York State education that has not got the public airing it deserves. Perhaps that is because no one has brought it up as a specific issue.
LEAD: Nancy Reagan needed no soothsayer to anticipate that a memoir by Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's former chief of staff, might embarrass the First Family.

LEAD: KAZUYOSHI TAKEI, barkeep at a watering hole in the Ginza,'' went the bright lead on a story from Tokyo by Fred Hiatt of The Washington Post, ''admitted that the word dry used to conjure nothing but dry cleaning in his mind. That was before the 'dry boom' hit Japan, before 'the dry wars' began. . .

LEAD: THEODORE'S in Oyster Bay doesn't serve clam chowder, shore dinners or breaded fried shrimp, yet it bills itself as a seafood restaurant. Which goes to prove that there are seafood restaurants and seafood restaurants. Theodore's calls itself unique, and is. Here, smoked shark, fish soup Provencal, snapper en croute and bouillabaisse tempt fish fanciers.
LEAD: Smoking Bans On British Air
LEAD: Medicare's fortunes have improved and its trust fund is now likely to have cash reserves until the year 2005, the system's trustees say.

LEAD: The colorful and ex-quisitely worked decorations in the exhibition ''Rolled, Scrolled, Crimped, and Folded: The Lost Art of Filigree Paperwork'' at the Florian Papp gallery are a wonderful surprise. Most are superb examples of a craft that was popular among women in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries but is virtually unknown today.

LEAD: Winning Colors today became only the third filly ever to win the Kentucky Derby, stealing away to an easy, early lead and then holding off Forty Niner by just a neck at the Churchill Downs finish line.
LEAD: I'VE heard the complaints of white people who grew up in the predominantly black village of Roosevelt, about the difficulties they faced as children because of the color of their skin.

LEAD: MONEY magazine recently singled out Stamford, Danbury and Norwalk as Connecticut cities that are among the most desirable places to live in America. By all accounts, remarkable economic strides have been made in Stamford in the last 25 years. But there are clearly two Stamfords.

LEAD: WHEN I was a kid, like most kids, I had a million things I vowed I would never do when no one would be there to force me to do them. I wouldn't wear a sweater when it was ''chilly,'' or keep my shoes on indoors (or outdoors, for that matter). I wouldn't clean my room or swallow pills. And I would never, ever practice the piano again.

LEAD: In Poland, the Government's attempts to raise prices have often triggered resistance. 1956 - Workers at engineering factory in Poznan strike over wages, food and working conditions and attack nearby prison. Authorities respond with tanks; as many as 70 people are killed and hundreds are injured.
LEAD: Not in my worst nightmare would the Mets bring in a mascot to Shea Stadium. (How about bringing back the organist, though?) PAMELA ROMANO White Plains

LEAD: The day had already taken a bizarre turn, but then it got a bit stranger. The Yankees, who had seen their manager finally arrive at Arlington Stadium today after he said he was attacked in a nearby night spot just after midnight Friday, received another unexpected jolt.

LEAD: THEY'RE usually brief remarks, tossed off in passing, made casually without any great thought. They're not mean. They're not nasty - well, maybe a tiny needle - but what makes them absolutely maddening is that there's usually a grain of truth nestled somewhere.
LEAD: A. J. Buttler, a man with a consuming aversion to untidiness, regularly walks the night streets of Manhattan, ripping down posters and handbills as he goes.

LEAD: Next Sunday, 10,000 architects from Maine to Guam will converge on New York City and the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for the 120th annual national convention of the American Institute of Architects. Besides professional workshops and seminars, the four-day event will afford New Yorkers who have never craned their necks at a New York building the chance to see them in the company of some rather astute visitors.

LEAD: Sally Anne Petrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Petrick of Cranford, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Ephram Zweig, the son of Mollie Levinson Zweig of Oroville, Calif., and Jonas Zweig of Passaic, N.J. The Rev. William J. O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Alfred Landsburg officiated at the Petrick home.

LEAD: A mascot for the Yankees? Absolutely yes! He should be oversized and out of proportion so he can easily be seen from the far reaches of the Stadium. He should possess a large enough mouth so that he can be heard at least two sections away. The ideal mascot will also be able to involve the players in his nutty antics.

LEAD: REAL ESTATE developers across the country are coming into conflict with utility companies over the rising electric energy consumption of new homes, and some state and utility officials are calling for penalties against builders who put up the residential equivalents of gas-guzzlers.

LEAD: MANY PC users think of the electronic spreadsheet, of which Lotus 1-2-3 is the most widely known, strictly as a corporate tool. In doing so, they overlook its usefulness as a financial planning tool for small businesses.
LEAD: William C. (Bill) Speidel, author and founder of Seattle's Underground Tours, died Tuesday. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: Mary Anne Elizabeth O'Callaghan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. O'Callaghan of New York, and Thomas Francis McElroy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James McElroy of Fairfield, Conn., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Queens of All Saints in Brooklyn by the Rev. Anthony M. Rucando.

LEAD: LIKE COUNTLESS OTHER STREETS and highways around the world at that very moment, the Harbor Freeway in Los Angeles was an instant catastrophe, the lines of cars jerking to a halt, the traffic congealing in the fuzzy Southern California sunlight. A television camera was watching somewhere overhead. Magnetic sensors embedded in the pavement measured the speed and density of passing cars.

LEAD: Bill Irwin, as a rubber-legged, befuddled soft-shoe dancer, blows kisses into the lens of a video camera he's holding inches from his face. He desperately wants to attract the beautiful danseuse who's watching the TV monitor, where she now sees her zany suitor, in wobbly, wide-angle close-up, looking like a demented trout.

LEAD: Billy Martin, whose career as a player and manager has been interrupted by frequent battles with players and barroom brawls, was involved in a fight at a bar just after midnight Friday that resulted in a cut inside his left ear and required an overnight stay at a hospital, the team said today.
LEAD: YONDER By Tony Johnston. Illustrated by Lloyd Bloom. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers.
LEAD: ARMS control can be a daunting exercise. But when it comes to controlling nuclear weapons at sea, the United States faces a particularly puzzling dilemma.
LEAD: It's as if Martina Navratilova won the Wimbledon men's singles. As if Nancy Lopez won the Masters. As if Jackie Joyner-Kersee won the men's Olympic decathlon.

LEAD: THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND: How Higher Education Has Failed Democracy and Impoverished the Souls of Today's Students, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) Are tribal arts as high-minded as paintings by the old masters? Is Beethoven no better than the Clash? Allan Bloom believes that creeping relativism is eroding society - and that it's partly Nietzsche's fault.

LEAD: To the Editor: I just returned from a trip to the San Francisco Bay Area where I picked up an auto tape tour in a bookstore for the Monterey Peninsula and Big Sur. It really made the trip, from start to finish.
LEAD: AN AMERICAN FRIEND who recently visited Japan returned home saying that when he feels like bringing back memories of his trip, he plans to take a $10 bill from his wallet and set it on fire.

LEAD: It might seem something of a stretch to discuss new recordings of Alberic Magnard's ''Guercoeur,'' Kurt Weill's ''Aufstieg und Fall der Stadt Mahagonny'' and Leonard Bernstein's ''A Quiet Place'' in one article. Yes, all three are 20th-century operas, although Magnard's barely qualifies, having been completed in 1900.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II today voiced his full approval of strikes by Polish workers, insisting that the crisis in his homeland could be solved only through fundamental political changes leading to democracy.

LEAD: To many songwriters, myself included, Irving Berlin is the American Popular Song, not only for his handsome lyrics and wonderfully accessible melodies, not only for a body of work that twines ivylike around the events of this century, but also because he has become the grid upon which all other pop songs and songwriters are positioned.
LEAD: FOR TOO long, many of us who own property in places like Hudson County have had to listen to the demagoguery of people like Allan De Fina, president of the West New York Housing Organization.

LEAD: THE Restaurant at Stamford Landing, another addition to Stamford's ever-expanding dining scene, has a novel idea: In a setting overlooking Mill River, it presents a menu that combines fresh seafood with the products of a Japanese sushi bar. The best of two seafood-loving worlds, one might think. It would be, if the Western selections on the menu were as successful as the oriental ones.

LEAD: Soviet foreign policy initiatives under Mikhail Gorbachev have so far been addressed mainly to the U.S. and Western Europe. A swing through four Far Eastern capitals makes it clear that there is more to come in the Pacific region.

LEAD: In percent Tax-Exempt Bonds 7.77 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds 6.32 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts 5.68 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 8.88 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 13.90 Continental Illinois, Chicago 14.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 17.75

LEAD: The Soviet Union's junior national basketball team made its second trip to the Bronx last night, and this time it won, beating the New York Gauchos, a squad of schoolboy stars, by 99-82 before a crowd of 1,000.

LEAD: To the Editor: In Travel on March 13 you carried an interesting article on Sheboygan and its bratwurst. With the article you included a map that depicted the Interstate highway system running through Wisconsin.

LEAD: MAREMMA L'AMARA it was called, Maremma the bitter, for the harsh life of its inhabitants, their unforgiving lands, their ruined villages. Of all the well-traveled regions of Tuscany, it was the most feared and remains the least known. Yet it is the one that most captivated the Tuscan imagination - from Dante's lugubrious evocations of violent death and disease in the region he elevated to a symbol of human vanity and eternal despair, to Giovanni
LEAD: JOHN PATRICK NORMAN McHENNESSY The Boy Who Was Always Late. Written and illustrated by John Burningham. Unpaged. New York: Crown Publishers. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 7)
LEAD: FISH cookery is a subtle art.
LEAD: FOR AMS Interiors Inc. of Greenwich, designing a children's sitting room goes beyond dollhouses and teddy bears, especially when it is in the Kips Bay Show House in Manhattan.

LEAD: Curt Byrum sank some lengthy putts on the Spanish Trail Country Club course today to carry a one-shot lead into the final round of the $1.3 million Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational. He is seeking his first victory in six years on the PGA Tour.
LEAD: AFTER wrestling for two decades with a weighty problem - Should men in uniform be allowed to use umbrellas in the rain? - the Navy decided last November: Why not?

LEAD: IN 1967, factions of zealous Red Guards fashioned a monstrous statue of their idol, Mao Zedong, and mounted it on a pedestal in front of the Beijing University library. Last month, in the dark of the night, the statue was toppled and carted off by workmen.

LEAD: Dr. Elizabeth Lathrop Finch, the daughter of Elizabeth J. Finch of New York and Quogue, L.I., and Edward R. Finch Jr. of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter Goodwin Coe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm D. Coe of Bassett, Va. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New

LEAD: 'This year's class really blew our socks off. Our applications were up 50 percent. We originally planned to accept 55 students, but the quality was so good we increased the class size to 75. ' Katherine K. Merseth Director of teacher training, Harvard Graduate School of Education, where a rush of new applicants reflects the revived allure of teaching among college students.

LEAD: Spring, it appears, has finally come to this island off Maine and so has a sense of calm. Islanders spent much of the winter grumbling about a new ferry they deemed unreliable, poorly designed and, all in all, just not what they needed.

LEAD: Eight years ago, Donald Sanders, the founder of the collective known as the New York Art Theater Institute, had an esthetic revelation. While visiting the Hudson River Museum, the director and writer, whose work had always been strongly influenced by changing trends in contemporary painting, found himself overwhelmed by the mystical landscapes of the 19th-century painter Thomas

LEAD: LAST call to prune forsythia; work hard on overgrown shrubs by cutting out to ground level at least one-third of the old wood. Spray fungicides on fruit trees, peonies and dogwoods to discourage fungus diseases later in the season. Transplant spinach and lettuce seedlings to a thumb width apart in garden rows.

LEAD: WHEN Betty Blake and her neighbors tied hundreds of red ribbons around trees in Wantagh last year, they wanted to make a point: that trees are precious and are being torn down by builders to make room for houses.

LEAD: FACED with the strain of a constantly increasing number of AIDS patients, this city's five major hospitals -University, St. Michael's Medical Center, Columbus, Beth Israel and United Medical Center - are forming a consortium to open a nonacute-care facility for such patients. It would provide a level of treatment similar to that of a nursing home.

LEAD: THE Methodists have been called the most American of American churches. Once the nation's largest religious group, their 9.5 million members now rank behind the 52.5 million Roman Catholics and the 14.5 million Southern Baptists. But the denomination, which became independent of the Church of England when the colonies became an independent nation, remains a sensitive barometer of
LEAD: Mascots are infantile, mindless travesties, unneeded and unwanted additions to a great game. Yes, the Yankees should have a mascot. ALAN MICHAEL SAFIE New York

LEAD: No one claims to have seen Michael Jordan walk on water, though some basketball fans are convinced he could if he put his mind to it. Many, however, believe they have actually seen Michael Jordan walk on air. Often. In a number of cities in America. With his size-13 sneakers. This they would testify to in a court of law.

LEAD: THE heavy-set young comedian with a style bordering on the manic-depressive was on the stage of the Treehouse Cafe and Comedy Club in Westport on a recent ''open mike'' night, and things were not going well.

LEAD: THE basic idea is simple enough to have attracted both computer industry giants and entrepreneurs in recent years: If computers can help design and make everything from shoes to automobiles, even other computers, why not use them to automate the painstaking, error-prone process of writing computer programs?
LEAD: IMAGINE a city that once a year opens its homes to strangers, feeds them and is host to them in the largest on-campus high school event in the United States.

LEAD: WHEN Congress passed a law prohibiting anyone in the United States from operating an office on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization, its purpose seemed clear and simple. It wanted to close the P.L.O.'s observer mission to the United Nations because it had found the P.L.O. was a terrorist organization.
LEAD: TRUST By Mary Flanagan. 292 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

LEAD: Vice President Bush was told nearly three years ago by the American Ambassador to Panama of allegations that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was involved in drug trafficking, according to Reagan Administration officials.

LEAD: THE ability to hammer nails skillfully has always been required for most carpentry tasks. But in recent years, fastening aids called construction anchors have been developed that allow strong joints to be created with less skill, particularly in toenailing, the difficult technique of driving nails at angles.

LEAD: Iran has suffered a chain of calamities in its seven-year war with Iraq. Some stem from adroit American policy, which tilted toward Baghdad when the Iraqis seemed in danger of defeat. The tilt has helped restore the military balance between Iran and Iraq; now it's time for America to adjust its diplomacy.
LEAD: FIVE minutes before, her husband had died. In the intensive-care unit at Washington (D.C.) Hospital Center, Lucie McKinney took comfort in the people around her.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR By David Brinkley. Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: THE problem with parenthood is that you never know how well you're doing until it's too late. And the problem with motherhood is that no matter how well you do, it will still be your fault if the child ends up on a psychiatrist's couch.

LEAD: On the surface he appears to be a series of contradictions, a flamboyant teen-ager with a punk hairdo and blue denim designer tennis shorts, who waved to an appreciative crowd after his match yesterday, but said he has not been particularly influenced by growing up in Las Vegas, the ultimate showtown.

LEAD: I would like to respond to ''An Office Casualty: My Right to Smoke.'' In her article, it would seem that Alice Schultze attempts to make an analogy between the negative effects from sitting next to an employee who smokes and the negative effects from sitting next to an employee who is sneezing from the cold or flu.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Ritz of Bridgehampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroleigh Ritz, to Edwin Denison Morgan Evarts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jasper M. Evarts of Landgrove, Vt. The couple plan to marry in September.

LEAD: Two days after she broke her neck when she fell while warming up for the vault competition at an international tournament in Tokyo, Julissa Gomez, a 15-year-old American gymnast, remained in critical condition yesterday, paralyzed and unable to breathe normally.
LEAD: To the Editor: I was amused to read of Joan Shangold's dismay (Letters, March 20) when people in the nonsmoking section at the Free Time restaurant in Paris lit up anyway.
LEAD: THE FINAL show of the season also marks a new beginning for the 10-year-old Crossroads Theatre Company.
LEAD: SINCE the beginning of the year, AIDS has become one of this city's leading weapons in its fight against prostitution.
LEAD: REDECKING of the western spur of the New Jersey Turnpike north of Newark is proceeding on schedule.
LEAD: Turkey
LEAD: HUNDREDS of children could be ousted from their day-care programs because of a change in policy at the Submarine Base in Groton.

LEAD: A French diplomat who has said he was subjected to mock executions during the three years he was held captive in Lebanon returned to a military hospital today suffering from a nervous condition, his wife said.

LEAD: Frances Littell's engagement to Adam D'Arcy Sherman Heath, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Desmond P.S. Heath of New York City and Staatsburg, N.Y., has been made known by her father, Walter D. Littell of New Haven. The couple plan to marry in July.

LEAD: The marriage of Mary Alice McManus, a daughter of Mrs. John Herbert McManus of Bethesda, Md., and the late Mr. McManus, to Dr. Richard L. White Jr., a son of Mrs. John H. Keating Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and the late Dr. White, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Washington.
LEAD: AMERICAN EDUCATION The Metropolitan Experience 1876-1980. By Lawrence A. Cremin. 781 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $35.

LEAD: When, in 1975, the American choreographer Agnes de Mille suffered a debilitating stroke, it was believed she would never again speak, never again walk and, most tragically, never again make dances. Indeed, Miss de Mille's career, spanning some 50 years, was thought to be virtually over, marking a sad end to an extraordinary chapter in dance history.
LEAD: The management of the big Lenin shipyard met today for the first time with workers striking for higher pay and for the legalization of the Solidarity trade union.

LEAD: UNDERCOVER. By Soledad Santiago. (Bantam, Paper, $3.95.) Two cops - one brutal and vengeful, the other kind and caring - patrol the mean streets of Alphabet City in this gritty first novel about the drug subculture of New York's Lower East Side. True to the schematic conventions of such crime procedurals, the ''human'' partner oozes compassion for the local criminals and their prey, who are joint victims of the rampant illegal drug economy, while the hard-nosed cop just wants to beat all the dope fiends to a pulp.
LEAD: Patricia Volk's article ''Lacroix or Le Cash''? (Hers column, April 10). Priceless. VIOLET M. KING Gelview, Ill.

LEAD: FOR decades, it was a tradition in the garment center that most of the elite fashion designers had their showrooms in just two Seventh Avenue buildings, 550 or 530, both at 39th Street. The clothes may have been made in Brooklyn or Pennsylvania, Hong Kong or India, but the designers showed their new models to buyers from around the country in elegant settings on Seventh

LEAD: In wonderland, the White Queen told Alice that it only takes practice to believe impossible things. ''Why, sometimes,'' she said, ''I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.''

LEAD: IT took three years of close work between Republicans and Democrats and labor and business to craft the trade bill that the Senate and House passed by large margins last month. And all sides - including the White House - appear to agree on the measure's get-tough-with-your-trading-partners thrust.

LEAD: NOT all preservation in New York is the result of noisy hearings before the Landmarks Preservation Commission, for most old buildings fall or survive without controversy, as the result of coincidence or chance.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency has given a qualified endorsement to a sale of offshore oil and gas leases in the North Atlantic despite a top agency official's belief that the sale, planned for next February, should be scuttled.

LEAD: Kathleen Freeman Hughes, a daughter of Eileen L. Hughes of New York and the late Emmet John Hughes, was married yesterday to Philip Stimson Murphy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Murphy of Los Gatos, Calif. Jean Davidson of the Universal Life Church officiated at the couple's home in Los Angeles.
LEAD: Preliminary figures show that Vermont ski areas enjoyed their second-best season on record despite lower-than-average snowfall.

LEAD: Dr. Hans Popper, an authority on liver diseases and a principal figure in the founding of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York, died of pancreatic cancer Friday. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: ''GOOD morning, Miss Shelley and visitor.'' In collective voice, the students of Long Island's only black prep school sprang to their feet at the sight of their school administrator.
LEAD: Psychologists have their own view of American Presidential elections. For some, the outcome in November hinges on optimism.

LEAD: In a land where more than 60 percent of the people are nomads, living in the deserts with the cattle, camels and sheep they raise, heroes are in short supply, most of them men of the sword or cloth.

LEAD: The height of the dance season is not necessarily the best time for a small foreign company, even one attached to France's national opera, to make a New York debut. There is no question that the sleek, streamlined and superb dancers of the experimental dance troupe that is part of the Paris Opera Ballet were nearly overlooked amid the attention paid to the feathers and ruffles of Christian Lacroix's very French costumes for American Ballet Theater's new production of ''Gaite Parisienne.
LEAD: URGING President Reagan to accept the plant-closing provision of the trade bill, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis points to a law enacted in his own state in 1984.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel in Saddle River, N.J., Jane Ellen Gifford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Gifford of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Keith Jude Lindenburg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Lindenburg of Bristol, R.I. Msgr. Robert T. Lennon performed the ceremony.

LEAD: EVERY Sunday morning, several acres of an old military airfield west of Warsaw become, for a few hours, the city's most active automobile salesroom. At what appears more like a county fair, with hot charcoal grills wafting the scent of browning kielbasa, enterprising buyers browse among dumpy little Polski Fiats (the locally assembled Fiat subcompact), new Mercedes Benz sedans and occasional old Pontiacs or Chevrolets that have often been brought into the country by
LEAD: THE County Medical Center has secured state approval to become the first hospital in the Hudson Valley region to perform kidney transplants.
LEAD: Early this school year, Kenneth DeSanctis, a teacher at Public School 83 in East Harlem, worried that one of his students was getting lost in the shuffle of 26 clamorous first graders.

LEAD: More than 600 anti-abortion demonstrators left New York City yesterday after a week of blockades, arrests and prayer vigils, leaving behind a debate over whether they had significantly helped the anti-abortion movement.

LEAD: To the Editor: When I returned recently to Newark International Airport, I learned the meaning of compound stupidity. I retrieved my car from long-term parking and went to pick up my wife, 6-month-old son and six bags from the sidewalk outside the baggage claim area. I followed the signs to Arrivals and pulled the car near where my family and luggage were waiting.
LEAD: Profits of New York's farmers increased in 1987 for the second consecutive year, up 23 percent from 1986, according to a report from the State Agricultural Statistics Service.

LEAD: There is a German say-ing that could serve as a motto for much of the work of the American artist John Sloan: ''The air of the city makes you free.'' No doubt city air can also oppress, and Sloan's art finds room for some of its harsher and more desolating effects. But the sense of freedom is what comes across most strongly - freedom to be yourself, to stay up at all hours, to share the life of the street; freedom to stroll around and observe.

LEAD: Marathon and triathalon atheletes talk about ''hitting the wall,'' that moment when they find their energy reserves depleted. For Kerry Downey, a runner in a recent quadrathalon held here, the problem was not hitting the wall but losing a beet.

LEAD: Q. The ceiling in our family room is stained and discolored because the toilet overflowed in the bathroom above this room. Will it be necessary to replace this ceiling, or will it eventually dry out so it can be repainted?

LEAD: I cannot say quite when I first heard of Trebitsch Lincoln. He is one of those types, notorious in their own day, who sink rapidly into obscurity after their deaths, sometimes hovering briefly in the footnotes of history. I believe that the outline of Trebitsch Lincoln's bizarre story was recounted to me some years ago in Jerusalem by the editor of the Encyclopedia Judaica, Geoffrey Wigoder, whose encyclopedic knowledge of such historical byways is unrivaled.

LEAD: It was 1908 when the first 781 Japanese walked off a migrant ship to reach out for the riches promised by a wild and tropical land. Instead, they found themselves replacing recently freed slaves on coffee plantations in the interior of Brazil.

LEAD: MY WHOLE family lives with me in a multigenerational array. The images of loved ones, frozen in time, live here in my home, displayed behind glass-fronted frames and - more deeply - locked in my memory.

LEAD: Hiding Out Starring Jon Cryer, Keith Coogan, Annabeth Gish, Oliver Cotton, Claude Brooks, Tim Quill. Directed by Bob Giraldi. 1987. HBO Video. 98 minutes. $89.99. Rated PG-13. Some strong language.
LEAD: The Government of Singapore today accused an American diplomat of interfering in its domestic affairs and asked Washington to withdraw the envoy.

LEAD: THE National Park System Advisory Board last week deferred to the Secretary of the Interior on the question of designating the Post Road Historic District in Rye as a National Historic Landmark.

LEAD: Hope Susan Gittis, a daughter of Sondra Gittis of Philadelphia and Howard Gittis of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and Robert Sheft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Sheft of Roslyn Heights, L.I., were married last evening at the Pierre Hotel in New York. Rabbi David Wice performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The first state testing of ground water at the Eastman Kodak Company's industrial park has found chemical and metal contamination, officials said. An analysis by the Department of Environmental Conservation showed that at least 12 chemicals and five heavy metals were present in ground water in and around the site in amounts that exceed state levels.

LEAD: One method of cutting medical costs is to ration services. Robert H. Blank, author of the book ''Rationing Medicine,'' and associate director of the program for biosocial research at Northern Illinois University, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about some of the choices society must make to contain medical costs.

LEAD: THE political thaw in Soviet-American relations is beginning to work its effect on the commercial front. This is the impression I brought back from last month's United States-Soviet Union Trade and Economic Council meeting in Moscow. This twice-postponed event brought together 500 chief executives from major American corporations and their Soviet counterparts in a four-day series of seminars and talks devoted to improving bilateral trade ties.

LEAD: IN assessing the state of the nation's space program as the Reagan Administration nears an end, experts inside and outside the Government often use two words: muddle and disarray. President Reagan, one of the biggest space enthusiasts to occupy the White House, will leave behind a host of costly projects and innovative policies.
LEAD: EVEN though I am a woman of considerable age, in spring my fancy always turns to baseball.

Meister of Waite Hill, Ohio, and the late United States Representative Oliver Payne Bolton. The Rev. George A. Westerberg performed the ceremony at St.

LEAD: AT dusk, Anthony O'Reilly is strolling the grounds of his 500-acre estate, Castlemartin, surveying with satisfaction his breeding cattle, his race horses and his 18thcentury 28-room mansion house.
LEAD: PARADE IN PRINCETON Princeton will mark the 200th anniversary of its Fire Department Saturday with a celebration that begins with a parade and ends with fireworks.
LEAD: Alice Schultze complains in her recent article [ 'An Office Casualty: My Right to Smoke,'' Opinion Page ] that ''No smoking in the workplace is the latest form of discrimination.''
LEAD: Perri Klass mentions the scarcity of women in leadership positions in medicine. Working at a university has given me the opportunity to observe this phenomenon, and to think about it.

LEAD: DIAL 1-900-909-1234. Woody Woodpecker picks up. ''It's Woody Woodpecker,'' he says. ''Thanks for calling. Haaa-haa-ha-ha-haaa.'' Then he puts on Dinosaur Buddy who tells how the telegraph and the telephone came about.

LEAD: WITH finales sprinkled throughout the schedule, it is comforting to report on a seasonal start. The 37th annual arts series at the Merryall Community Center began last evening with a lecture by the gossip columnist Liz Smith.

LEAD: THE vibration of the gong washed over the tones of the other instruments. Suddenly, the drummer reared his head and the pace became frenetic. Dynamics and density escalated. The wooden hammers struck the bronze keys relentlessly, in perfect synchronization. Rhythmic patterns repeated and repeated; melodic lines interlocked precisely.

LEAD: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, competing in the 100-meter hurdles for the first time this year, set an American record tonight by winning the women's event in 12.70 seconds at the S&W Modesto Invitational track and field meet.

LEAD: The 1988 career grants of the Avery Fisher Artist Program have been awarded to Pamela Frank and Ida Kavafian, violinists; Andrew Rangell, pianist, and David Starobin, guitarist, each of whom will receive $10,000.

LEAD: The Devils approached their first playoff appearance as if assigned to an experimental classroom. Everything was new to them, but everything on the playoff syllabus seemed possible to study, comprehend, and eventually master before moving on to the next lesson.

LEAD: The West Bank seems far removed from this cement-block development town just north of the Negev. But a visit from Foreign Minister Shimon Peres made clear that the Palestinian uprising is a blazing political issue for virtually every Israeli.

LEAD: ''Beetlejuice,'' which is quickly turning into a hit of serious proportions (it earned more than $9 million in its first three weeks of release), is a farce for our place and time. It's technically sophisticated and so amiable and well meaning that it seems rude to point out that, like some of our public figures, it is more of a bore to watch than to describe.
LEAD: Mayor Koch proposed doubling capital spending for the New York City school system yesterday, saying he would seek $5.2 billion over the next 10 years.

LEAD: A recent issue of the American Contract Bridge League's Bulletin brings bad news for the future of bridge in North America, but also a ray of hope. A survey of student interests, conducted at nearly 400 colleges and universities by a group at the University of California at Los Angeles, showed bridge to be at the bottom of a long list.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Kentucky Derby Day at Churchill Downs got off to a strange start with a series of mix-ups surrounding the day's first race. A bettor made a winning $20,000 bet by accident, then thanked track officials for canceling it for him.

LEAD: After James Callahan died in a fraternity hazing incident at Rutgers University in February, some students rationalized his death as being the 18-year-old freshman's own fault. After all, he consented to the hazing; he just got in over his head. Indictments this week of 15 fraternity members send a different message, one that may prevent more senseless tragedies.

LEAD: SUFFOLK COUNTY EXECUTIVE Patrick G. Halpin's promised foreign trade initiative, designed to expand Long Island's exports, will get under way tomorrow amid growing pressure for the county to step up its efforts.

LEAD: When physicians working for the Phoenix Cardinals determined that Ken Easley, the All-Pro defensive back the Cardinals had obtained in a trade with the Seattle Seahawks, was suffering from a kidney condition, the medical report seemed to come as a surprise to everybody concerned.

LEAD: Q. The ceiling in our family room is stained and discolored because the toilet overflowed in the bathroom above this room. Will it be necessary to replace this ceiling, or will it eventually dry out so it can be repainted?

LEAD: Having found only a blind alley in Tawana Brawley's assertions of racial and sexual abuse by a gang of white abductors, investigators have now turned to the drug-infested streets of Newburgh, N.Y., for fresh clues to the black teen-ager's mysterious four-day disappearance last fall.

LEAD: Every generation, or at least every art-world generation, has its own Museum of Modern Art - a complicated institution that it loves, learns to know by heart and almost invariably loses. This is because the museum has, since its inception, regularly changed and expanded. Nonetheless, every change takes some getting used to.

LEAD: LAST January's headlines carried unexpected tales of woe for health care consumers. First was the news that health insurance premiums for millions of workers would jump between 10 percent and 70 percent in 1988. Then there was word that premiums for people on Medicare would rise 38 percent and that health maintenance organization costs would rise by as much as 20 percent in 1988.

LEAD: Japanese think of themselves as an honest lot, and, for the most part, the self-trust is not misplaced. Their low crime rate attests to that. But sometimes they give themselves too much credit. Take Japanese tax codes. The law allows the shopowner, the farmer, the real-estate speculator - basically anyone in business for himself - to declare his own income and expenses.

LEAD: IF your house has an electric water heater, central air-conditioning or a swimming pool with an electric pump, the Long Island Lighting Company may want to talk to you soon about turning them off.

LEAD: Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida, the clear front-runner in that state's race for a seat in the United States Senate, withdrew yesterday from the campaign for the Democratic nomination.

LEAD: Memphis begins at the river, wide and brown and swollen with the rains of spring. LEAD: HOW can my first-born be 45 years old today when I am still in my 20's? How could she have changed so quickly from the cute little red-faced baby who was born on that icy day in January 45 years ago, when I am still the same young woman? And as I kiss her and wish her a happy birthday, I wonder if she is asking herself how that graying lady with the wrinkles here and there could have changed so soon from the dark-haired, round-faced person she remembered from her childhood.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE ''Co-ops for Sale'' signs on the sides of multifamily buildings tell the story of housing in transition on Bay Parkway in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Apartment houses built for rental occupancy over the first half of this century are gradually being converted to owner occupancy.

LEAD: With two out in the seventh inning and Bob Ojeda tiring slightly, Dave Johnson, the manager of the Mets, walked solemnly out of the dugout. Almost instantly, Gary Carter took the mound in the bullpen and, smiling broadly, quickly signaled he was ready if needed.

LEAD: A dance review last Sunday about the April 27 performance of the American Ballet Theater production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' misidentified the dancer who performed the ''Gold'' solo. He was Johan Renvall.

LEAD: Nearly 150,000 people visit the House of Seven Gables in Salem every year, but few who tour the 17th-century house overlooking Salem Harbor, the house made famous as Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''House of Seven Gables,'' know their visits support a neighborhood settlement house that began in 1908.

LEAD: Perri Klass asks if women are better doctors. The question is sexist and irrelevant. A female physician is no less able to perform open-heart surgery than a male doctor is able to tell patients, caringly, that they have cancer. Sensitivity, empathy and sincerity are not female qualities; they are human ones.

LEAD: BY textbook definition, the H. J. Heinz Company should be a pretty tense place. Its managers are constantly asked to squeeze yet another penny out of costs. Subsidiary presidents must vie at planning meetings for capital resources. Annual earnings and growth goals are ambitious, yet a good portion of each executive's compensation depends on meeting them.

LEAD: The United Way in the New York metropolitan region plans to solicit contributions this year from 2 million workers and retired employees who have not been asked for donations in past fund-raising campaigns.

LEAD: Bayport $195,000 3 Cole Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old ranch; basement, hardwood floors, 2-car garage; taxes $4,900. East Meadow $174,000 396 Avalon Place 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500.

LEAD: Because of a distributor's change of plans, a picture caption on page 19 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide give an incorrect date for the opening of James Bruce's horror movie ''The Suicide Club.'' It will open at neighborhood theaters on Friday, May 20, not May 13.

LEAD: The Polish Government's violent crackdown on recent labor protests has jeopardized American support for the country's economic recovery plan, the State Department's second-ranking official said today.

LEAD: LOOK what burst out of their cocoons this spring: men's jackets, which have been drastically reshaped by a handful of forward-thinking designers.

LEAD: The advertisements these days are proclaiming it ''the most honored film in 25 years,'' and indeed, Bernardo Bertolucci's new movie, ''The Last Emperor,'' which won nine Oscars at last month's Academy Awards ceremonies, does dazzle the eye. The film, in telling the life story of Henry Aisin-Gioro Pu Yi, the last, quivering twig on the Manchu Dynasty's venerable tree, is distinguished by its gorgeous re-creation of the lacquered, ceremonious interior of the Forbidden City, where Pu Yi was virtually imprisoned for 12 years after the tottering dynasty crumbled into nothingness in 1912.

LEAD: Tennis Sabatini vs. Kelesi in Final: Second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and 14th-seeded Helen Kelesi of Canada advanced to the final of the Italian Open yesterday with straight-set victories in 86-degree heat in Rome. Sabatini, the heavy favorite after the withdrawal of top-seeded Chris Evert because of a heel injury, staved off a set point and needed nearly two hours to beat 13th-seeded Judith Wiesner of Austria, 7-6, 6-3.

LEAD: The marriage of Julie Joy Larson and Thomas Gaylord Brown, both assistant buyers at Macy's New York, took place yesterday at the Woodlands Inn in The Woodlands, Tex. The Rev. Charles C. Hendricks, pastor of the Woodlands Community Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: TO walk among the penguins has been a dream of mine ever since I learned that they existed. The idea beckoned from my subconscious like an Art Deco vision, tantamount to stepping into an elegant black and white film filled with men in top hats and tails where everything would be clean and cool.

LEAD: SHOULD doctors warn sexual partners of AIDS patients that they may have been infected, even if the patient objects? The New York Legislature will soon consider that question, and the result could be the first state law in the nation permitting doctors to make such disclosures.

LEAD: BEAUTIFUL ISLANDS. By Russell Martin. (Linden/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Russell Martin's well-written first novel traces a year in the life of Jack Healy, a decent, fortyish family man whose strenuous career has put too much pressure on his marriage. This seemingly predictable material is made fresh because Healy is not a typical overworked professional but an astronaut, and because the year revolves around the real-life explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

LEAD: Stacy Pamela Salob, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Salob of Brookville and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Michael Steven Goldman, a son of Sharon Elliot of Merrick, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Morton Goldman, were married last evening. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L

LEAD: When he was in his 20's Harold Shapero was thought by many to be the young American composer most likely to succeed. He had everything going for him. He was an impressive pianist. His music displayed an inspired ability for tune making and technique to fashion works intricately detailed yet cohesive.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 2 9 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's.
LEAD: THRIFTY energy habits, shrinking office quarters and sloppy maintenance are helping to pollute the air that workers breathe in many office buildings.

LEAD: The Veterans Administration's system for reviewing veterans' appeals of denied benefits has been attacked in a lawsuit as ''assembly-line'' justice that denies fair hearings to thousands of claimants.

LEAD: Brent Ashton scored twice, including the go-ahead goal late in the second period, as the Detroit Red Wings came back from two successive losses in Edmonton for a 5-2 victory over the Oilers in Game 3 of the Campbell Conference finals tonight.
LEAD: He may work in Washington, but that doesn't mean that John Thompson, the Georgetown basketball coach, has been caught up in the thaw in Soviet-American relations.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Charles Jensen of New York and Mystic, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Ann Jensen, to Charles L. Young, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Young of Shrewsbury, Mass. A July 3 wedding is planned.
LEAD: MOVING to outwit robbers and muggers, Paris taxicab drivers introduced an electrifying solution in October: the ''blazing seat.''

LEAD: Patricia Volk's arithmetic explained: A 10 percent discount after New York City sales tax nets out to about 2 percent. Fifty Lacroix dresses ($750,000) less 2 percent discount equals one Lacroix ($15,000) free (no discount, no sales tax, dated register receipts and price tags required). FRANK J.
LEAD: WHEN the housing market weakens or interest rates start to soar, sellers often help to finance sales of their homes by offering buyers mortgages at below-market rates of interest.

LEAD: JAY SPIELER SAYS HE'S STILL PARTIAL TO the vivid shirts, paisley ties and plaid suits he wore in the giddy days before Black Monday. Spieler, a broker with Drexel Burnham Lambert, insists last October's market collapse hasn't caused him to change his image by a thread. ''In other words, '' he jokes, ''I'm not wearing a hair shirt.

LEAD: Everything Grand Canyon College of Phoenix did Friday turned into a run. And the game turned into the highest-scoring runaway in college baseball history.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH ''The Price'' by Arthur Miller never made a big dent in the commercial theater, it has had a flourishing regional afterlife. Now, 20 years after its Broadway premiere, the play holds up as a work of masterly craftsmanship, psychological validity and emotional force. LEAD: The engagement of Ann Elizabeth Shoemaker and Charles Montgomery Meredith 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Meredith 3d of Quakertown, Pa., has been announced by the future bride's mother, Barbara May Shoemaker, of Erdenheim, Pa. A December wedding is planned.

LEAD: Karen Beth Merdinger and Mark Spencer Labe plan to marry June 12. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Merdinger of Rye, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Labe of New Milford, N.J. Miss Merdinger is a senior sales representative for Chemical Bank in New York. Her father is the president of Simplex Machinery, a machine tool importer and distributor in Hackensack, N.J.
LEAD: The Soviet Union is embroiled in a turbulent struggle against its own authoritarian tradition.

LEAD: THE reaction was classic last week when the Supreme Court ruled that the Sharp Electronics Corporation could lawfully conspire with one of its high-price retailers to shut out a discounter from selling Sharp products.
LEAD: PUTTING one's head into the lion's mouth is not only a great stunt in the circus but also in the chess arena. The problem is the same in both domains: getting it out again.
LEAD: In the public mind, mothers have their ups and downs.
LEAD: An article on April 24 about the Westchester County Hispanic Advisory Board misidentified George Castellanos. He is the board's chairman.

LEAD: WHILE the emergence of an original full-scale musical, even with a title like ''Last Tango in New Wango,'' may not be uncommon for a drama student's thesis, it isn't every semester that a production company is formed as part of the project.
LEAD: Numerous New Haven police officers called in sick today, apparently in protest of stalled contract negotiations.

LEAD: Q. The ceiling in our family room is stained and discolored because the toilet overflowed in the bathroom above this room. Will it be necessary to replace this ceiling, or will it eventually dry out so it can be repainted?

LEAD: In the 1950's, when Irving Berlin com-plained that 20th Century-Fox had paid more to Rodgers and Hammerstein for ''Oklahoma'' than it was offering him for ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' Joseph M. Schenk, the studio head, tried to reason with him.
LEAD: Raising Cain Instead of Steins

LEAD: Donald Byrd is a choreographer who has the gift of making dancers move. He is a humanist who responds to the world around him, seeming to acknowledge it as providing a valid and valuable context for dance. His is a bold, clear, strong voice - trying to find its way through a good deal of static clutter.

LEAD: In his poignant article ''The Wolf Inside'' (Body and Mind, April 3), John Stone showed great sensitivity for the suffering and pain of lupus patients. The outlook has indeed improved since Flannery O'Connor was diagnosed in the early 1950's, but there are still too many lives cut short by this pernicious and complex disease.

LEAD: In 1849 Count Leo Tolstoy established a school for peasant children at his country estate, Yasnaya Polyana (Clear Glades). He also taught at the school, and wrote and published a primer that included sections on teaching reading, handwriting and arithmetic, as well as the fables he wrote for the pupils.
LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's office today defended the decision to deport Mubarak E. Awad, a Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolent protest.

LEAD: After an eight-month search, the Rockefeller Foundation has named Peter C. Goldmark Jr. as its new president, choosing a corporate executive with a 20-year career in public service and a reputation in New York State and New York City government as an ingenious problem solver.

LEAD: AS many high school seniors rejoice over college acceptances, their parents worry about meeting next fall's tuition bill. Unfortunately, there isn't much they can do between now and September to amass an education fund other than to take out a home equity loan.

LEAD: THIS IS NOT YOUR TYPICAL COUNTRY kitchen, but then the house - a three-story, brick Georgian structure designed in 1906 by the architect Charles Platt - is not your typical country house either. LEAD: IN A PUERTO RICAN COMMUNITY center in the South Bronx, its walls tattooed with graffiti, the crowd is jammed into every available space, anxiously awaiting the candidate. Outside, a chill rain is falling, splattering the chunks of broken cars in an adjacent vacant lot; the noise of an elevated subway train rumbles through the room.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Over the years, Nebraska's Presidential primary has often generated excitement.

Rabbi Solomon Ackrish performed the ceremony.
LEAD: AS United States military spending is steadily declining, pressure is rising on America's allies to carry a larger share of the financial burden of their defense.

LEAD: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York, Hilary Whittaker Curtis, the daughter of William G. Curtis 4th of New York and the late Roberta Lamm Curtis, was married yesterday to William George Hartman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hartman Jr. of Northbrook, Ill. Msgr. Henry J. Mansell performed the ceremony.

LEAD: SIXTEEN families who have farmed their New Jersey spreads continuously for more than 200 years will be honored next month at a jubilee that will feature tributes by the Secretaries of Agriculture of 10 states from Maine to Delaware.

LEAD: PARIS NOTEBOOKS: Essays & Reviews. By Mavis Gallant. (Random House, $17.95.) Reviewers' copies of new books commonly come with fliers from the publisher tucked in, lauding the author's previously published work. There is one such accompanying ''Paris Notebooks,'' a collection of Mavis Gallant's essays and reviews, mostly written for The New Yorker and this publication, praising her latest book of short stories.

LEAD: Since our daughter Victoria was born in March 1987, with major heart defects, we have had ample opportunity to observe both male and female doctors (''Are Women Better Doctors?'' by Perri Klass, April 10). We were overwhelmingly impressed by the quality of her medical care -by women and men doctors.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Patricia Volk captured my own feelings when she wrote, ''Is it Lacroix? Is it La Salvation Army? What, besides $14,950, is la difference?''

LEAD: After years of assaults and intimidation in her native El Salvador, then months in a detention center fearing deportation, Telba Dora Erazo was granted political asylum this week in a cinder block courtroom in this sun-baked border town.

LEAD: Through the years, the Boston Celtics have never been known as gracious winners or losers. Their feeling of superiority would never allow it. LEAD: Friday's tribute to Jerome Hines at Carnegie Hall could have been better managed. Planning and promoting require more than renting a big hall; they mean making sure it is full. Mr. Hines's audience was embarrassingly small, enthusiastic though it was.

LEAD: To some children the Vietnam War may be dry history. Yet the two intersecting black granite walls of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial bearing the names of 58,156 servicemen and women who died in the war or are still missing, have become a site of pilgrimage for families and other visitors to Washington.

LEAD: NEW YORK, DEC. 9, 1987: Riots have erupted in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. The networks show scenes of rampaging Palestinian youths hurling rocks and insults, Israeli soldiers firing back. Is this it? Has the pot boiled over at last? Twenty years of occupying an alien people, and now on our television screens a harvest of rage.

LEAD: When it comes to entertaining children - your own or borrowed ones - the most rewarding activity is reading aloud to them. Almost all children prefer being read to, even unskillfully, to watching any television program, no matter how violent and flashy. We're talking post-Mother Goose and ''I'm a Little

LEAD: Unemployment went down again in April, reaching a level not seen in 14 years. The April rate was put at 5.4 percent, down from 5.5 percent in March. While no doubt encouraging to the 606,000 people who found jobs last month, the steady decline in unemployment is raising concern that a tight labor market could push wages up enough to produce worrisome inflation.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH auto-focusing cameras seem to be everywhere these days, they're not the only game in town. Last week, for example, I needed a lightweight, portable, 120-roll-film camera that could hang at my side while I toured the exotic avenues of Barcelona. Ever see a 120-format point-and-shoot camera with automatic focusing?

LEAD: IT IS, SO TO SPEAK, A CHIP OFF the old engine block. Conceived as a successor to the British-built Cosworth engine that has captured every Indianapolis 500 since 1978, the Chevrolet-Ilmor V-8 was initially designed, in fact, by two former Cosworth engineers. ''We ran it in one of our spare cars in 1985,'' says Derrick Walker, vice president and general manager of Penske Racing, which, along with Chevrolet, financed the endeavor of the two designers, Mario Illien and Paul Morgan.
LEAD: ''From an inflationary concern, we may be closer to full employment than we wis but you can't say that from a social point of view.'' - Roger Brinner, an economist at Data Resources.

LEAD: SUSAN HURLEY HEALY, 38 years old, of Milford is the Young Mother of the Year in Connecticut.
LEAD: ALTHOUGH debatable as an idea, ''Painting Is Silent Poetry'' sounds right as the title for the Kornbluth Gallery's current show by four artists.

LEAD: THE Irish Republican Army took advantage of the shape of things to come on the European mainland when it killed three British soldiers and wounded three others last weekend in separate car-bomb and gun ambushes in the Netherlands. The men were relaxed in civilian clothes amid the off-base nightlife of Dutch border towns, far, but not far enough, from the Irish troubles.

LEAD: At the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., Dani Jayne Hutchins, the daughter of Mrs. Dan E. Hutchins of New Canaan and the late Mr. Hutchins, was married yesterday to David James Mollenkamp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Mollenkamp of Apple Valley, Calif. The bride, a cum laude graduate of Bryn Mawr College, is a management consultant at General Electric Consulting Services in Somerset, N.J.

LEAD: THE Arena Players Repertory Company usually offers at least one Agatha Christie mystery each season. This time around it is presenting ''Murder at the Vicarage,'' a mystery thriller with a plethora of subjects.

LEAD: The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Alexandra Masterson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Masterson of New York and Houston, to John Ralph Dumke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Dumke of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

LEAD: MANY Israelis seemed reluctant last week to talk about their Army's latest victory. For the first time, the Israeli Army sought a direct confrontation with the pro-Palestinian Party of God in southern Lebanon, killing 40 of the Shiite Moslem militiamen and losing three of their men. The Israeli soldiers also came within a few miles of Syrian front lines in Lebanon, risking a conflict with Syria.
LEAD: LETTERS TO OLGA June 1979-September 1982. By Vaclav Havel. Translated by Paul Wilson. 397 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

LEAD: 'PETER PAN' EXHIBIT Early 18th-century photographs of the two boys who were the inspiration for ''Peter Pan'' and other items related to the evolution of the original stage version will be displayed at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library of Yale University.
LEAD: FAIRFIELD COUNTY has a surplus of condominiums, real estate experts say, and some estimate that prices may have dropped as much as 10 to 15 percent over the past year.

LEAD: The State Department intends to deny a visa to an American-educated Vietnamese economist who is regarded as a leading advocate of economic liberalization in Hanoi, according to groups and individuals in the United States supporting his application.

LEAD: Lucie Livingston, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Livingston of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Seth George Aidinoff, the son of M. Bernard Aidinoff of New York and Amagansett, L.I., and the late Mrs. Aidinoff, plan to marry in August.
LEAD: If a New York baseball team adopts a mascot, it should not be an animal but a vegetable. A bush. Because that team will be truly bush league. MARISA HAGAN New York
LEAD: FOR Lech Walesa, the head of Poland's outlawed but remarkably vigorous Solidarity trade union, they were, through most of the week, the ''kids.''
LEAD: Vice President Bush has characterized the Rev. Jesse Jackson as a ''hustler from Chicago.''

LEAD: At least 18 Buddhist monks, including a 12-year-old boy, were killed during nationalist protests in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa in early March, according to a new report from a foreigner who went to Tibet after the violence.

LEAD: The New York City terminal for a new Hudson River ferry between Hoboken, N.J. and Manhattan will be built at the north end of Battery Park City, a short walk from the World Trade Center, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and Battery Park City announced yesterday.

LEAD: Most Western music is based on an octave divided into 12 equal pitches. Of course, the octave can be split differently, as it is in other cultures, and as composers of the Microtonal persuasion have argued for decades. Microtonalists insist that the mathematically pure intervals yielded by, for instance, a 31-note scale, are inherently more pleasing than the slightly impure ones we are used to.

LEAD: If Oliver North considers it an honor to have been indicted in the Iran-contra affair, as he said last week, will he be embarrassed if he is found not guilty? And, if so, would that affect any political ambitions he has? Mr. North, who is charged with conspiring to defraud the Government by diverting arms-sales profits to the Nicaraguan contras, talked about the case in a speech at Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va.

LEAD: I used to have record shelves. They held LP's and 45-r.p.m. singles, more or less alphabetized. In the late 1970's, I squeezed in 12-inch singles and a handful of cassettes, and set aside a shelf end for a novelty, 10-inch EP's. Then the 1980's came, and the Walkman. Cassettes started to stack up -cassettes with more songs than the album with the same title, cassettes of rare albums, cassette-only recordings, dance tapes.

LEAD: Without ''conceding a legal obligation to do so,'' the Cuomo administration today made public the Governor's ''private'' schedules for the last five years after several news organizations requested them under the state's Freedom of Information law. There was only one catch. Everything private was missing.

LEAD: Michael Tilson Thomas put together a thoughtful all-Czechoslovak program for the Pittsburgh Symphony's concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. And one thing that can be said right away about the performances was that the orchestra itself is sounding very good. Occasionally, when the violins ventured into their topmost range, things sounded a little stringy and acidic.

LEAD: BETWEEN 1870 and the early 1890's optimism about Colorado, embodied in discoveries of gold but mostly of silver, crested in the Rockies and converged with the other national sensation of the era, the steam-driven narrow gauge railroad. Along with their precious ore the trains carried ''the emotional treasure of a westering people,'' wrote Lucius Beebe, the extravagant chronicler of Colorado's railroads.

LEAD: Lucie Livingston, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Livingston of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Seth George Aidinoff, the son of M. Bernard Aidinoff of New York and Amagansett, L.I., and the late Mrs. Aidinoff, plan to marry in August.

LEAD: The United States' war on drugs has recently led to the attempted ouster of Panama's military leader, the virtual kidnapping of a Honduran, new efforts to burn crops in Bolivia and a proposed Congressional resolution accusing Mexican officials of accepting bribes. Only a short time ago, similar actions were directed at Pakistan, Colombia, Peru, Turkey and

LEAD: BETWEEN 1870 and the early 1890's optimism about Colorado, embodied in discoveries of gold but mostly of silver, crested in the Rockies and converged with the other national sensation of the era, the steam-driven narrow gauge railroad. Along with their precious ore the trains carried ''the emotional treasure of a westering people,'' wrote Lucius Beebe, the extravagant chronicler of Colorado's railroads.
LEAD: BURIED in a dealer's bargain box at this year's New York International Stamp Exposition were two postcards that, despite their lack of bulk, are referred to hereafter as The Altoona Papers.

LEAD: MAYOR KOCH is criticized by his own Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, for his unfettered attacks on the Rev. Jesse Jackson before the New York Presidential primary. He stammers like an exasperated parent as Mr. Ward and the Fire Commissioner, Joseph F. Bruno, all but come to blows in public. And he calls the chief engineer of his own Transportation Department a ''dummy'' for failing to warn of the rotting underside of the closed Williamsburg

LEAD: WHERE fitness is concerned, we live in an age of numbers. We measure our weight, the resting and exercising pulse rates, the caloric intake at meals and even blood pressure. But in terms of preventing heart disease and possibly living longer through regular exercise, such numbers pale in importance when compared with the four values that reflect the fats found in our blood.
LEAD: On a hectic night that involved litigation, the Devils evened their Stanley Cup semifinal series against the Bruins at two games apiece with a 3-1 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: North Castle Partners in Greenwich, Conn., had a good haul last week. Its new client, with $4 million in billings, is Booth Food Products of Portsmouth, N.H., a division of National Sea Products. The brands to be promoted are Booth and Fisher Boy. The previous agency was the Leo Burnett Company of Toronto.
