LEAD: Tom Wolfe, Meryl Streep and Willie Nelson will not be directly affected if a proposal to take International Creative Management private receives Government approval. But their agents, and those representing 2,600 other agency clients, could be. They stand to be paid much more if the proposed leveraged buyout of I.C.M.

LEAD: MOJO NEW YORK, a recently established outpost of a major Australian ad agency network, has won the international trade advertising account of the mighty Reader's Digest even though it was a latecomer to the competition.

LEAD: SAM FREEMAN can tell you a great deal about Central Park. He can give you an exact number of lampposts on the east side of a reservoir, recount the total of park benches in a six-mile stretch and rattle off a precise figure of garbage cans situated in a designated area.

LEAD: The night didn't begin routinely, and someplace between a dream and a nightmare, two teams with the Stanley Cup on their minds had to cope with a game that threatened to disintegrate before it ever began.
LEAD: John DiGilio, a reputed leader of the Genovese crime family in New Jersey, was reported missing by his wife from their apartment in Holmdel, N.J., officials said early this morning.

LEAD: Sam Spade, he's not. Fred D. Knapp is a modern private investigator, skilled in the use of the computer modem and the art of searching public records. Because he operates in New York City in the late 1980's, his prey is a particular local species: the illegal rent-regulated tenant.

LEAD: THE Bethlehem Steel Corporation's announcement last week of a public offering of 10 million of its common shares at $19 each is viewed as a sign not only of the attractiveness of steel stocks but also of the relative prosperity of basic industry.

LEAD: Israeli Ouster Appealed A Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolence appealed Israel's order expelling him, and an Israeli judge gave the Government three days to prove its case. Page A3. Aircraft Retirement Age A jet's accident over Hawaii has drawn attention to the issue of how to prevent the aging of aircraft from leading to crashes.

LEAD: New York City officials and the police officers' union nnounced yesterday a tentative agreement on a contract that would provide a 6 percent pay increase in each of the next three years, for a total cost of $394.5 million to the city.

LEAD: Jane Whitney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo C. Balzereit of Jupiter Island, Fla., and Jenkintown, Pa., and Lindsey Gruson, the son of Flora Lewis Gruson of Paris and Sydney Gruson of New York, were married yesterday at the Horticulture Center in Philadelphia. Representative Bob Edgar, a Democrat from Pennsylvania who is a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Michael Garin, the Harvard philosophy graduate who co-founded a television syndication company a decade ago, has resigned from the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation, where he had been a member of the office of the president and a director.

LEAD: Patrick Hogan, an artist who achieved renown as a painter in Los Angeles despite a handicap that allowed him only the use of his mouth to hold a paintbrush, died of respiratory failure on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old, and had moved to New York two years ago to pursue his painting career.
LEAD: Heublein Inc. has agreed to pay $300,000 to settle Federal charges of unfair trade practices, an official of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said.
LEAD: John J. McNamara, an architect who designed and renovated some of the best-known theaters in New York City, died April 26 in Raleigh, N.C., his home in recent years. He was 90 years old.

LEAD: From the moment it arrived on Aug. 1, 1981, the cable-television music network MTV was everything the rest of television was not. It was fast, it was loud, it was scary to parents and, mostly, it was hip. Even the time it went on the air - one minute past midnight - was a kind of anti-television statement.

LEAD: During five days of screening last week, nearly 700 public television professionals viewed an international smorgasbord of some 80 programs representing 60 broadcasting companies from 30 countries. It was the llth annual International Public Television Screening Conference, which is held in the United States every four years.
LEAD: Conditions in the fixed-income markets are putting further pressure on the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates, market participants said.

LEAD: At Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., Valerie Tina Rosenson, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, was married yesterday to Russell Dana Robbins, a fourth-year medical student at New York University. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson and two cousins of the bridegroom, Rabbi Donald Gluckman and Cantor Ellen

LEAD: QUESTION: In the National Hockey League semifinals, if Detroit eliminates Edmonton and Boston eliminates the Devils, then the Red Wings and Bruins, two of the six pre-expansion teams in the N.H.L., would meet for the Stanley Cup. When was the last time the final round did not include an expansion team?

LEAD: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly described the status of the proposed acquisition of Farmers Group of Los Angeles by B.A.T. Industries of London. The Arizona Insurance Department has not acted on the issue yet.
LEAD: Silver International, founded Jan. 1 by six North American silver mining companies to promote silver products to consumers, has chosen an agency: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss.

LEAD: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita of Japan today urged an expansion of trade between the European Community and Japan. ''The importance of increased economic cooperation between Japan and Europe cannot be underestimated,'' the Prime Minister told reporters after meeting with West German officials as part of an 11-day European tour.
LEAD: IT may seem a cruel imposition in view of last year's anguish, but millions of Americans will have to fill out new W-4 wage withholding forms this year.

LEAD: Lawyers for the Union Carbide Corporation have asked District Court Judge M. W. Deo to remove himself from hearing India's $3 billion suit against the company. The suit charges negligence in the 1984 Bhopal gas leak disaster.
LEAD: Given the troubles of airlines across Latin America, Helio Smidt seems remarkably confident that Varig will emerge unscathed from the inflation, recession and labor unrest buffeting the region.

LEAD: It was the Stanley Cup playoff game that almost wasn't. When it finally began, just over an hour late, it featured impromptu and ill-dressed substitute officials, over-anxious players, and a sheet of overheated ice.

LEAD: Musical expression is related to personality and character, but not in a direct correspondence. Moving embodiment of the highest moral aspirations can spring from the pens of people whose lives are depressing studies in expediency, and witty people can write music that is earnest and bland.

LEAD: A Federal nuclear licensing board has told Governor Cuomo and the Suffolk County Executive that they must either prepare their own emergency evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant or say how they would cooperate with the Long Island Lighting Company in any crisis.

LEAD: It shouldn't surprise anyone that the United States ski team's major emphasis for the next year will be on physical fitness. Last season, no fewer than 15 of the women and 5 of the men on the team suffered injuries that kept them out of competition.
LEAD: A 26-day-old boy was found dead in his family's Bronx apartment Saturday night and his mother was charged with second-degree murder yesterday, the police said.

LEAD: Youngsters 3 and 4 years old preparing for the start of a mini-marathon race yesterday in Central Park. The race, which was sponsored by L'Eggs, covered a quarter-mile and was part of festivities celebrating Mother's Day. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: Dr. Ruth Myra Lebovitz, an assistant professor of psychology at La Guardia Community College of the City University of New York, was married yesterday to Robert L. Markovits, a lawyer in Middletown, N.Y. Rabbi Frederic Margulies officiated at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York.

LEAD: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it had again extended its $1.16 billion offer for shares of the Irving Bank Corporation. The offer is now scheduled to expire Friday at 5 P.M., Eastern daylight time.

LEAD: The headline told the whole story: ''Say Williamsburg Bridge Is Unsafe.''

LEAD: A former University of North Dakota assistant men's basketball coach was acquitted of a charge that he tried to scalp tickets for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Final Four tournament, authorities said.
LEAD: With many leading New York City Democrats favoring the present system of mayoral primary runoffs, a politically significant bill to repeal it appeared to be in serious trouble over the weekend.

LEAD: Answering a request from the owners of the Four Seasons, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission may grant landmark status to that cool and hushed modernist restaurant on East 52d Street.
LEAD: Oil production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries rose to 18.2 million barrels a day in April from 17.7 million barrels in March, the International Energy Agency said Friday.

LEAD: It was Hit Parade night at the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival on Saturday when Peter Martins presented the premiere of ''Black and White'' and William Forsythe, the American director of the Frankfurt Ballet in West Germany, offered his own premiere, ''Behind the China Dogs.'' Set to pop-influenced commissioned scores, both are New

LEAD: More than two months after a police officer was slain in Queens, detectives report no breakthroughs in the hunt for evidence that would permit charges against someone for having ordered the murder.
LEAD: It looks like a wristwatch, but it doesn't fell time. Trip the yellow lever on the wristband, and out pops an inflated pillow designed to help keep a person afloat.

LEAD: Gary Koch, who lost his exempt status on the PGA Tour last year because he was 175th on the 1987 money list, today won the $250,000 first prize in the sixth Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational. This is the second largest winning payoff on the tour behind the $360,000 at the Nabisco Championship.

LEAD: TRACK AND FIELD Two American Records Broken: Tom McCants and Jerome Carter set an American high jump record and Ramona Pagel set an American mark in the shot-put at the sixth annual Jesse Owens Classic in Columbus, Ohio. McCants and Carter, who train together, each cleared the bar at 7 feet 9 1/4 inches.

LEAD: There is a sense of inevitability about the Oakland Athletics. Not the type that takes success for granted and turns winning teams into October disappointments. It is a day-by-day inevitability, the sense that sooner or later, an opponent will commit a mistake and soon that mistake will become costly.

LEAD: The first Hans Christian Andersen Ballet Performance Awards were presented during an international performance at the Danish Royal Theater on Saturday, with the top awards going to Sylvie Guillem of the Paris Opera Ballet and Irek Mukhamedov of the Bolshoi Ballet.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The Fed is under increasing pressure to raise interest rates, the latest squeeze coming from the release of April employment data. Some analysts took heart from the fact that payroll employment increased by only 174,000 jobs, but others were concerned about inflation because unemployment had fallen to its lowest level in 14 years and the total number of hours worked had risen sharply.

LEAD: Russell P. Gilsdorf is rejoining a former associate, Dick Tarlow, as executive vice president, director of marketing services and the media, at the new Tarlow Advertising.

LEAD: There were dozens of typewriters and three computers in the campaign office when Michael S. Dukakis ran for governor of Massachussetts in 1982. His 1988 Presidential campaign headquarters has dozens of computers and three typewriters.

LEAD: On the first hit, Tim Teufel just couldn't get the ball out of his glove. On the second, a sprinting Darryl Strawberry couldn't quite grab the ball. On the third, everyone stood and watched as a bunted ball refused to come up off the infield grass.

LEAD: SOME of the nation's largest consumer-products companies have begun to pursue one of the youngest markets: ''latchkey children,'' the perhaps seven million boys and girls between the ages of 5 and 13 who are routinely left unsupervised before or after school.

LEAD: Concern about poor earnings and growing financial difficulties led some outside board members to force Leo M. Walsh Jr. to resign last week as chief operating officer of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, financial industry officials familiar with the situation said.

LEAD: * Bishop Inc., which is engaged in the marketing and distribution of engineering and design products, appointed Kenneth J. Kay executive vice president and chief operating officer and Dennis K. Tsuyuki controller and principal accounting officer.
LEAD: For the Record From Wall Street to Washington By Donald T. Regan 397 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $21.95.
LEAD: Hedda Nussbaum is willing to end her silence and testify against Joel B. Steinberg in the death of Lisa, the 6-year-old child they had raised, the woman's lawyer says.
LEAD: The wife of the painter and collagist Romare Bearden plans to set up a foundation named for her husband that will aid art students and art institutions.
LEAD: Biting for the Camera

LEAD: If it weren't for the stock market collapse last fall, Robert N. Gordon might still be struggling to earn his first $10 million before he turns 40. But Mr. Gordon has handsomely profited from the turmoil on Wall Street as investors have sought a money manager who can earn a double-digit rate of return without the heartburn caused by the dramatic fluctuations in the market.

LEAD: THE phone rang late on a Friday afternoon at Golf House, the headquarters of the United States Golf Association in Far Hills, N.J. It was a rules question from a tournament in Georgia, but all the rules experts had gone home. The call was put through to Frank Hannigan, the U.S.G.A.'s senior executive director.

LEAD: ''At one point, I kept a color-coded calendar on my desk (numerals highlighted in green ink for 'good' days, red for 'bad' days, yellow for 'iffy' days) as an aid to remembering when it was propitious to move the President of the United States from one place to another, or schedule him to speak in public, or commence negotiations with a foreign power.
LEAD: An article on Wednesday about an operation in South Africa to separate twin girls joined at the head translated the name of one girl incorrectly.
LEAD: Anthony Luiso, who spent 15 years as an executive at Beatrice Foods, has been named president and chief operating officer of the International Multifoods Corporation, effective July 1.
LEAD: A surge in rail ridership across the metropolitan region has created a new obstacle for a growing number of commuters: no place to leave their cars at the station.
LEAD: One of the more persistent beliefs in sport is that the thoroughbred, while indisputably the fastest of horses, is also the fastest possible horse.

LEAD: ''It looks like it's going to be the Woody and Wayne Show again,'' was D. Wayne Lukas's prediction last month about the Kentucky Derby. It turns out he called it just right, and that the show is far from over.
LEAD: Dorothy Denny Scardino has been playing the piano for 18 years. In a bank.

LEAD: The young man in a hurry would have to be brief in his postmatch interview. There was a plane to catch to Rome, site of the Italian Open, where word of Andre Agassi's latest exploits will doubtlessly precede him. By the time he plays his first-round match there, he will have moved up a place or two in the ranking and probably stolen the headlines from the established order.

LEAD: The buyer of Jasper Johns's fiercely compelling ''Diver,'' from 1962, which brought $4.2 million last Tuesday at Christie's, was Jeffrey Deitsch, a Citibank vice president, who represented an unidentified buyer. The price was an auction record for a work by any living artist.

That space is occupied, for the first time in more than two decades, by the playful elephant that has followed the franchise from Philadelphia to Kansas City, and finally, 20 years after the team's arrival on the West Coast, to the East

LEAD: Kenny Anderson of the New York Gauchos, left, being elbowed by Gennady Uspensky of the Soviet national junior team during basketball game Saturday night in the South Bronx. The Gauchos won the first meeting between the teams. Page B3. (NYT/G. Paul Burnett)

LEAD: Pity Peter Schickele! There is an authentic compositional talent there, but we will never know just what its true merit is, because nobody living today can listen to this music with wholly uncluttered judgment. For 23 years Mr. Schickele has been ''finding'' music by P.D.Q. Bach (he can't stop, and behavioral therapists can't cure him).
LEAD: WHEN his alarm clock buzzed at 3:30 yesterday morning, D. Wayne Lukas's first thought upon waking was not that one of his horses, the filly Winning Colors, had finally won the Kentucky Derby.

LEAD: If the Yankees wore the mask of a beaten and weary team this weekend, it was not because of events that transpired off the field. Don Mattingly, their first baseman, said they simply failed to capitalize on opportunities, that the eight runs they totaled today should have been enough to stop any team.
LEAD: The Russians took revenge on the Americans Saturday night in a crowded gymnasium in the heart of the South Bronx.

LEAD: The Examer Bay to Breakers road race in San Francisco May 15 is a populist's fitness fantasy. Now in its 77th running, the 7.5-mile race throught he streets of San Francisco attracts 100,000 entrants and has been designated the largest footrace in the world by the Guinness Book of World Records.

LEAD: The Detroit Piston defense smothered the high-scoring Jeff Malone and led Detroit to a 99-78 victory over the Washington Bullets today in the fifth and deciding game of their first-round playoff series.

LEAD: Casio Computer Ltd., which was expected to become the first company to sell digital audio tape recorders in the United States, has put its plans on hold, indicating that the American introduction of the controversial product will be delayed yet again.

LEAD: A number of significant discrepancies surfaced today between Billy Martin's public version of an incident at a local nightspot early Saturday morning and the report Martin filed with the police. However, the Arlington police said they were convinced the Yankee manager was blameless in the incident.
LEAD: Barefoot and surrounded by Teddy bears, Alison Fraser sat in her dressing room at the Helen Hayes Theater, effervescent over the success of her first Broadway starring role.

LEAD: Edith Wharton endured a lonely childhood, an unhappy marriage and occasional shortsightedness on the part of critics. But nothing she suffered in her lifetime is comparable to the misfortune inflicted on her by Donald T. Sanders at the Public Theater.
LEAD: The first part of the Treasury's quarterly refunding will begin tomorrow, just a part of the heavy schedule of Treasury financings set for this week.
LEAD: Mike Felder drove in two runs as the Milwaukee Brewers scored four times in the 10th inning today, beating the Kansas City Royals, 6-2, for their ninth straight victory.

LEAD: Is it mere happenstance that an exhibition about major new architecture in Paris has made a stop in its world tour to touch down in one of New York's greatest Beaux-Arts structures, the old United States Custom House in lower Manhattan?
LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds dropped in April for the first time in eight months, falling 6.4 percent, to $661 million.
LEAD: After a long and heated debate, West Germany is planning to alter shopping hours in an attempt to raise consumer demand and bolster economic growth.

LEAD: In a country where supermarkets sell orchids in bunches and no public occasion is complete without cascades of blooms, Thais were bound sooner or later to turn their love of flowers into something exportable.
LEAD: A strong international field continued play yesterday in the annual Invitational Charity Pairs at the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.

LEAD: For all of the praise, it has been a source of irritation for Michael Jordan that the Bulls have never survived the first round of National Basketball Association playoffs. LEAD: Even for many people who are not jazz aficionados, names like Louis Armstrong and Bix Beiderbecke are familiar. But Sidney Bechet, who is usually ranked with Armstrong and Beiderbecke as an innovator and soloist in the early years of jazz, has, for a number of reasons, been much less well-known.
LEAD: The clash between the White House and Congress over broad trade legislation has failed to derail a free-trade agreement with Canada.

LEAD: Young & Rubicam, which is rarely satisfied with just one bite, has gotten another mouthful of the Revlon business. LEAD: Arnell/Bickford, an agency that is extremely conscious of style, has been named the agency for Christian Lacroix, the French designer noted for his romantic and fanciful clothing.
LEAD: Doug Drabek pitched eight hitless innings today before a pinch-hitter, Randy Ready, led off the ninth with an infield single as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the San Diego Padres, 6-2.

LEAD: * Argentina's cost-of-living index rose 17.2 percent in April after a gain of 14.7 percent in March, the national statistics institute said. The index showed a rise in the year to April of 247.8 percent, compared with 206.9 percent in the year to March. Inflation in the first four months of the year was 62 percent.

LEAD: Michael J. Shaara Jr., whose book on the Civil War, ''The Killer Angels,'' won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction in 1975, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 58 years old.

LEAD: It was a short honeymoon. Two weeks ago Thursday, Dall W. Forsythe, head of the Governor's Office of Management and Productivity, received a call from Governor Cuomo asking him to be his next state budget director. He said yes. On Monday, the departing director, R. Wayne Diesel, called to tell him that the state was looking at a $300 million shortfall in income tax receipts.

LEAD: Hearing more than 40 American composers being danced to by the New York City Ballet these last two weeks has been a provoking, sometimes puzzling, experience for a music critic. With a generosity and optimism so agreeably American, the company has been celebrating its own in grandly hectic style - mounting ballet after ballet, night after night, all to music from this country.

LEAD: An article on Tuesday about unhappiness among Bolivian priests about the number of foreign bishops misstated the background of the Aymara Indians. They were conquered by the Incas in the 15th century.

Daub bounced from table to table, greeting the mostly Republican members of the Norfolk Rotary Club in the mostly Republican northeastern part of this predominantly Republican state. LEAD: Vietnam veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder were less sensitive to pain after seeing scenes from a war movie, according to a new study that gives a glimpse into the complex biology of the disorder. The finding may also be a step toward new treatments, scientists said.

LEAD: A weekend fire at an Illinois Bell switching station kept telephones idle for 35,000 customers in Chicago's western suburbs today and caused delays at major airports.Crews at the Federal Aviation Administration's control center in Aurora were using a backup phone system, but the lack of full service meant controllers had to stagger the arrival of flights by 20 miles.

LEAD: John H. Calhoun, a civil rights leader in the South whose activism dated to the 1940's, died of respiratory failure in his sleep Friday at his home in Atlanta. He was 88 years old. LEAD: To the Editor: The legitimacy of a government depends to a large extent on its ability to appear fair and evenhanded. A nation will accept a great deal of suffering if its citizens perceive that this suffering is both necessary and evenly distributed. When, however, an administration violates this rule of legitimacy, when it becomes the captive of a small, privileged interest group, its days are surely numbered.

LEAD: Q. Why is it that spiders don't get caught in their own webs? A. Nobody knows, because nobody has investigated it thoroughly, according to Dr. Herbert Levi, professor of zoology at Harvard University. ''I don't know of anybody who has worked on this,'' agreed Dr. William Mitchell Masters, assistant professor of zoology at Ohio State University, who has studied how fast spiders can run across their webs and how well they detect vibrations through the web.

LEAD: Gerard Schwarz and the New York Chamber Symphony began Sunday afternoon's concert at the 92d Street Y by doing a service for a work most of us have underestimated, Aaron Copland's ''Dance Panels'' of 1959 (revised 1962). One thing about Mr. Copland's music: you can always recognize it. The man has a true style and a true voice, and this ''abstract'' ballet score - produced at a time when interest in the composer was distinctly waning and largely neglected -speaks authentically.

LEAD: By any objective standard, the treaty on medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles is one that should have made its way easily from the negotiating table to ratification. And in the grand scheme of superpower relations, arms control experts on both sides regard its primary significance as political rather than military.

LEAD: The Winter Garden is a vast new indoor public space that is part of the still uncompleted World Financial Center at Battery Park City. Since March, the center's arts and events program has been sponsoring a series of free lunchtime and early evening performance events of various sorts there. Yesterday at noon the composer, painter and performance artist Connie Beckley presented a piece that will be repeated this evening at 6 o'clock.

LEAD: Bernhard Goetz again. The very thought is likely to induce groaning. For more than two years, the Goetz case preoccupied the public. LEAD: Disappointed by team owners' diffident response to rowdiness at ballparks, the New York Legislature is moving sensibly to curb stadium drinking. LEAD: Like his father and his older brother, Mike Shula has announced his retirement as a professional football player at a young age in order to get started as a coach in the National Football League. The 22-year-old reserve quarterback for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers said Monday he would make the switch to assistant coach, as an offensive aide to Ray Perkins, the Buccaneers' coach, who was also Shula's boss when he was a quarterback at Alabama.

LEAD: Clifford Geertz, the anthropologist, tells the story of visiting a family in a Javanese town in Indonesia recently when his hosts, remembering that a young American had attended the wedding of their daughter three decades before, showed him a photograph of that event.

LEAD: ''Blue Skies'' was a show-stopper when Belle Baker first sang it in the musical ''Betsy'' in 1926. Al Jolson kept it going in ''The Jazz Singer.'' In 1941, a Tommy Dorsey recording made it No. 1 on the Hit Parade. Fritz Kreisler, the concert violinist, recorded it. The comedienne Beatrice Lillie did, too.
LEAD: A report yesterday in the Campaign Trail column misidentified the Governor of Delaware, elected in 1984. He is Michael N. Castle, a Republican.

LEAD: The strains of attempting limited reform in Communist countries these days provoke reflections on old political and even deeper human issues. Change is necessary and inevitable, but it always brings pain. Violent revolutions make subsequent change even harder, not only because they concentrate power beyond civil challenge, but also because they instill such an attachment to order, stability and predictability, and such a fear of risk.

LEAD: The Agriculture Department said today that 1988 winter wheat production is estimated at 1.62 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year's harvest of 1.56 billion bushels. LEAD: MICHAEL WEINSTEIN is showing off the rooftop cafe of one of his restaurants in New York, pointing to the crumbling wall of the adjoining building and gleefully recounting a story. It seems that the neighbor, pleased by the gentrification signified by Mr. Weinstein's restaurant, offered to fix up his property so it would fit in better with its glossy new neighbor.

LEAD: KATE COLBORN of Brooklyn is waiting for the traffic light to change at the corner of Third and Atlantic Avenues. Alongside her is a small, frail elderly woman. The woman is clutching a cane and, it is apparent, is quite concerned about crossing against the aggressively turning traffic. Ms. Colborn smiles in understanding, takes the woman's arm and escorts her - slowly, gently - across the intersection.

LEAD: Lenny Bruce can be seen on public television this evening, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock. That simple fact is bursting with social and cultural reverberations. LEAD: MARKETS Five large Wall Street firms suspended program trading for their own accounts, in a move intended to restore investor confidence in the stock market. The firms involved are Morgan Stanley; Salomon; Bear, Stearns; Paine Webber, and Kidder, Peabody. Index-arbitrage trading has come under intense criticism as a leading cause of volatility in stock prices.

LEAD: Zola Budd burst into international prominence in 1982 more as a curiosity than a prominent runner. Here was this wisp of a teen-ager, barely 5 feet 4 inches and 95 pounds, who ran barefoot.

LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said it would form an equal joint venture with BOC Group P.L.C. of Britain to separate oxygen and nitrogen from air and supply the gases to industrial users around the world. LEAD: THE versatile leek is one of the oldest known cultivated vegetables. But it was no movie.

LEAD: For some years now, Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, has been inveighing against what he perceives as the cable television industry's perpetration of rampant evil, the common denominator of which he calls ''monopoly.'' He was doing his own version of ''Hooray for Hollywood'' again Wednesday in a hearing on the video marketplace before the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance.

LEAD: Finance and economic ministers from the European Community will meet Friday and Saturday to discuss an idea that some key observers say may be an impossible dream: creation of a single European Community currency.

LEAD: A MILLION strolling gourmands on Ninth Avenue and several parks full of celebrators can mean only one thing: New York's festival season has begun. The appearance of the Ninth Avenue International Food Festival, You Gotta Have Park Festivals in Central and Prospect Parks and a host of smaller outdoor festivities this weekend are as telltale signs of spring as the crack of a bat at Yankee Stadium or the year's first warm breeze over a newly green lawn.

LEAD: Terry Bannister and Roy Warman, both from England, have been elected to the board of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company and have been named joint directors of operations for the Communications Group. That group is made up of the giant company's advertising agencies, public relations firms and marketing services firms.

LEAD: The defense ended its closing arguments today in the cocaine smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas, ridiculing prosecutors for trying to make the Colombian appear responsible for the drug problem in the United States.

LEAD: Guatemala's civilian Government weathered a coup attempt this week but remains seriously threatened by disgruntled army officers allied to far-right groups, Guatemalan politicians and diplomats here say.

LEAD: The owner of the sightseeing helicopter that crashed into the East River on May 1 filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking at least $24.5 million in damages from two corporations involved in the manufacture of the aircraft's engine.

LEAD: During seven months of contract negotiations, New York City's Board of Education has tried to break the stranglehold of the school custodians. The board president, Robert Wagner Jr., has now issued a bold ultimatum: Unless ''significant progress'' is made toward a new contract by next week, the board will hire private contractors to clean the schools.

LEAD: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Tracy Jones, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Leo Garcia, outfielder, from Nashville of the American Association. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Agreed to terms with Bill Buckner, first baseman-designated hitter. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Sent Mike Maddux, pitcher, to Maine of the International League for injury rehabilitation.

LEAD: Two Chinese men, seeking to defect, hijacked a domestic airliner from the mainland to Taiwan on Thursday. They were granted asylum, and the jet took the other 116 people aboard back to China early today.

LEAD: On Wednesday afternoon, Rick Aguilera sat at the table in the clubhouse playing cards with his teammates. He won a couple of hands with good cards, several more with shrewd bluffs. Aguilera's mind is a tough one to read, perhaps never more so than when the only thing he has in his hand is a baseball.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY A new method of regulating long-distance telephone rates was proposed by the F.C.C. The plan could save callers $1.6 billion in the next four years, the agency said. The new system would allow A.T.&T. and local phone companies to set their own rates for long-distance calls and access charges as long as they do not exceed new price ceilings.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 426 money market mutual funds decreased $3.2 billion, to $270.56 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 117 institutional funds decreased $3.65 billion, to $72.43 billion. Assets of the 212 general-purpose funds were up $217.1 million, to $89.94 billion.

LEAD: In planning how to manage the nation's economy if he becomes President, Michael S. LEAD: William Wegman has forged a major career by striking consistently minor, even off-key notes in a number of media. In a body of work that has so far included video, photography and drawing, Mr. Wegman has repeatedly thwarted our expectations of artistic mastery, ambition and unity. He has drawn badly, produced videotapes that make the average home movie look like Oscar material and taken as his main photographic subject a Weimaraner in an array of strange costumes and situations.

LEAD: The Travelers Corporation announced yesterday that it would offer its Canadian subsidiaries for sale. LEAD: To American ears, the sound of Bulgarian music can be bracing - or shocking. LEAD: Golf Crenshaw Takes Lead: Ben Crenshaw shot a five-under par 65 yesterday to take the second-round lead at the $750,000 Byron Nelson Classic in Irving, Tex. Crenshaw had a six-birdie, one-bogey round for a 36-hole total of nine-under-par 131. He had a two-shot lead over Jeff Sluman and Mark Wiebe and was three shots up on Craig Stadler and John Cook, who had the day's best round with a 64.

LEAD: THESE are not the best times for developing suburbs. Conceived as havens from the ailments of crowded central business districts, the suburban office centers, from riverside to corporate countryside, are going through a period of adjustment in which they are becoming more like urban centers.

LEAD: AT A CERTAIN level of speculation about the body and its diseases, medical science begins to sound like myth. Flesh talks, blood listens. The body wants things, genes know things, immune systems see things, diseases have secrets that go back to once upon a time in the primeval forest.

LEAD: At the age of 33, Steve Largent of the Seattle Seahawks is getting a bit long in the tooth for a National Football League receiver. LEAD: Francois Mitterrand's strategy has never changed, says Claude de Kemoularia, a French banker, former ambassador and astute political observer. He analyzes the plan in four stages: first, to create an electable alternative to the old Gaullist majority; then to smash the Communist Party; then reform a Socialist base into a non-Marxist social-democratic party; and finally, to smash the right, leaving a solid foundation for France to be governed from left-center.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recently read about the introduction of Smarte Cartes at Kennedy International Airport. While I sympathize with the porters who are losing tips, I am delighted that their monopoly has been broken. It is, after all, the needs of the traveling public that should come first.

LEAD: AT the height of the Spring Comdex computer show in Atlanta last week, officials of AST Research Inc. discovered, to their horror, that they had forgotten to lock up their memory boards. Sometime during a cocktail reception in the AST showroom Tuesday night, someone walked up to a display of the memory cards and slipped out eight slender banks of memory chips, each about the size of a cigarette.

But there are also buildings significant in the history of the skyscraper that one never sees on a walking tour or a Circle

LEAD: Plans are under way to begin the county's first municipally run, all-day child-care facility for working parents. With the aid of $10,000 appropriated by the Trustees of the village of Mamaroneck, the day-care center will open in January 1989.

It is available from Winnipesaukee Flagship, Post Office Box 367, Weirs Beach, N.H.

LEAD: IN contrast to the paltry role of the Federal Government and New York State in housing, New York City has an ambitious long-term housing production program. It relies on a modest amount of state support, assumes no Federal contribution and depends upon huge amounts of spending from the city's capital budget.

LEAD: ''DO YOU have varicose veins in your legs?'' a fellow middle-aged spa member asks as she enters the whirlpool. I am submerged up to my neck in hot, swirling delight. Flustered and annoyed, I mutter: ''Well . . . I do have a few little spidery veins around the knees.''

LEAD: THE IMPERFECT ART: Reflections on Jazz and Modern Culture. By Ted Gioia. (Oxford University, $16.95.) This is an unusual jazz book for two reasons: it deals with the music not just on its own terms but in a broader cultural and esthetic context, and it was written by a musician. Ted Gioia, a young pianist who teaches jazz history and performance at Stanford University, has chosen a formidable theme for his first book: ''how peculiar jazz is in comparison with other arts'' and what makes it that way.

LEAD: The westbound tube of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel was closed for more than six hours yesterday after a dump truck ripped down about 200 feet of ceiling tiles, the authorities said.

LEAD: IF the 10-year capital spending plan proposed by Mayor Koch last week meets all its goals, New York City should be able to build garbage disposal plants, highways and bridges more quickly and cheaply than before. The key to this minor fiscal miracle would be the creation of three independent authorities, one to supervise the construction and financing of each kind of project.

LEAD: FOR many years the Russian Bear has been a cause of concern to the United States. In the past decade there have been problems with Swedish bears. First Bjorn Borg, whose first name means ''bear,'' arrived to plague our tennis courts and now Bjorn Fallenius is doing well at our card tables. A week ago he and his partner, Magnus Lindquist, became the first players from another continent to win the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs in the 14-year history of the event.

LEAD: By divorcing addiction from the circumstances in which it occurs, James McKearney's research does a disservice to addicts and to those who try to help them. There are understandable reasons why people may turn to drugs when they feel unable to cope with economic hardship, stress, psychological or physical abuse or discrimination.

LEAD: The people of Williamsburg never did want that bridge. The operator of the ferry between Manhattan and Brooklyn said it would kill his business, and genteel residents on the Brooklyn side said they would be overrun by immigrants from the Lower East Side. For a time, it seemed they were right, but now the ferry is running again, the neighborhood is rebounding and it is the bridge that is ailing.

LEAD: Asian arts and crafts made over five centuries for export to the West -porcelains, silver, ivory, lacquer, furniture and paintings - are now increasingly appreciated for their historical and esthetic value. Just why these art works and objects are of enduring interest can be seen in the impressive displays that went on view yesterday in the new Asian Export Art Wing of the Peabody Museum of Salem here.

LEAD: To the Editor: While snorkeling off the Beach Club in Grand Case, St. Martin, recently I spotted what looked like a piece of play money on the ocean floor. Removing my mask, I dove down and retrieved it. Sure enough, it was a real $10 greenback. Dried out, it looks as good as new - if a little pale - and I expect to keep it as a treasured liquid asset.

LEAD: Continuing its American Music Festival at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet celebrated Irving Berlin's 100th birthday Tuesday night with a cinematic tribute to this great songwriter. It was a day for celebrations, for Tuesday also happened to be Martha Graham's 94th birthday.

LEAD: Warning that the elephant population in Africa is declining at an alarming rate, the African Wildlife Foundation has called on Americans to help save the great mammals by refusing to buy ivory or ivory products.

There could be up to a billion potential customers for a malaria vaccine alone in the years following its introduction. The problem, said Mr. Ratafia, the market researcher, is ''third world countries just can't afford to pay much for vaccines.

LEAD: REAL men like me don't brake for garage sales. We don't hop to flea markets. Real men pick trash, and we're proud to admit it. Spring is our season. We feed off everyone else's ritualistic desire to shed the household clutter that accumulates all winter.

LEAD: In his article ''Patterns of Addiction'' (Body and Mind, April 10), William Ira Bennett says that ''Even addiction to street drugs may be at least partially explained as a craving for a certain schedule of sensations, as much as for the drug itself.''

LEAD: WHEN the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in the late 1950's, he did not mean to imply that there would be anything second rate about mechanical minds. However, three decades later computers still do not think. Is this because of the technological failings of the computer industry?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN Lackawaxen, Pa., an unprepossessing little town on the banks of the Upper Delaware River, stand monuments to two very different kinds of genius. Downstream from the pebbly point where the Lackawaxen River tumbles through a murmuring riffle and is lost into the broad Delaware, there looms a bridge of obvious antiquity and anomalous design, its three midstream stone piers draped with a graceful sweep of cables and spanned by wood framing for high side walls.

LEAD: ''LET'S cut consumption'' has taken on the sound of an idea whose time has come although its practicality has yet to be examined. This catch phrase has jelled into the consensus for remedial action to fix all that's gone wrong with the economy. Prof. Paul Kennedy, in his New York Times response to complaints that his best-selling book, ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' expressed a passivity toward America's decline, replied that we could always cut consumption.
LEAD: FEDERAL officials have taken the first step toward putting the state on a list of areas that have not met clean-air standards, a move that could result in sanctions this year.
LEAD: After a season of hurtling past obstacles that had stymied them before, suddenly all that really mattered to the Devils tonight was the one leap they failed to make.

LEAD: After playing two uncharacteristically polite games with Chicago, the Detroit Pistons, who have become known for their brutish style of play, took off the kid gloves this afternoon and handed the Bulls one of the worst losses in their playoff history.

LEAD: FOR MORE than a century, the gray buildings, shaft houses and crushers of a 71-acre zinc mine stood high on a ridge above this two-square-mile Sussex County hamlet in the Wallkill Valley, tangible evidence of the community's most valuable economic asset and major tax ratable.

LEAD: On a lush tropical estate outside Havana, there's an open-air extravaganza six nights a week at the Tropicana, one of the world's best-known nightclubs. Two thousand people regularly jam the place to dine and dance, to hear mambos, cha-chas and newer Cuban music and to watch more than a hundred dancers in feathers and sequins as they strut through glittering routines.

LEAD: A musical arrangement in pop is like air: It's necessary for survival, and it's usually only noticed when it's bad. The topography of a composition, propped up by varying rhythms, dynamic changes, instrumental combinations or a vicious, prominently displayed bass line is constantly overlooked, rarely questioned and laden with significance.

LEAD: Donna Peabody doesn't mind smelling the sewage treatment plant or the dump, but the fish rendering plant near her home is another matter. So when the plant's owners announced last month they were closing in the fall, she should have been ecstatic.

LEAD: ''CAT'S CRADLE,'' by Leslie Sands, is a psychological mystery thriller now having its New York premiere at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst. This 1983 British drama takes place in Waverton, a small English village in which, 12 years before the time of the play's action, a 6-month-old baby boy was kidnapped.

LEAD: FOOD, INSISTS TOMMY LASORDA, THE well-fed manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, is the only weakness he has not been able to conquer. He recalls taking a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, staring at it, deciding he was stronger than the cigarettes and throwing the pack away, never to smoke again. He quit drinking in a similar manner.

LEAD: THE RISE OF AMERICAN AIR POWER: The Creation of Armageddon. By Michael S. Sherry. (Yale University, $29.95.) It is a sobering idea Michael S. Sherry pursues in this book, which won the 1988 Bancroft Prize in American history. In the 1920's and 30's it was assumed that the prospect of bombing cities was so horrifying it might make war obsolete.

LEAD: It is true, as Noel Perrin says, that Benjamin Disraeli and Mary Anne Wyndham Lewis had a happy marriage. It is true that he became Prime Minister, and that they ''lived devotedly together. . . .''

LEAD: FINISH planting crops such as lettuce, chard, beets, carrots; harvest peas just before cooking for best flavor. Check ornamentals for immature insect pests and control, if found. Prepare soil well before planting young shrubs and perennials. Snap off faded flowers from daffodils and tulips to prevent seed pods.

LEAD: IF something starts out simple, you can bet it will become complicated sooner or later. So it is with point-and-shoot cameras, which were originally designed to make 35-millimeter picture taking as simple as pointing and shooting.

LEAD: LAND, the lack of it, the price of it, the restrictions on it, is the major cause of the soaring cost of new construction in the county, say the brokers who deal in land sales. The most frequently heard aphorism when land is discussed is ''when it's gone, they can't make anymore.'' That sentiment was recently voiced by Anthony Cassetta, head of Cassetta Frank, a Hawthorn-based concern that specializes solely in land sales.

LEAD: Musical tastes ebb and flow, though not nearly so predictably as the tides. There is no telling just when it will again be seriously argued, for instance, that the blander music of Telemann is as relevant to our times as that of the great artificer Bach. The last serious Telemann revival that I recall came in the 1950's, when the arrival of the long-playing record permitted us to hear a representative selection of his immense but on the whole mediocre oeuvre.

LEAD: IT'S not the most wonderful feeling in the world, but it's pretty great. It happens after a morning, afternoon or complete day of what is loosely called free time, or even after several hours stolen at the end of a workday. You've finally done a lot of things that you've been meaning to do for months and put off for various reasons or that you knew you'd hate to do and therefore didn't.

LEAD: Many of the premieres in the New York City Ballet's continuing American Music Festival look grim rather than pretty and are danced without tutus. This virtually tutu-less festival, with its tendency toward gloom, offers an esthetic image of the City Ballet that is significantly different from the one we customarily expect.
LEAD: ALTERNATIVE spaces are proliferating so rapidly in the tri-state area that it may be time to find an alternative to the term alternative.

LEAD: The question implicit in the New Contemporary Masters festival was answered on Thursday when the series formally opened at City Center for its two-week run. Can ''downtown'' dance, with an esthetic that is often anti-establishment, be transplanted successfully to the dance equivalent of a Broadway theater?

LEAD: Reuven Frank's article brought back a flood of memories, as I was an ABC-TV director at that time.

LEAD: The marriage of Dr. Hillary Hart, a daughter of Louise Cadby of Northampton, Mass., and the late Richard C. Hart, to Dr. Anthony Alofsin, the son of the late Frederick Alofsin and the late Eleanor Alofsin, both of Memphis, took place yesterday in Austin, Tex. Judge Jon N. Wisser of State District Court performed the ceremony at the couple's home.

LEAD: DEER ISLE looks on a map, in the words of a local historian, Vernal Hutchinson, ''like a figure eight drawn by a very shaky hand.'' At high water the sea all but meets at Long Cove and Northwest Harbor and divides the island. Countless coves and inlets run along the island's jagged coastline. Scores of smaller out islands, some no more than pink granite outcrops where cormorants spread their wings to dry, whorl about the shore.

LEAD: Six months after a massacre halted presidential elections in Haiti, United States officials and lawmakers say that there has been no progress toward democracy in the impoverished Caribbean country and that Congress will take new steps to force change.

LEAD: Pamela Gail Fried, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart J. Fried of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to David Alan Picon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Picon of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal officiated. The bride, a sales manager at Dynamic Designs, a clothing manufacturer in New York, graduated from Emory University.
LEAD: THE refinancing of a co-op building's mortgage poses some tricky issues for its board - when to do it, how to find a good lender, how much to borrow and for how long.

LEAD: For the first time in the 124-year history of Gallaudet University, a deaf president and a deaf chairman of the board presided over commencement exercises for the graudates at the nation's only college for the hearing impaired.

LEAD: EVEN AT THEIR SIMPLEST, DESSERTS are especially dazzling in summer, thanks to an abundance of fresh fruit. For decoration and seasoning, there is also a generous harvest of delicate blossoms and feathery herbs.

LEAD: EVEN if a settlement between the state and Lilco is announced before the utility's annual shareholders' meeting Tuesday, the Long Island Power Authority will continue its proxy battle for three seats on Lilco's board.

LEAD: WHEN the leader of a democratic society lays his hands on the person he would have as his successor, the gesture can mean everything or nothing. For Vice President Bush, it could end up meaning both.
LEAD: Nassau Plastics Ban?

LEAD: The prime rate went up by half a percentage point, to 9 percent. After weeks of increases in other rates, the move by banks to raise their base lending rate was no surprise. Nevertheless, the financial markets took it as confirmation of a discouraging trend. At 9 percent, the prime is where it was before the stock market crash of October.

LEAD: IN the middle of the 18th century, while traveling and preaching in the ''ungospelized wilds'' of North Carolina, the evangelist George Whitefield made several visits to the busy port town of Bath. As legend has it, Whitefield ended one of his stays with ill feelings toward Bath's residents. He walked out of the town, shook the dust from his feet and laid a curse on

LEAD: THERE are only three things to do with trash: Dump it, burn it or find a new use for it. For years, New York State and New York City have relied on the first two options, paying little more than lip service to the third. But with landfills rapidly filling up, and pollution experts finding disturbing problems with incineration, officials are looking again at recycling.

LEAD: Throughout this summer, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will strive to define the kind of Presidency they would create if given the chance. While voters undoubtedly have their own ideas about the ideal Presidency, I would like to suggest a standard of comparison: the Ford Administration.

LEAD: Closings in the week ending April 30 MANHATTAN Gramercy Park Area $143,000 330 Third Avenue (23d St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, hardwood floors, southern exposure; maintenance $391, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate)
LEAD: Former Gov. Evan Mecham was elected today as a delegate to the Republican National Convention in August.
LEAD: The nation's nursing shortage worsened last year, temporarily closing some emergency rooms and delaying admissions and operations, the American Hospital Association says.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: Adm. Sergei G. Gorshkov, who transformed the Soviet Union into a global sea power during 29 years as chief of the Soviet Navy, died on Friday in Moscow, the official Tass press agency said on Saturday. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: Marguerite Lammot Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis V. Lee of Charlestown, R.I., and Frank Perkins Hixon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hixon of Franklin, Tenn., were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. V. Alastair Votaw.

LEAD: CONCERNED that Long Island adolescents are not receiving proper health care, officials are considering opening health clinics in some schools. But many of the proposals are running into opposition, including from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, because they would offer counseling on contraception.

LEAD: Margaret Mead Green is a scraggly strip of city-owned parkland on Columbus Avenue between 79th and 81st Streets, a sort of side yard to the American Museum of Natural History. Its grass has been rubbed bare by the dozens of dogs and their owners who use it regularly. Tree roots are exposed. The soil is so compacted that when it rains the park becomes a huge mud puddle.

LEAD: FOR ALL THEIR POTENTIAL PLEASURES, outdoor cafes have their distinct perils - especially in such congested urban centers as New York City. They include everything from flies performing kamikaze dives into your gazpacho to exhaust fumes, gawking passers-by, airborne napkins, cold food, street noise, sudden weather shifts and confused canines who mistake table legs for spindly shrubs.

LEAD: My first knowledge of a place called the Cloisters came with a part-time job in a curious picture-book school building far in mood and distance from my South Bronx James Monroe High School. It was my ungrateful duty to soothe excited, recalcitrant children into bed moods; their older teachers were too exhausted for this last task of a long day.
LEAD: GOOD-BYE, MY WISHING STAR By Vicki Grove. 128 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. BORROWED CHILDREN By George Ella Lyon. 154 pp. New York: Orchard Books/ Franklin Watts. $12.95. (Ages 10 to 12)

LEAD: To prevent conflicts of interest, the State Board of Equalization and Assessment is pressing for legislation that would bar real-estate assessors from holding jobs as real-estate brokers or appraisers in their home towns.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An art school apologized in advertisements appearing in Sunday newspapers here for exhibiting a student's portrait of the late Mayor Harold Washington in lingerie.

LEAD: He grew up on a tobacco farm in North Carolina, so it should come as no surprise that Todd Welborn takes a chaw on a plug now and again. But Welborn, a relief pitcher for the Mets' Class AA farm club in Jackson, Miss., insists that tobacco never passes his lips.

LEAD: Last October, Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, and Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, introduced a plan to ease the county's growing homeless problem that they thought communities would quickly accept.

LEAD: House and Senate conferees have reported significant progress on a bill to protect 32 million Medicare beneficiaries from exposure to financial catastrophe because of illness. They say they hope to complete their work in the next two weeks.

LEAD: Pressed by corporate clients, Salomon Brothers and Morgan Stanley & Company finally caved last week. They announced that they, along with three other large firms, would give up program trading for their own accounts. This delighted Wall Streeters, desperate for ways to prove that the demon had been slain and that it's safe for investors to test the market waters again.
LEAD: To The Editor:

LEAD: The alarm blares at 6:30, and the morning hustle begins - the half-hour for exercise, the five-minute shower, the quick strokes of moisturizer, mascara and lipstick. Then, a bowl of cereal and a dash for the door.

LEAD: FOR SOME PEOPLE, ESPECIALLY THE young, the inexperienced and the super-busy, nothing provokes more anxiety than the thought of giving a dinner party. They become exhausted merely contemplating all the chores they would have to do: shopping for decent place mats, removing the books from the living room floor, fixing the broken chair.
LEAD: President Reagan, the residents of Vorovsky Street thank you. They salute you on Voyevodin Lane, too, and on the roads leading to the Danilov Monastery.

LEAD: YOU'VE seen the reports about the increasing numbers of pleasure boats along the Connecticut coast, and what they portend. Plans to build more marinas are viewed with alarm. Mid-channel moorings raise legal questions. Dredging proposals threaten bottom life. But amid the worry about all that, is a little-noticed positive factor: people like me have acted to limit the potential problem.
LEAD: A man who served as his own attorney and confronted victims on the witness stand at his trial has been sentenced to 376 years in prison on 14 counts of rape and burglary.

LEAD: In ''A Town Pays a Price for Indifference'' (April 24, Opinion page), Southbury resident Alvin Laster expressed concern about the impact I.B.M.'s new Southbury facility will have on the ambiance of the town. We want to assure Mr. Laster that the International Business Machines Corporation cares about Southbury, too.

LEAD: EVERY diner likes to have in his repertory a pleasant, inexpensive restaurant as a cozy retreat for an informal meal with the family. Alla Bettola in the Goodwives Shopping Plaza in Darien is such a place.

Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Prime Minister Branko Mikulic today defied calls for his resignation made by Yugoslavia's two most Westernized republics.

But it is one thing for a few Congressmen to talk about taxing a wider range of the profit-making ventures of not-for-profit organizations and quite another when the White

LEAD: ''To each his own. To one it is given to sing of the love of Romeo and Juliet, to another to depict the frenzied screeches and comical capers of monkeys.'' Such is the ironic indictment of Prokofiev by V. Kolomyitsev in 1916, quoted by David Gutman in notes to the CD reissue of the Lorin Maazel recording of Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet.

LEAD: It was Riccardo Zandonai's bad luck to have been a successor in an age that preferred revolutionaries. The publisher of his operas, Ricordi, proudly announced him as Puccini's heir,and so perhaps he was. In a long life that ended in 1949, Zandonai took Puccini-esque declamatory style and prettied it up considerably, but never discarded its character.

LEAD: WORK is progressing here on the city's first major hotel construction in a decade, the Pickett Suite Hotel, a $28 million, 230-suite accommodation just three blocks from the reigning hostelry, the Hotel du Pont.

LEAD: During the four-day summit meeting in Moscow later this month, President Reagan is expected to leave the confines of official government buildings at least three times to mix with Soviet citizens who reflect the country's changing religious and intellectual climate.

LEAD: ENTERTAINING BY THE POOL OR on the patio no longer means plain paper plates and boring plastic cups. The newest stars on the outdoor entertainment circuit are vibrantly colored, innovatively textured and often sturdy enough to be used over and over again.

LEAD: Ann Peters Duffy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Duffy of Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Nicholas Cooke Hanna, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Hanna Jr. of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Charles A. Lennon performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Quiogue, L.I.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Winn Adams of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Nancy Lee Adams to Bruce P. Dexter Jr., a son of Mrs. Dexter of Prairie Village, Kan., and the late Mr. Dexter. The couple plan to marry July 9.
LEAD: MORE crumhorns and sackbuts are showing up at Connecticut concerts these days. And audiences cannot get enough of them.

LEAD: A vegetable garden is tucked into the yard of nearly every home in this Palestinian village, watered by perforated black rubber tubing. Rabbits and chickens are fattening in handmade cages as a defense against expected hard times to come.

LEAD: It is something of a given in a land where history is a sensitive subject and self-scrutiny a national affliction that an attempt to found a museum of German history will be controversial - especially if the initiative comes from the Government.

LEAD: After 24 years as the sole operator of the only radio station in this quaint fishing community, Simon Geller has sold WVCA-FM with considerable glee and eager visions of the apartment he hopes to buy on Manhattan's Upper East Side.
LEAD: TOURISTS visiting Cape Cod this summer may wonder: who are those angry-looking motorists whizzing down Route 6 with piles of dirty socks in their back seats?
LEAD: The National Labor Relations Board has granted striking jai alai players in Hartford and Newport, R.I., the right to conduct union representation elections.
LEAD: * Challenging recipes for grillers.

LEAD: IT is nice that Middle America has given its name to all that's average and respectable when it has been the stomping ground of so many weird artists. One of the earliest and weirdest was Ivan Albright, who could make anything -from flesh to flowers - look as if it was in the last stages of putrefaction.

LEAD: THE questions seemed never to have come up in Paris during the 19th and early 20th centuries, but today seem never to stop coming up in New York and other American cities: Can minority artists make the mainstream and keep their cultural identities? Is it possible or even desirable to cultivate these identities in what amounts to a hothouse atmosphere?

LEAD: The New York Post, which has had several editorial incarnations in its 187-year history, will now be aiming for ''the highest possible journalistic standards and practices.'' So said the newspaper's new owner, Peter S. Kalikow, last week in announcing the appointment of Jane Amsterdam as the Post's new editor.

LEAD: For the crowd that gathers inside Superior Court here each day to watch the trial of Richard B. Crafts, the lure is a crime as intriguing as a Philip Marlowe mystery and as grisly as the movie ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre.''

LEAD: In an unusual move to clear up a backlog of thousands of disputed food-packaging violations by supermarkets, a New York City agency is negotiating a mass financial settlement with a supermarket trade association.

LEAD: TO give a logical description in general terms of the strategy of any opening without getting involved in rank contradiction is impossible because each comprises possibilities for diverse strategies.

LEAD: FEW dissenting voices were heard in recent years as India undertook an ambitious military buildup. Many Indians seemed to agree with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi that questioning the need for more spending was unpatriotic.

LEAD: Exasperated by the seemingly endless deaths, crime and corruption generated by the world's illicit drug trade, a growing number of public officials and scholars in recent weeks have begun to call for debate on what for years was politically unspeakable: making drugs legal.

LEAD: THE city of White Plains is reportedly in the process of drafting historic landmark-preservation legislation, and I want to offer a few personal thoughts on the subject. The rush to place plaques in front of so-called historic sites in Westchester about a century ago left us with some rather strange heritage, including a number of markers to events that did not even occur here.

LEAD: On May 1 you published a letter by Dr. Herbert Ross which challenged much of the material in Penny Singer's article about me [ ''Diabetic Doctor Offers a New Treatment,'' April 3 ] . The purpose of my letter is to clarify some of Dr. Ross's distortions and inaccuracies point by point. 1.

LEAD: The newspapers here are no friends of Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, and so it seemed the norm when an editor compared the Turkish leader's fortunes to those of a fairy-tale magician well past the hour when miracles turn to mush.

LEAD: The Israeli Army reopened the occupied Gaza Strip today after a 29-hour closing imposed to prevent Palestinians from reaching Jerusalem for prayers on the last sabbath of Ramadan, the Moslem holy month.

LEAD: THE REAL PROBLEM with entertaining is that it can't be done without guests. And the real problem with guests is that you never know what they'll get up to. They are, after all, only human - they can't be timed like roast beef, arranged like flowers or turned off like a cassette. Sparkling house, fabulous food, a list of friends that sounds terrific - it can all come to nought if someone drinks too much, begins an argument or monopolizes the conversation.

LEAD: WITH Memorial Day coming soon, it is time to think about foods suitable for summer picnics. Sandwiches and salads are the obvious choices. LEAD: Roger Clemens pitched a three-hitter and struck out 10 today en route to his fourth shutout of the season as the Boston Red Sox beat the Seattle Mariners, 3-0.

LEAD: A reclusive bird that even the most dedicated hikers rarely see, the American woodcock, is in trouble, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service, which estimates that for the last decade and a half its numbers have been declining at the rate of about 2 per cent a year.

LEAD: THE new generation of genetically engineered vaccines, unlike their earlier counterparts, does not contain live or killed disease organisms, which have been linked to side effects. Instead, they make use of only portions of infectious organisms, like surface proteins called antigens, which arouse immunity but seldom cause side effects.

LEAD: WHEN the 80-year-old founder and namesake of Arthur Bryant's Barbecue, a landmark restaurant in Kansas City, Mo., died in December 1982, devoted customers across the nation wondered what would happen to the restaurant they had come to love for its hickory-smoked ribs, beef, ham, mutton and renowned spicy sauce.

LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of St. Stephen the Martyr in Edina, Minn., Marissa Harris Miller, a daughter of William R. Miller of New York and Lawrence, L.I., and the late Nancy McClain Harris Miller of Paris, Ill., was married yesterday to James William Howard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Howard of Gill, Colo.
LEAD: * Foreign investors step up the pace.
LEAD: THE New Britain Red Sox are playing in the same ball park this year. But it isn't the same old ball park.

LEAD: Nancy Lopez got up and down from a bunker alongside the 18th green today to save par and preserve a one-stroke lead over Alice Ritzman going into the final round of the 13th annual Chrysler-Plymouth Classic.

LEAD: THE Democratic administration of Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin is taking shape after four months and is leaving an impact on a government of 12,000 civil servants and a county population of 1.3 million.

LEAD: THE TRADITIONAL NEW ENGLAND-style clambake is a labor-intensive but rewarding ritual that I usually perform once a year on the beach at my home on eastern Long Island. City dwellers, of course, do not have the opportunity to stage this oceanside event. But there is no reason why the essence of a clambake cannot be simulated by assembling the ingredients in a deep pot or steamer and cooking them on a stove top.

LEAD: MANY corporations have tried to become more efficient by imitating Japanese management techniques, but the rules for compensating executives have remained strictly American. In the United States auto industry, top executives were paid 12 to 18 times as much as the average blue-collar worker, according to a University of Michigan study published in 1984.

Tartt Bell of McLean, Va., were married yesterday at the Woodrow Wilson House in Washington. The Rev. Harry Quiett, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Mark Taylor, an assured and accomplished modern-dance choreographer, seemed to strive primarily for neatness in a program of new and recent dances presented by Mark Taylor and Friends on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater. Neat joins and interlocking body parts were the order of the night, part of the ongoing 3-D at the Joyce festival, as well as neat small surprises and neat abstractions.

LEAD: A field of 85 men and 85 women, including many racers who will compete this summer for positions on the 1988 United States Olympic cycling teams, is expected to start today in the Subaru National Criterium Championships in White Plains. The races are the first in a series of seven Subaru-sponsored events over five months.

LEAD: Florida Institute of Technology ended Temple University's five-year reign as the men's varsity heavyweight rowing champion of the Dad Vail Regatta, defeating the Owls today in the eight-oared final to win the Tom Conville Cup.

The Rev. Neely Paul Towe performed the ceremony at the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich.

LEAD: The engagement of Amanda Elissa Hodgson to John Thomas Hompe has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. S. Hodgson of Port Washington, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harold Hompe of Stanley, Wis. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: One of the purposes of a referee in a sports event is to establish and maintain order on the field. Mr. Giamatti is well founded in his refusal to tolerate ''any potentially injurious harassment of any kind of the umpires.'' However, the same sense of order which protects an umpire must restrain him.

She's the kind of woman who giggles and shrieks and chatters too much while this job is being done. When it's finished, she steps back to admire her handiwork and, of course, the expected thing happens.

LEAD: I REMEMBER VIVIDLY the last time I played with my toy soldiers. It was a wet summer afternoon a week or two before the start of eighth grade, and I was 12 years old. Most of that summer had been spent playing baseball, exploring Philadelphia's vast Pennypack Park and pedaling my bicycle wildly through the neighborhood streets playing ''ball tag on bikes.

LEAD: As many as three million people in northern Vietnam may be facing starvation, according to Hanoi's official radio and to reports from international aid organizations, which have been asked for emergency food supplies.

LEAD: ACCORDING TO A RECENT study by a private foundation, the Council on Library Resources, at least 10 million irreplaceable books in America's research libraries are, through the ravages of old age, in danger of disintegration. One man doing something about it is Jan Sobota, a Czech-born bookbinder and restorer.

LEAD: THE first department head to be suspended in the five and a half years of the O'Rourke Administration said last week that problems in the Probation Department had resulted from the county's failure to provide enough financial support, not from a lack of leadership on his part.

LEAD: STORMING THE MAGIC KINGDOM: Wall Street, the Raiders, and the Battle for Disney, by John Taylor. (Ballantine, $9.95.) Almost from the beginning, the Disney entertainment empire was bitterly divided as the disciples of Walt lorded it over the followers of his lesser-known brother, Roy. John Taylor's story of how Roy's son took revenge in the early 1980's, with the help of Ivan Boesky and other financiers, is ''a tale of raw corporate power,'' David McClintick said in The Book Review last year.

LEAD: The Palestinian uprising, now in its sixth month, has not moved the Government of Israel a visible inch toward any greater willingness to withdraw from the West Bank and Gaza. To the contrary, Prime Minister Shamir has become increasingly emphatic in saying that Israel will keep those territories forever.
LEAD: MIKE DILLON remembers the last time he handled asbestos.

LEAD: In the days that passed between games in Chicago and New York - between his last failed pitching appearance and yesterday's shining success - Dave Righetti sat in the Yankee bullpen and wondered. There had been a string of lost chances, a succession of nights without work, and a tender left elbow that had left him unavailable for a time.

LEAD: In the itty-bittiest print imaginable, the ads for ''Light Years'' indicate that Glenn Close, Christopher Plummer, Jennifer Grey and John Shea appear only in ''starring the voices of'' capacities. In other words, this is an animated film, and it wasn't made with these particular actors in mind.

LEAD: JUST as tulips are giving way to irises and the commuter traffic on the Long Island Expressway is swelled by the Friday flight to houses on the East End, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton is presenting ''The Long Island Country House, 1870-1930.''

LEAD: Illusion and Reality We travel not to places, but to illusions, which make every arrival both an anticlimax and a beginning. Here is Mary Morris in Mexico, from ''Nothing to Declare: Memoirs of a Woman Traveling Alone'' (Houghton Mifflin).

LEAD: Soccer Wimbledon Captures Cup: Lawrie Sanchez scored in the 36th minute yesterday as Wimbledon upset Liverpool, 1-0, in the final of the Football Association Cup before a crowd of 98,000 at Wembley Stadium. Sanchez, a member of Northern Ireland's national team, headed a free kick from Dennis Wise and sent it past Bruce Grobbelaar.

LEAD: WHEN a humbled Jacques Chirac submitted his resignation last week to President Francois Mitterrand, France formally ended two novel years of ''cohabitation'' between a Socialist head of state and a Prime Minister chosen by the rightist majority in the National Assembly. In the aftermath of Mr. Mitterrand's stunning re-election to a second seven-year term, the two years of cohabitation are looking less like an odd parenthesis and more like the springboard to an even bolder political experiment.

The statement should have read: ''The Red Cross said the rate of blood donors testing positive for the AIDS antibody is 1 in 20,000,'' not a 1 in 20,000 chance of receiving an AIDS-infected pint of blood.

Dabney of Boston have announced their daughter's engagement to Mr. Abe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold K. Abe of Westport, Conn., and Tokyo.

LEAD: Remember Game 1 of the recent Knicks-Celtics series? It was late in the third quarter at Boston Garden and the Knicks led, 74-71, when Dennis Johnson stepped forward as he has done so often during crunch time in the playoffs.

LEAD: Q. We removed the wallpaper from our bathroom ceiling and walls, then painted with a water-base semigloss. Almost immediately the paint started cracking and peeling. LEAD: A response in the Q & A column on Jan. 24 about retirement in Mexico gave an incorrect address for the Retire in Mexico Corporation. The correct address is Avenida Americas 1297-101, Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico.

The confidante of Nancy Reagan is not listed in the San Francisco phone book.

LEAD: Bet Twice, the forgotten horse of the racing world, boldly reclaimed his stature by outfinishing Lost Code, Cryptoclearance and Alysheba to win the $600,000 Pimlico Special today at Pimlico Race Course.

LEAD: For Betty Sprague, falling in love with her psychiatrist, with what she believes was his encouragement, was no cure for her depression and emotional distress.
LEAD: A chemical distribution company with a long record of pollution violations has been convicted on criminal charges of illegally storing and dumping hazardous wastes at its plant here.
LEAD: The Defense Department has settled a lawsuit brought by two environmental groups by agreeing to curtail research into a high-power electrical phenomenon, electromagnetic pulse.

LEAD: It would be no great exaggeration to say that over the last 10 years, the art of photography has split into two irreconcilable camps. On one side are the post-modernists and their allies, who see photography as a particularly useful and provocative means of making images that address the issues of art in our times.
LEAD: A 10-year-old preacher who said he would rather be rewarded in heaven than get an education on earth was suspended from school Friday after refusing to stop proselytizing and go to class.

LEAD: SINCE MANKIND HAS BEEN cooking food over glowing embers at least since Prometheus, the technique, by all rights, should be at a very high level. But there is one major impediment to achieving this degree of skill - that typically American failing, lack of patience.

LEAD: TODAY my idea of a sophisticated beach is an intimate little stretch of sand or shingle tucked into a cove beneath Mediterranean mountains, but when I was a kid I had different ideas. In those days Revere Beach, just north of Boston, a New England counterpart of Coney Island, was the height of sophistication for me.
