LEAD: For almost 11 years now, Ivan Lendl has been known mostly for his demeanor on a tennis court, brutally efficient and businesslike, lacking real passion, those terms all becoming synonymous with his name. They painted a one-dimensional portrait, but it was all that Lendl was comfortable revealing about himself, the only personality traits the fans and news media were allowed to see.

LEAD: LIKE living marionettes locked in a dark room with unknown hands pulling their strings, the hostages of Beirut may be wondering how the savage fighting in the streets during the last week might affect their fate.

LEAD: MOST fireplace owners know the importance of having chimneys cleaned regularly. Doing so prevents the buildup of sooty deposits inside them, which can cause a fire, and also keeps fireplaces functioning efficiently and with less smoke.

LEAD: ''YOUTH supplies us with colors,'' wrote Samuel Johnson, ''age with canvas.'' Put them together, and you have a portrait in accomplishment. You also have the 17th Joint Concert by the Ridgefield Symphony and the Ridgefield Youth Orchestra today.
LEAD: After perhaps his most frustrating year in baseball and a controversial spring training, Bob Knepper of the Astros, a left-hander, is at peace with himself and has forgotten the past.

LEAD: Jean Pamela McGavin plans to wed Daniel Myers Eldridge in July, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Alfred McGavin of Arlington, Va., have announced. Her fiance is the son of Ronnie Myers Eldridge of New York and the late Dr. Lawrence O. Eldridge. He is the stepson of Jimmy Breslin, the Daily News columnist.
LEAD: ''I ALSO WANT TO FIND the edge,'' said the comedian Will Durst to Stephen Holden of The New York Times. ''I keep pushing at the envelope.''

From Philadelphia . . . It's the National Conventions,'' April 17).
LEAD: REMEMBER radio? Sitting around the console was a time of listening, of paying sustained attention.

LEAD: With Soviet troops poised to begin their withdrawal Sunday, Afghanistan faces a period of turmoil in which the United States is preparing to play an ambiguous military and political role.

LEAD: AFTER the tension stirred up by weeks of campaigning and rumors of a coup, Ecuadoreans were understandably relieved that the Presidential election last Sunday proved to be an anticlimax. There was no violence, no cry of fraud, no rumble of tanks and, above all, no surprise victory for Abdala Bucaram Ortiz, a rabble-rousing populist who had come to personify political instability here.

LEAD: A 70-pound girl whose kite took her on an unscheduled flight in March returned today to her liftoff site. This time, she managed to stay on the ground as she flew the first kite under a new set of safety rules.

LEAD: The Devils' dream season came to an end tonight after 20 playoff games. They fell one victory short of the Stanley Cup finals by losing to the Boston Bruins, 6-2, in the seventh game of their National Hockey League playoff series.
LEAD: There was once a catcher for the San Diego Padres named Gwosdz, called Eyechart by his teammates, though he was known to his family as Douglas.

LEAD: In the late 1800's thousands of passenger boats powered by steam plied America's waterways; today there are only a handful, according to David Crockett, president of the Steamship Historical Society of America. Happily, nostalgic travelers can still sample the flavor of the era in the Northeast. Short excursions are available on vintage boats (some now converted to run on diesel fuel) or recently built steamboats in a few locations; more common are replicas that aim to recapture the spirit of the steam age.
LEAD: TWO artists I knew and respected died recently. One was internationally known, Louise Nevelson, age 88; the other, little known but much appreciated, Charles Balth, 95.

LEAD: No subject is of greater interest to antiques collectors than how to detect fakes and repairs in period furnishings. In FAKE, FRAUD, OR GENUINE? Identifying Authentic American Antique Furniture (New York Graphic Society/ Little, Brown, $29.95), Myrna Kaye, a former consulting curator of furniture at the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities in Boston, describes scores of ways in which American antique chairs, tables, chests and sideboards are not all that dealers and auctioneers claim them to be.

LEAD: Beginning this afternoon, some 3,000 architects will descend on New York for the 120th annual convention of the American Institute of Architects. It is expected to be the largest gathering of the profession ever - not a bad way, perhaps, to make up for the fact that the association has not chosen to meet in New York since 1967, preferring instead to gather in such architecturally significant cities as San Antonio, Kansas City and San Diego.

Lying on the coffee table was a sampling of the 14 books she had written, including ''Use Astrology and Change Your Name'' and ''Nixon's Horoscope.

Despite the early hour and a yawn or two, Ms. Horn's friends were in high spirits and ready for adventure.

LEAD: ''BEAUTIFUL water in a high place'' - the most commonly accepted translation of the Indian name Winnipesaukee -is on target in describing the sprawling New Hampshire lake. With its lovely vistas of mountains and 274 habitable islands, Lake Winnipesaukee has been attracting vacationers for two centuries.
LEAD: A Welter of Weeklies ''IT'S the talk of the industry,'' said a former editor of a Long Island weekly newspaper.

LEAD: Heavily armed teams of law-enforcement officers arrested two suspects in New Jersey late Friday and early yesterday in the robbery of a payroll service in lower Manhattan Friday morning. Another suspect surrendered last night in New Jersey.

LEAD: The engagement of Capt. Annesley Jeanne Williamson and Maj. Jonathan Hunter Jaffin, both of the Army Medical Corps, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Wilmajeanne B. Williamson of Stamford, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: WEN Mary Fisher first proposed the idea to the fashionable ladies gathered at Mrs. Vincenzo Botta's weekly reception in New York City one day in 1888, one guest was appalled. ''A home for old authors and artists?'' she exclaimed. ''My! What a company of cranks! What will you do with them?''

LEAD: Fragments of satisfaction and fragments of disappointment - placed side by side - made up Berenice Lipson-Gruzen's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night, and one's piecemeal response to her playing was actually a metaphor for the playing itself. Its highest moments were the Debussy pieces - the three ''Estampes'' and the isolated Prelude from Book One called ''What the West Wind Saw.

LEAD: DESPITE A RATHER healthy dose of doubt where marriage was concerned, I had always had a fairy-tale image of weddings. Satin shoes at the Drake Hotel, or mossy bliss beneath a waterfall. Of course, I'd always assumed that someone else would take care of the plans. I was mired in the sweet innocence of youth, when weddings seemed to spring forth mysteriously through spontaneous generation.

LEAD: Edison's ''talking machine'' with its tinfoil cylinder uttered its first croaking words in 1877. But the flat phonograph record as it is known today came a little later. It was first heard a hundred years ago, almost to the day.

LEAD: The Environmental Proctection Agency is preparing new rules for field tests of genetically altered microorganisms that are expected to relax restrictions on certain tests. The power to approve tests is expected to be moved from the E.P.A. to regional Environmental Biosafety Committees. How will these changes affect commercial genetic engineering?
LEAD: REPAIRS on the George Washington Bridge and the New Jersey Turnpike's Laderman Bridge over the Passaic River will restrict late-night traffic this week.

LEAD: Almost all Olympic hopefuls have the same opinion about sponsors: It's better to have one than not have one. Take it from Mike McCarthy, a member of the United States national cycling team.

LEAD: WHENEVER there is an unusual run of violence or near-violence in professional sports, it attracts the anguished attention of various moralists and concerned parents. Their worry is that sports is reflecting the worst in our national character - the itch to kill thy neighbor - or providing nasty role models for Little Leaguers.

LEAD: Hockey is the most exciting game in the world but at the same time it is one of the most potentially violent. This is particularly so given the speed at which it's played, the equipment used and the degree of physical contact. More importantly, hockey, unlike other contact sports such as football and basketball, regulates, instead of prohibits, fighting.
LEAD: John C. Bullitt, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under President Kennedy, died of cancer yesterday at his farm in Princeton, N.J. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: My wife and I spent a very enjoyable evening at the Studio Theater viewing the play ''Doubles.'' This play was as good a presentation as any we have seen in suburbia.

LEAD: FOR about a year now, banks and other financial institutions that issue credit cards have been pushing cards with a cause. These so-called affinity cards are issued in conjunction with a nonprofit organization, everything from the League of Women Voters to the National Rifle Association. Under the typical arrangement, the nonprofit group gets a small cut each time the cards are used to charge a purchase.

LEAD: I HAD gone to Sanibel Island, on the Gulf Coast of Florida, to look at its potable-water processing plant. Sanibel and adjacent Captiva share a narrow strip of land divided into two islands by a small river. Together, they are shaped like Long Island and are, in many ways, a microcosm of it.

LEAD: COLORFUL six-inch suspenders called Mini-Grips are spanning the generations in popularity. Mothers wear them to clasp cardigans and anchor scarves, while daughters use theirs to create mock Mary Janes out of plain flats. The suspenders also shorten hems for a scalloped effect on skirts, T-shirts and pants, and can cinch waists like a belt.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Dr. Bennett's comparison of ''the absolute amount of pleasure anyone can get from gulping a cup coffee . . with having an orgasm . . . '' brings to mind the celebrated anecdote about Lady Astor's temperance speech: ''I would rather commit adultery than drink a glass of beer.''
LEAD: MARIO CUOMO LIKES TO play games, and on this day in April the game is baseball, the opening of Pilot Field in Buffalo.

LEAD: THE liability issue ''is a tremendous cloud'' hanging over vaccine developers, said Mr. Rotheim, the analyst. Certainly, companies have good reason to be wary. The average award paid out in the 1970's for injury claims stemming from the swine flu vaccine was more than $100,000. Injury awards for the D

LEAD: With reference to the April 10 Opinion Page article ''A Divided Society Is an Unjust Society,'' I was keenly disappointed that Stan Lipton referred only very peripherally to our large and growing population of Hispanic-American ancestry. We may talk with a bit of an accent, but I would reassure your readers that we are also part of God's human family, and wish to live in peace and brotherhood with all other Americans.

LEAD: The independent prosecutor's report on Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is not likely to make broad conclusions about Mr. Meese's conduct but instead will offer an exhaustive review of the evidence gathered, according to people with knowledge of the yearlong inquiry.

LEAD: Bill Hanzlik scored 4 of his 9 points in the final 35 seconds, including the game-winner with three seconds to play, rallying the Denver Nuggets to a 107-105 victory over the Dallas Mavericks in their National Basketball Association playoff series today.
LEAD: ''Chance,'' James Joyce once said, ''furnishes me what I need. I am like a man who stumbles along; my foot strikes something, I bend over and it is exactly what I want.''

LEAD: DUE west of coastal Savannah, among pine forests and dusty crossroad towns with names like Santa Claus, Stanleys Store, Jordan, Ohoopee and Daisy, the flat, flourishing fields yield a mild, succulent delicacy. The Vidalia onion - promoted as having a higher sugar content than Coca-Cola, another famous product of
LEAD: LEGENDS OF MALIBU Music by The Beach Boys, Surf Raiders, Surfaris Frontline Video. 45 minutes. 1987. $24.95.

LEAD: It is no insult to Beverly Sills to say that her retirement from the stage a decade ago was one of the best things that ever happened to the New York City Opera. As general director of the company, Miss Sills proved to be as talented a fund-raiser as she was - and remains - a soprano. By all accounts, her fund-raising abilities were the main factor in the growth of the City Opera budget from $9 million in 1978 to a projected $26 million in the 1988-89 fiscal year.

LEAD: Umpires should be respected. In the court of law of baseball, the umpire is the judge, the manager the lawyer. If he isn't persuasive in his argument, a shove or push could mean a contempt citation. Surely this law will be upheld after its strict interpretation. SYLVAN STRETCH Stamford, Conn.
LEAD: Evening Cruise
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Donna E. Shalala left the presidency of Hunter College in New York City to become Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Madison only four months ago, but she is already one of Madison's leading celebrities.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY and the state are jointly rehabilitating the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, a project expected to be completed by the mid-1990's. Widely known as the East River Drive, it is certainly one of Manhattan's great public works, particularly the section between 53d and 92d Streets, a dizzying stretch of dips and rises, views and tunnels, sun and shadow.
LEAD: The State Judicial Conduct Board has asked the Vermont Supreme Court to discipline a retired Associate Justice of the court for five instances of judicial misconduct, all involving a colleague.
LEAD: As part of a three-concert swing through Manhattan, the Los Angeles Philharmonic presented a program Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall that offered two insights into Andre Previn.

LEAD: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Barbara Leith McClenahan, the daughter of Marilyn Van Syckel McClenahan of New York and the late Richard L. McClenahan Jr., was married yesterday to Evan Hays Sheppard, the son of Sarah Frances Hays of Madison, Va., and Michael Bazel Sheppard of Washington.

LEAD: He has a respectable regular season record, 283-192-68, in seven years as coach of the Washington Capitals, but in postseason play, Bryan Murray hasn't done so well. He has never led the Capitals past the Patrick Division final, and that has stirred periodic talk that he might be due for replacement.
LEAD: The fans that night in Cincinnati made a messy problem impossible. Pete Rose is paying for their sins as well as his.
LEAD: The bumper sticker reads ''There's No Life West of the Chesapeake Bay,'' and the philosophy behind it is at the heart of life on Maryland's Eastern Shore.
LEAD: In southwestern Texas, the streams have turned to dust and the grass to tinder, and ranchers are knocking thorns off prickly pear cactus so cattle can get to the moisture inside.

LEAD: A consulting company advising the Defense Department has concluded that it would cost the United States more than $1 billion a year to return to military conscription while maintaining a force as qualified and effective as that of today.

LEAD: A few blocks north of the jumble of glass boxes in the office district of Stamford, Conn., says Leonord W. Cotton, Grove Street was once lined with Victorian gingerbread. Not all the houses were lost. Mr. Cotton, president of Cotlyn Enterprises, patterned the nine buildings of his $7.3 million Cambridge Court, a 25-unit condominium colony he is building at No.

LEAD: Susan S. Gold's giddy joy over her third pregnancy (''The Magic of Babies Makes Three a 'Perfect Number,' '' April 10, Opinion page) should not blind her to the demographic consequences of her actions.

LEAD: Realizing that suburbs do not grow by condominiums alone, Mark Grebler, along with David Camhi and Alvin Lefkowitz, has begun construction of a 30,000-square-foot, retail-and-office building near Brewster, N.Y. The southeastern Putnam County village (pop. 1,650 in 1980) is part of the Town of Southeast (pop.

LEAD: James S. Mooney, a retired New York City Police Inspector, died after a heart attack Tuesday at North Shore Hospital on Long Island. He was 66 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

LEAD: THE TOWN of Englewood Cliffs, which wants to stop sending students to the heavily black and Hispanic Dwight Morrow High School in neighboring Engelwood, has filed with the state's Commissioner of Education its objections to a decision recommending that it not be allowed to pull out.

LEAD: At Santa Teresita Roman Catholic Church in Santurce, P.R., Nellie Marie Vizcarrondo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julio E. Vizcarrondo Jr. of Guaynabo, P.R., was married yesterday to Thomas James Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Burke of Moorestown, N.J. The Rev. Robert Pelton performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The commander of Soviet military forces in Afghanistan said today that a quarter of Soviet troops would be pulled out of the country by the end of this month, and he vowed that their withdrawal would not be greatly impeded by attacks from insurgents.

LEAD: In an essay entitled, ''A Playwright in Hollywood,'' David Mamet said that he was not asking for altruism on the part of movie producers, ''just a little creative venality.'' His uproarious new play, ''Speed-the-Plow,'' makes it clear that hypocrisy and greed are no assurance of profit and that art is less than a by-product in Hollywood.
LEAD: Laura Dean continues to be an amazing choreographer. She certainly demonstrated that Friday night when her company, Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians, performed at the City Center.

LEAD: A TENANT whose fight to keep possession of his family's rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan appeared likely to set an important legal precedent has agreed to give up his legal battle and leave the apartment in an out-of-court settlement with his landlord.

LEAD: Often the very person who deplores the depiction of violence in movies and on television endorses the vivid recounting of the ghastly horrors of the Holocaust to children. Cui bono? What would we have done to prevent the Holocaust if we had remembered the Inquisition?

LEAD: Liza Donnelly, a writer and illustrator of children's books for Scholastic Inc., was married yesterday to Michael Maslin, a cartoonist for The New Yorker, at the Oswego Friends Meeting House in Moore Mills, N.Y.

LEAD: An article in the Sports section last Sunday about Abdi Bile, the Somalian runner, gave an incorrect world record for the 400 meters. The record, set by Harry Reynolds of Ohio State, is 44.10 seconds.

LEAD: A YOUNG boy parks his bicycle and enters a pizza parlor on Central Avenue in Pearl River, but does not lock the bike. In fact, he does not even have a lock. ''What do I need a lock for?'' he says in response to a question.

LEAD: There's stunning news from Moscow: George Orwell's ''1984'' is to be published soon in the Soviet Union. Excerpts already have appeared in a Moscow magazine, Literaturnaya Gazeta, prefaced with an acknowledgment that Stalin's despotism helped inspire the 1949 novel. That Winston Smith; the Ministry of Truth; Newspeak; Big Brother; and the memory hole, where wrongthink documents were vaporized, are to make a licit appearance on Soviet bookshelves is the best evidence yet that a fresh wind is blowing in the

LEAD: Doesn't it occur to the biologist James W. McKearney that the animal he concludes is racing toward the anticipated shock is, instead, frantically trying to speed past it? After failing to do so, it is wearied by its extra efforts and by the shock itself, so it rests before it has to go through the whole tortuous routine again.

LEAD: With Venezuelans as transfixed as they might be by a steamy television soap opera, a long-running drama of passion, politics and power set in the Presidential Palace of Miraflores here is at last building towards its denouement.

LEAD: IT IS OFTEN SAID THAT RESTAURANTS TODAY are part sustenance and part showmanship, not always in equal proportion. And nowhere is the theater of dining more vibrant than in outdoor cafes, whether on a bustling urban thoroughfare, in a salt-sprayed seaside village or deep in a sylvan glade. An outdoor terrace or garden can make an ideal setting for warm-weather entertaining.

LEAD: Noel Perrin may believe he is singing the praises of older women in his article ''The Allure of the Older Woman'' (About Men, April 17). In reality, his left-handed homage only objectifies women in the familiar image of the eternal nurturer. In his view: it is the woman who is counted on to assume the role of mother, teacher and therapist; the woman is merely a way station on the road to manhood; she herself is of consequence only insofar as she can help the younger man cultivate his own inchoate sense of self.

LEAD: A University of Miami study has asserted that the Reagan Administration, Congress and the two political parties have neglected Latin America's growing economic difficulties ''to the detriment of our national objectives and well-being.''

LEAD: ANNE MENARD is executive director of the Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence, which was formed in 1976. The coalition represents 18 programs across the state that provide services to women, who are the primary victims of domestic violence.
LEAD: PRIME TIMES, BAD TIMES By Ed Joyce. 561 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

LEAD: FOR YEARS, the debate over how to repair New Jersey's expensive automobile-insurance system has been depicted as one between insurance companies, which blame high litigation costs, and the trial attorneys, who say insurance company greed is to blame.

LEAD: Vice President Bush today denied that a United States Ambassador told him in 1985 about drug trafficking by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's leader. But Mr. Bush said he could not recall exactly what was discussed at the meeting, held in December 1985 with Everett Ellis Briggs, then the United States Ambassador to Panama.

LEAD: The article titled ''Homeless Projects: Setbacks and Optimism'' [ April 24 ] primarily featured the attempts of Andrew M. Cuomo to do something about homelessness, and mentioned several times his name along with that of the county executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke.

LEAD: FEW human athletic endeavors are as beautiful as an accomplished swimmer gliding through the water, a study in grace and precision of movement. For such people, swimming appears to come naturally. For others of us, bullied into the deep end of a pool by a physical education teacher long ago, swimming is an ungainly struggle, a battle to breathe correctly and stroke efficiently.

LEAD: AS dock space in the nation's harbors becomes increasingly expensive and hard to find, yachtsmen are turning to moorings as a place to keep their boats. When set up properly, the harbor anchorages are as safe as a dockside berth, and often less wearing on the boat. In fact, in a storm, moorings often are preferable.

LEAD: An Afghan guerrilla leader said today that his fighters would attack Jalalabad as soon as it was free of Soviet Army troops.

LEAD: Joseph Zambelli, who put together fireworks displays for Presidential inaugurations, the Statue of Liberty centennial and other national celebrations, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home here. He was 80 years old.
LEAD: Willie McGee's two-out, pinch-hit single in the bottom of the ninth gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 7-6 victory today over the Atlanta Braves.

LEAD: Sitting at a table in their backyard, an elderly man and his granddaughter go through their nightly routine. As he reads aloud from the obituary columns, she crosses off names of people in the telephone book. The grandfather, who operates a discount stand, explains that he is simply cutting down on the cost of his business mailing list.

''A Little Odyssey'' was the appropriate title for a new work collaboratively choreographed and performed by Ms. Tseng and Cydney Wilkes that proved to be a journey into fantasy.

LEAD: The beginning of the Soviet Union's withdrawal of military forces from Afghanistan was given unusually prominent coverage today in Soviet newspapers and on the prime-time television news.

LEAD: Hang Ching Lam, the owner of the Dragon Garden restaurant in the Poconos, was married in Chinatown yesterday. But the hours before his wedding found him with his bride, Hau Hung Yim, smiling for cameras on the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Turtle Island.

LEAD: At long last, it now appears that Carl Lewis and Ben Johnson will race each other this summer as a prelude to the Olympics. Promoters are close to finishing a three-race deal of two 100-meter dashs and one 200 that could generate as much as $500,000 for each runner.

LEAD: Harvard waited out a two-hour delay today before capturing the featured varsity heavyweight event at the 43d annual Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges Sprint Championships on a churning Quinsigamond Lake.

LEAD: Police guarding women and children after they surrendered at Golden Temple complex in Amritsar, India. About 146 people, most of them Sikh militants, surrendered during cease-fire called by police. Page A3. (Reuters)

LEAD: The Detroit Pistons didn't deserve to lose today, Isiah Thomas decided. And largely because of him, they didn't.
LEAD: A man and a woman who the police said were apparently involved in drug dealing, were shot and killed in a Brooklyn housing project last night, officials said.

LEAD: Dr. Marisa Lawrence and Dr. Stephen M. Martin, surgical residents at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, were married yesterday at Tavern on the Green in New York. The Rev. Mathew Pravetz, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Blair Heath, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

LEAD: After eight years of secrecy, a public portrait of the Stealth bomber is taking shape: an airplane with the range and sophistication to roam elusively over enemy territory for repeated attacks with only two fliers aboard.
LEAD: PUT away the Mickey Mouse ears, Edmonton fans. The New Jersey Devils are not coming to town.

LEAD: When the opening credits announce ''Gary Busey is Bulletproof,'' you pretty much know what to expect. One of those daredevil cops who can only survive on film, Mr. Busey jumps into a shoot-out with a room full of gunrunners. They have piles of automatic weapons, he has a handgun, yet he escapes with a single bullet in his shoulder.

LEAD: Someone shrewdly described Singapore as a capitalist society run by a Leninist party. That's the People's Action Party, whose unquestioned boss is Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. For 29 years, Mr. Lee has been a largely benevolent autocrat, helping guide Singapore's 2.6 million people to the third-highest living standard in Asia, with an annual per capita income of $7,000.

LEAD: For all the talk about how voters have been turned off by boring candidates engaged in confusing contests, more Americans say they are paying a lot of attention to the Presidential campaign this year than said so in 1984.

LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has been warning the banking and savings industries that if the long-term problems of the insolvent savings and loan insurance fund are not resolved soon, the next President might come up with some very unpalatable solutions.
LEAD: Membership rolls were flat, while revenues from dues and operations rose a bit, but not quite as much as costs.
LEAD: Ivan Lendl overcame a tenacious opponent and a raucous crowd today, beating 18-year-old Guillermo Perez-Roldan in five sets to capture the Italian Open tennis championship.

LEAD: BURT SUGARMAN'S battle to take over Media General Inc., the Richmond-based communications conglomerate, is being watched by many in the communications industry with the fascination due a portentous struggle.

LEAD: ''An Ocean Apart'' traces 20th-century United States-British relations. That may sound academic and dusty; the seven-part series, however, is not. It is generally imaginative and often evocative; old newsreel film recalls a world that no longer exists. The series starts on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

LEAD: Bassoonists have long learned to live with it: when thrust into the limelight, the bassoon tends to sound - well, funny. Just think of the solo in ''The Sorcerer's Apprentice.'' There is even a bassoon line in Beethoven's Fifth Symphony that is almost always transferred to horns, lest giggles spread through the orchestra.
LEAD: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta urged graduates at the University of Notre Dame to become politically aware and volunteer their skills to the needy.
LEAD: Jose Oquendo has played every position but catcher in his major league career. Now he has a new claim to fame: he's the first non-pitcher in 20 years to get a decision.

LEAD: In the 1940's, Harold Shapero was nominated for prominence in this country's musical future. But those who said they knew soon forgot. Mr. Shapero took on a quiet but distinguished career as a teacher in Boston, and his music has more or less disappeared from the concert stage. LEAD: Albie Sachs, now the most durable of South Africa's exiled dissidents, sits freshly maimed and hiding in a hospital bed somewhere in Britain, his right arm blown away, his left hand resisting his efforts at conversion to the pen, still his only weapon of protest against apartheid.

LEAD: Robert Brown was getting a pregame snack at Yankee Stadium last weekend. For the first time in stadium history, he had lots of choices - sandwiches, pizza, hamburgers, chicken fingers, egg rolls or french fries. He could drink an imported beer, like Dos Equis. He could even eat clams or shrimp, served from a raw bar in little plastic boats.

LEAD: Vice President Bush today accused Senator John Kerry of disclosing potentially ''slanderous'' information implying that a Bush aide had knowledge of drug dealings involving the Nicaraguan rebels.
LEAD: Shareholders of Affiliated Publications Inc., the owner of The Boston Globe, yesterday approved creation of a new class of stock with 10 times the voting power of its common stock.

LEAD: Federal authorities have reached an agreement with 226 companies that calls for the firms to pay $4.98 million in cleanup costs at the now-closed Kin-Buc Landfill in Edison, N.J., the United States Attorney's office said today. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has identified at least 22 cancer-causing or suspected carcinogenic substances at the former landfill.

LEAD: Boris Pasternak's posthumous journey from the outlaw reaches of Soviet literature back to the embrace of the establishment was completed a few days ago as the membership of the Soviet Writers' Union was told Pasternak's woodland retreat would become a memorial museum.

LEAD: Gene A. Davis, formerly vice president of programming for Essence television, has joined the Uniworld Group, one of the largest black-owned ad agencies, as executive vice president of the its new unit, Uniworld Entertainment.

LEAD: THE tumultuous events in adland in the last 18 months were felt yesterday at the annual meeting of the Omnicom Group, whose shareholders voted to allow the board to issue more stock so as better to compete in the acquisition marketplace with the deep-pocketed British companies.

LEAD: August Wilson's ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' was named the best new play of the 1987-1988 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting held yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel. ''The Road to Mecca'' by Athol Fugard was named best foreign play, and the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods'' was named best new musical.

LEAD: Syria's threat to use its army against a pro-Iranian militia in southern Beirut is a signal to Iran that it cannot go too far in challenging Syria's role as a power broker in Lebanon.

Other fashion observers report spotting scarves, skirts and shirts blooming with big floral prints all over town, even on the formerly clad-all-in-black downtowners.

LEAD: A 27-year-old probationary police officer was suspended yesterday on charges that he used unnecessary force in subduing an emotionally disturbed patient at Elmhurst General Hospital in Queens, the police said. Officer Stephen Benner, appointed to the force in July 1987, struck the patient, a 24-year-old woman from Jackson Heights, Queens, in the face after she spit at him, the police said.

LEAD: South Africa's major black trade union federation is to hold a three-day work stay-away next month, apparently in defiance of Government restrictions.

LEAD: More than seven years after its authors first began work on it, the critically lambasted musical ''Carrie'' has closed after 5 regular performances and 16 previews, making the more-than-$7 million show the most expensive quick flop in Broadway history. ''Rags,'' a musical about the Jewish immigrant experience that starred Teresa Stratas, ran for only four performances in August 1986, but cost less: $5.25 million.

LEAD: In a case of great importance to the medical profession, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that hospital peer review committees are not absolutely immune from antitrust suits brought by the doctors they penalize.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL Little progress has been made on ending farm subsidies, officials of the leading industrial democracies say as they prepare to meet in Paris. The U.S. wants countries to set a firm date for ending protectionism. But the European Community maintains the U.S. is as much at fault as anyone else for slowing down the elimination of barriers.

LEAD: Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, brought new definition to his career today as he explained how he wound up with a harrowing task behind the White House press podium rather than at harrowing work in the fields of his father's farm.

LEAD: Two Palestinians died and at least seven others were shot and wounded in renewed demonstrations across the occupied territories today. But this evening the Israeli Army tried to determine if one of those killed, an Arab youth said to have been shot by soldiers, had actually died of natural causes.

LEAD: The Wedbush Corporation and the Morgan, Olmstead, Kennedy & Gardner Capital Corporation said they were discussing a merger of the two securities firms. LEAD: TENNIS U.S. Edges Switzerland: The United States came from behind yesterday to edge Switzerland, 2-1, in the opening round of the $750,000 World Team Cup in Dusseldorf, West Germany. In the other match in the eight-team competition, Argentina and France were tied at 1-1. That match will be completed today.

Well, today's the day for the March figures, and perhaps another spasm of speculation.

LEAD: A NEW study of liberal arts graduates in the business world is optimistic. The study, ''Liberal Education and Corporate America,'' was prepared by Prof. Michael Useem of Boston University.

LEAD: Dave Parker hit a two-run homer and Storm Davis worked out of two early bases-loaded jams tonight, leading the Oakland Athletics to a 3-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

LEAD: Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire announced yesterday that he would not seek a fourth two-year term.
LEAD: A crowded cable car heading downhill in light rain rammed the rear of a truck stopped at a red light today, injuring at least 28 people.

LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge in New York today granted the LTV Corporation a 90-day extension to file a reorganization plan for the company and its 65 subsidiaries. LEAD: The Senate rightly held back on ratifying the treaty on medium-range missiles in Europe when Soviet-U.S. verification differences sprang up. Now Secretary of State Shultz is back from Geneva with the differences resolved.

LEAD: As usual, Bill Irwin's show - in this case, ''Largely/New York'' at City Center Theater - begins with no overture or fanfare. The clown is by himself on stage. Holding a remote control, he points it up at the curtain and slowly the curtain rises, revealing another curtain. Abashed, he pushes the button again.
LEAD: Four people have joined Bartels & Carstens Advertising, which has prompted it to change to Bartels & Carstens and Associates.

LEAD: The international strategy for resolving the third world's debt crisis is being jeopardized by the refusal of private banks to cooperate and by lower-than-expected economic growth in the industrial world, according to a World Bank report.
LEAD: Q. Why does a magnet lose its power over time?
LEAD: It looks as though Pope John Paul II will not be invited to join PEN after all.

LEAD: A student committed suicide Sunday to demand the release of political prisoners and the reunification of Korea. The death set off protests today by hundreds of students, who hurled rocks and firebombs at riot police here.

LEAD: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, announced today that the Senate would begin floor debate on the new missile accord on Tuesday because all verification issues had been resolved.
LEAD: The United States qualified for the soccer competition at the Seoul Olympics when Trinidad and Tobago beat El Salvador, 1-0, Sunday in a qualifying match.
LEAD: The White House working group on the stock market crash recommended changes today that would only slightly alter the way trading is conducted on the nation's exchanges.

LEAD: The driver of a pickup truck that was driven the wrong way on an interstate highway and slammed head-on into a church bus was charged today with 27 counts of capital murder, one count for each person killed in the fiery crash near here Saturday night.
LEAD: High above the downtown area, two wild peregrine falcon chicks pecked out of their shells in a nest on a skyscraper ledge.
LEAD: The Hawks sensed that the Celtics were in trouble tonight in the first 19 seconds of the game, when Dominique Wilkins hit his first shot, an 11-foot jumper on a pass from Glenn (Doc) Rivers.

LEAD: In a settlement af a dispute that arose when Brian Holloway, a three-time All-Pro, was traded by the New England Patriots to the Los Angeles Raiders last Sept. 2, the Patriots agreed yesterday to pay Holloway an undisclosed sum. The National Football League Players Assocation said it would drop charges before a National Labor Relations Board administrative judge that Holloway had been traded because of union activities.
LEAD: Perhaps the best evidence of skepticism about the monthly trade figures, related both to compilation difficulties and the ''lumpy'' nature of trade flows, is the wide range of forecasts.

LEAD: The Big East Conference double-elimination baseball playoffs will begin today at 5 P.M. a with a doubleheader at Muzzy Field in Bristol, Conn. In the opener, top-seeded Villanova (16-2 in league games, 30-20 over all) will play St. John's (9-9, 23-16-1). In the second game, Seton Hall (12-6, 38-14) will play Providence (12-6, 22-27).

LEAD: FOR nearly a decade, the Senior PGA Tour has kept Arnold Palmer, Gary Player, Chi Chi Rodriguez and dozens of other cherished golf names out there on display. It's been their ''mulligan'' in life, a second tee shot from age 50 on. But none of the touring senior pros has hit a longer, straighter mulligan than a new name, Larry Mowry, who suddenly found himself walking onto the final green with Palmer and Player at last year's Pepsi Senior Challenge in Roswell, Ga.

LEAD: Debbie Armstrong, who may be best remembered for her unrestrained glee after winning a gold medal in the giant slalom at the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, has announced her retirement from the United States Ski Team. Taped in the East Room, these periodic specials star the President and Mrs. Reagan as just plain Ron and Nancy having a few select friends over for a character-building exercise in arts appreciation.

LEAD: Dr. Herbert D. Ayers Jr., a teacher of dentistry at Columbia University for almost half a century, died Saturday at the University Heights Nursing Home in Albany after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Roslyn Estates, L.I.

LEAD: Jimmy Connors, the fifth-ranked player in the world, has withdrawn from the French Open, which starts Monday, because of an injured right foot. Connors, 35, first suffered the injury before the United States Open last August. He aggravated the injury three weeks ago. The French Open is the only Grand Slam tournament he has failed to win.
LEAD: A Canadian researcher says that a hole in the ozone layer may be developing in the stratosphere near the North Pole each winter just as a similar hole is created over the South Pole.

LEAD: Selected Poems of Anne Sexton Edited by Diane Wood Middlebrook and Diana Hume George 266 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95. I am filling the room with the words from my pen. LEAD: A week after Paul Westphal resigned as the basketball coach at Grand Canyon College in Phoenix in order to accept a position as assistant coach with the Suns, his older brother, Bill, accepted the job Paul left. Bill, who is expected to sign a three-year contract today, has a career coaching record of 169-149 and was 25-27 the past two seasons at Occidental College in Eagle Rock, Calif.

LEAD: A senior at the Bronx High School of Science, one of the most selective high schools in the country, has a 93 average, three varsity letters, 1,490 out of a possible 1,600 on his Scholastic Aptitude Tests and has never missed a day of school. LEAD: Those who play duplicate have an advantage over the followers of almost all other sport or recreation: In almost any city in the world they can walk into a bridge club, receive a warm welcome, and make new friends.

LEAD: LAST October, two days after the stock market plunge, a 64.83-carat diamond was sold at Christie's for $6.4 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a gem. Last month, that record was broken by the sale of a 85.51-carat diamond for $9.13 million at Sotheby's. The same Sotheby's auction set records with the prices fetched by a pink diamond ($4.73 million) and a cultured pearl necklace ($1.265 million).

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese had the right to dismiss Terry Eastland as his public relations chief. Mr. Meese may even have been right to want him out if he thought his aide was privately commenting on Mr. Meese's plight with not wholly flattering candor. What's astonishing about the firing is its insensitivity.

LEAD: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of May 1 in the seven leading beef states totaled 7.5 million head, up 4 percent from a year ago and 6 percent from two years ago, the Agriculture Department said on Monday. As of May 1, feedlot inventories were larger than a year earlier in five states and down in two.

LEAD: FOR the past year, a homemade cookbook newsletter - with neither recipes nor photographs - has been firing the imaginations of many of the nation's food writers. Grace Kirschenbaum, the creator of the newsletter, World of Cookbooks, has been reading and remembering cookbooks for 35 years.

LEAD: Israel's effort to expel Mubarak Awad, a Palestinian-American known for his espousal of nonviolence, raises fundamental legal and political issues. LEAD: The jury in the cocaine-smuggling case of Carlos Lehder Rivas asked today to see two videotapes of the defendant, including one in which he called drugs a weapon against imperialism. LEAD: I HAVE noticed that there are a great many more young people around than there once were. LEAD: Not every road movie sends its characters off to do their rambling in a Bentley, but then ''Rikky and Pete'' is substantially out of the ordinary. A charmingly offbeat comedy from Australia, it breaks the road-movie tradition at every turn. The title characters are not runaway lovers or freewheeling pals; instead, they're a well-heeled brother and sister who've simply run out of options in Melbourne for the time being.

LEAD: ''Call Me,'' the wrong number now at the Baronet and other theaters, is about Anna, who gets a panting phone call one night (''I want you, I want you, I want you.''), which soon develops into an aural relationship as she and the caller share their fantasies about imaginative uses for an orange. The dirty talk is the more wholesome slice of Anna's story.

LEAD: Markus Raetz will represent Switzerland in next month's Venice Biennale. His work is provocative, contradictory and perverse. It asks us both to slow down and to keep moving. It appears to be anti-dogmatic, yet it is insistent upon an esthetic, one of incompleteness. It makes a point of its openness, but it is every bit as controlling as the masterpiece mentality it is reacting against.

LEAD: In Judge Edward E. O'Farrell's municipal courtroom in New Philadelphia, Ohio, anyone convicted of drunken driving can count on one thing these days: going to jail. That is Judge O'Farrell's rule, and it is one measure of how American society's attitude toward drinking and driving is changing, even in smaller communities where people know each other and have preferred not to make an issue of such behavior.
LEAD: Greek divers have found a treasure-laden Turkish warship sunk by Greek revolutionaries in the Aegean Sea in 1822.

LEAD: IN Frances Sternhagen's 33 years as a stage and, sometimes, screen actress, her performances have progressed, accordise to perfection. She paid her dues by proving versatility, reliability and competence, qualities that her reviewers may have taken for granted. As her work continues to deepen, revelatory may become the operative adjective in describing her performances.

LEAD: HAMMER, by Armand Hammer with Neil Lyndon. (Perigree/Putnam, $9.95.) ''Dr. Hammer has managed to turn himself into a sort of living footnote to some of the principal events of his time,'' Ted Morgan said in The Book Review last year.

LEAD: THE first time, during my two-year stay in Austria, that I saw a letter addressed to Professor Dr. Dr. So-and-So, I thought the secretary's finger had slipped. But it was I who was in error. I was in for a lesson in protocol that to this day I have not mastered.

LEAD: The spring of 1953 was an exhilarating time for the publisher Alfred A. Knopf. His freshly printed American edition of ''The Second Sex'' by Simone de Beauvoir made the New York Times best-seller list and appeared on the way to being considered the most ambitious and brilliant study of woman ever written.

LEAD: ONE by one, in the 1980's, major development sites in ostensibly offbeat locations in Manhattan have gone into construction. The Zeckendorf Organization, as developer, seems to have made a specialty of them.

LEAD: EVERY Saturday morning, 8-year-old Shaunta Matthews waits eagerly in her Milford apartment for her Big Sister, Michelle Polhemus. Once Ms. Polhemus, a 22-year-old volunteer for Big Brothers-Big Sisters of America, arrives from New Haven, the two ''sisters'' hop into the car and do anything from flying a kite, going to the movies or roller skating to simply taking a ride and having a heart-to-heart talk.
LEAD: AT A RURAL COLLEGE in Michigan, Dr. Harry Edwards, the controversial sports sociologist, is delivering his first speech of a three-day, $8,000 lecture stop.

LEAD: MUSIC IN MONTCLAIR The flamboyant Canadian Brass quintet will combine forces with the Salvation Army Band of Montclair for a concert Friday evening at Montclair High School.

LEAD: THE problem of moving 240,000 eastbound commuters across the Hudson River during rush hours every weekday morning has convinced New Jersey transportation officials to push ahead with a plan to create a second express bus lane leading into the Lincoln Tunnel.

LEAD: Beverly Sills has never been the retiring type, so let's avoid the word and say that she is stepping aside. Her scheduled departure at the end of this year as general director of the New York City Opera will not take her out of the company's picture - she becomes president of the board, after all.

LEAD: COUNTY BIKE TOURS Dan and Robbin Sweeney, a young Mamaroneck couple, this month started a business called Criss-Cross Bicycle Tours. They will lead a group of about 14 cyclists around the county on a variety of routes every weekend through the end of September.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article about Wiltshire and other chalk horses brings back memories of using the Uffington Horse as a navigational landmark when flying over England in World War II. Several of these figures were marked on our British air navigation charts.

LEAD: One of the minor obsessions of the British writer Cyril Connolly was the murder of Lord Erroll in Kenya in 1941. But fascinating though he found the case (and officially, it has never been solved), there came a point when he couldn't help noting down his distaste for most of the characters involved.

LEAD: DAVID ROSENBLUM can remember the day he called his parents for help. It was New Year's Day of 1983, and they had dropped in on him, bearing bagels ''like good Jewish parents,'' only to find his house, and his life, in disarray.

LEAD: This spring the United Nations is sending the Vice President of Burundi's Supreme Court on a four-week course to study human rights and is also sending a team of French-speaking police officers to help train Togo's police force.

LEAD: The Lucky-Goldstar Group of Seoul, South Korea, whose 29 companies are involved in everything from oil exploration to video cassette recorders, is trying its hand at building in Bergen County and finding it heavy going.

LEAD: The marriage of Kate Humbird Lind, a daughter of Mrs. Carl C. Ulstrup and John D. Lind, both of New York, to Mark Lee Geoffroy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Geoffroy of Portland, Ore., took place yesterday at the Old Meeting House on the Hill in Yarmouth, Me. The Rev. Dorothy Greene, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: HE plopped onto the concrete steps in front of the Washington Redskins offices, gaining a brief respite from a long, sweaty morning of minicamp practice. The sun's rays dazzled as he squinted his right eye and then his left one. A Concorde jet blazed overhead, leaving a trail of booming clatter. Quickly, his thoughts shifted.

LEAD: THE battle between Europe and ''non-Europe'' is coming to a head. With less than five years to go before a self-imposed deadline, the European Community is racing to remove the hundreds of trade barriers that bedevil its 12 member countries.

LEAD: Daniel Menaker's article, ''Hell on Wheels'' (May 1), brought back memories of similar six-hour weekly drives to and from our farm in Vermont. After five years, however, I realized Mr. Menaker's dream of sprouting wings: I learned to fly and purchased a well-used four-passenger Piper airplane to speed the trip for my wife, two children and overweight dog.

LEAD: A small group of wealthy American businessmen, ideological conservatives and evangelical Christian missionaries have joined forces in an effort to aid guerrillas of a right-wing movement fighting the nominally Marxist Government of Mozambique.
LEAD: After 40 years of hostility and separation, China and Taiwan have never felt so close to each other.

LEAD: The purpose of calling balks is to protect the runner on base. A pitcher must come to a discernible stop before pitching. How can a pitcher be called for a balk when his team is going to intentionally walk the hitter? Umpires have every right to call violations of the rules and regulations of the game, but let's call them only when there is clearly an infraction.
LEAD: Denny Alsop says he made a 33-day trip across the state by canoe to implore all who would listen to clean up and preserve the water.

LEAD: Detectives investigating the execution-style shootings of three workers Friday in the basement of a plumbing supplier in Manhattan identified the last victim yesterday, but said the motive for the murders remained unclear and asked for the public's help in the case.

LEAD: FOR centuries, trade statistics have tracked the course of human history. Exports and imports have documented the rise and fall of civilizations. They marked the progress, for example, of mercantile Britain and Germany as well as the emergence of the United States and Japan as industrial giants.

LEAD: The fierce spring winds now whipping through California have brought little cheer to the hearty band of entrepreneurs who turn nature's power into electricity. Thousands of turbines, some shaped like eggbeaters, some like huge propellers, are humming now, driven by the winds that sweep across California's Central Valley, through Tehachapi Pass and into the Mojave Desert below.

LEAD: Considerably dampened by rain, the Survival Research Laboratories presented its post-apocalyptical performance piece ''The Misfortunes of Desire'' Thursday night in the parking lot at Shea Stadium. This was, first of all, an exercise in audience survival techniques.

LEAD: ''The Ballplayers have been here for hours,'' writes the poet and essayist Donald Hall, ''for batting practice and pepper and shagging outfield flies. . . . We arrive and settle with score cards and Crackerjack and peanuts and Schlitz and hot dogs.'' So it is at major league ball parks before every game, a unique atmosphere captured by Scott Mlyn and Louis Rubin in their new book ''Before the Game'' (Taylor Publishing Company, $13.95).

LEAD: Since I function both as an engaged theater practitioner and as a detached observer of the theater scene, I sometimes find myself in contorted positions, juggling refractory problems. Perhaps the most knotty of these is how to preserve personal principles while trying to nurture a practical theatrical operation, congenial to all its members.

LEAD: Cecil Taylor has been before the public - some sort of public; he has never commanded anything approaching a mass audience, despite all his critical acclaim - for more than 30 years. Yet those who admire his music, from critics to musicians to plain fans, still grope for ways to describe it.
LEAD: THE president of the Farmstead Telephone Group might be based in Glastonbury, but he is doing a lot of business in Beijing.
LEAD: SCIENTISTS are collecting thousands of soil, water and marine-life samples in an effort to develop computer models of Long Island Sound.

LEAD: In his lifetime, Simon Bolivar was a known as a military hero, a political dreamer and a legendary lover. But since his death in 1830, the Venezuelan-born Liberator has gradually assumed the stature of a demigod in the country that he helped to free from Spanish rule.

LEAD: The marriage of Ann Jaquett Wing, the daughter of Mrs. Rodney G. Aller of Lakeville, Conn., and the late Morgan Wing Jr., to Harold Daniel Heck Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Heck of Easton, Conn., took place yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth Swanson performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Plans to use chemicals to destroy Lake Champlain's fish-killing sea lampreys could harm rare birds along tributary rivers in Vermont, a state-sponsored panel of naturalists has warned.

Stone of Greenwich, Conn., and Paris, were married yesterday. The Rev. Vincent Liddle performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Gwynedd.

LEAD: I REMEMBER the study where the Beaver went to receive the wisdom of the ages given to him by Ward Cleaver, his father. I do not remember any of the pearls that this sage cast before the boy but I do remember the study and the magical maleness that emanated from that room and its surroundings. I have always wanted a room like that for my own.

LEAD: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., Susan Sharp Hess, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. The couple graduated from the University of Vermont and completed the exchange, trade, law and language program of the American-Chinese Cultural Exchanges in Shanghai.

LEAD: FOR almost three decades the thoroughbred horses at the 600-acre Mill Ridge Farm just outside Lexington, Ky., were surrounded by nothing but bluegrass. But these days the serenity of an area known as a breeding ground for Kentucky Derby winners is being disturbed.

LEAD: The Kronos Quartet ended its first, sold-out and by all accounts highly successful series at Alice Tully Hall Friday night with a generous program that included three scores partly commissioned by Lincoln Center.

LEAD: President Reagan, heading a contingent of about 600 Americans, will meet five times with Mikhail S. Gorbachev during next week's Moscow summit meeting, which is expected to be heavy with symbolism and ceremony.
LEAD: St. Sergius High School in Manhattan, one of the few secondary schools in the nation to emphasize the teaching of Russian language and culture, is struggling to survive.

LEAD: Secretary of the Interior Donald Hodel has taken it into his own hands to declare Whittaker Chambers's Maryland farm a National Historic Landmark. His pitch to the conservative right is a low-water mark in landmarking.

LEAD: BERND MUNSTEINER is a third-generation gem cutter from Germany who devised a technique of cutting stones that bears little relation to the traditional faceting of gems. He gouges deep vertical, horizontal or asymmetic cuts into the back of a stone so that mysterious planes are revealed when the cuts are viewed through the smooth, unbroken surface.

LEAD: I GUESS you could say I'm a born recycler.

LEAD: A listing of summer music festivals in last week's Arts and Leisure section incorrectly described the schedule of the Dobbs Ferry Chamber Music Festival series. The concerts take place on Sunday. The dates indicated - June 5, 12, 19 and 26 - are correct.

LEAD: PRUNE suckers from magnolias and water sprouts (upright shoots) from dogwoods. Plant geraniums, begonias, ivy, petunias, vinca, impatiens, torenia, salvia, marigolds, zinnias and other showy annuals in tubs, planters and window boxes. Set out started seedlings of peppers, tomatoes, eggplants, melons and sow cucumbers and sweet corn in hills.

LEAD: ''If I don't get no relief,'' said the condemned murderer Edward Earl Johnson, looking at a date circled in black on his wall calendar, ''they're gonna kill me.''

LEAD: Our 702-student high school budget for next year is projected at just under $6.7 million, representing an increase of almost 12 percent. Such double-digit increases in educational budgets, commonplace throughout Fairfield County, are incurring strong resistance by Boards of Finance and by the taxpayer.

LEAD: There was a strange mix of hype and glory to the announcement earlier this month by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch that a 50-acre waterfront park system would be created at Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. The parks themselves aren't hype; they are among the best public spaces designed for New York City in a generation.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. LEAD: The Mets, still streaking in all directions, won their sixth straight game tonight by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-0, as Dwight Gooden won his eighth straight by pitching a four-hitter with the oldtime mastery.

LEAD: Elaine Park of the town manager's office says about half of Williston's 4,291 people want a 400,000 square foot shopping mall in their town and the other half fear such a mall will change Williston's character.
LEAD: FROM classical concerts to jazz sessions and, indeed, on to ''the whole world of music,'' the next fortnight will be a busy time around the Westchester Conservatory of Music.

LEAD: A correction in this space last Sunday misidentified the holder of the men's world record for the 400-meter run and gave an incorrect time. The record is 43.86 seconds; it was set by Lee Evans of the United States in the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City.
LEAD: From last Sept. 17 to Oct. 22, more than 175 small earthquakes occurred near the town of Moodus, Conn. Many were accompanied by sounds like gunshots; the strongest vibrated a van.

Just 19 years ago Vanessa Redgrave, perhaps one day to be known as the mother of Natasha Richardson, won the Cannes Film Festival's best-actress award for her bravura performance as Isadora Duncan, the dancer and all-American romantic who had a fatal fondness for long scarves. The film was Karel Reisz's ''Isadora.'' At this writing, one-third of the way into the 41st Cannes festival, it seems entirely possible that Natasha Richardson might win this year's best actress award for Paul Schrader's ''Patty Hearst,'' a biographical film that is less about an extraodinary character than about an extraordinary event.

LEAD: Haiti has joined Panama as a growing drug-smuggling center, and members of its secret police are forcing their way into the distribution of crack in Florida, witnesses told a special Senate hearing today.
LEAD: THE Boston Celtics have usually been winners on the basketball court but on Wall Street the team has been as well-received as an air ball.

LEAD: Rebecca Kelly is not afraid of big themes. Alienation, euthanasia and capital punishment were only a few of the topics with which the Rebecca Kelly Dance Company concerned itself when it performed Thursday night in the 3-D series at the Joyce Theater. Yet Ms. Kelly's choreographic earnestness was not always accompanied by an equally high level of imagination, for she often left provocative ideas undeveloped.

In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage.

LEAD: The politics of drugs suddenly alters the mood of Congress. Alarmed by rising public concern over drug-related crime and corruption, members are rushing to enlist the Defense Department in a literal war on drugs. Both the Senate and the House propose using the military to stop drug smugglers.

LEAD: To the Editor: Julian West's piece on Melbourne (Travel, April 3) was most informative but left out one important segment under Shopping. Little Collins Street, which parallels Collins Street, is Melbourne's equivalent of New York's 47th Street insofar as opal dealers are concerned. Here are to be found black opals from Lighting Ridge as well as fire opals from Coober Pedy and stones from other mines.

LEAD: ON a May morning, the sense of well-being on the quiet tree-shaded street of Tudor homes in Hamden where the author Maggie Scarf lives with her husband, Herb, seems to run counter to the malaise in American domestic life she has documented in her two best-sellers, ''Unfinished Business: Pressure Points in the Lives of Women'' and ''Intimate Partners: Patterns in Love and Marriage.

LEAD: Australians like to see themselves as the dancing boys and girls of the Southwest Pacific, innately honest, able to deal with anyone on the level of their humanity. You see that knockabout side of the Australian character even in Australian politics. People on the street and in shopping malls, encountering the Prime Minister, the personable Bob Hawke, call him by his first name.
LEAD: The race for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination is effectively over, but the Rev. Jesse Jackson carries on, motivated by practical politics, broad philosophy and personal drive.

LEAD: WHEN Herbert Beckhard designs a building, he sticks to the basics: wood, stone and concrete. LEAD: To the Editor: To your list, in Q & A (April 24), of small gifts to take to the Soviet Union should certainly be added picture postcards of American sights and landscape. We were asked for these everywhere we went - mostly by children and teen-agers, who always were ready with postcards for us. Sew-on patches (not those with political motifs) would also be highly regarded.
LEAD: Tony Pena hit a three-run homer with one out in the 11th inning, lifting the Cardinals over the Houston Astros, 7-4, tonight.

LEAD: THE THIRD FRIDAY. By George Bellak. (Morrow, $18.95.) Hot on the heels of the Government's insider trading cases and Oliver Stone's film ''Wall Street,'' there promises to be a spate of business-oriented novels. After all, if the business of America is business, what better place to set a crime thriller for our times than on Wall Street, where fortunes are gained and lost quicker than it takes a body to fall 32 floors?

LEAD: Centennial Farms' entry of Aptostar and Topicount swept the first two places in the Grade I, $183,300 Acorn Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Belmont Park yesterday. Aptostar was the winner by three lengths. In taking the Acorn, Aptostar, trained by H. Allen Jerkens, took the first leg of the New York Racing Association's Triple Tiara series.

LEAD: Call it a case of poetic justice. In a verse written 30 years ago, Howard Nemerov poked fun at the job of poet laureate, with its long hours and low pay; last week, he was appointed poet laureate of the United States, a post created in 1985. Mr. Nemerov's poem, ''From the Desk of the Laureate: For Immediate Release,'' referred to the British laureate, who is appointed for life and is expected to chronicle important events in verse.

LEAD: WHEN a group of Western newspaper correspondents crisscrossed Far Eastern Siberia last year on a tour of gold mines, reindeer farms and hydroelectric dams, they were occasionally startled to discover that officials in the most godforsaken outposts wanted to discuss prospects for tourism. Tourism? In a place where the 40-below winter is interrupted only long enough for mosquito season?

Jammed in among a desk, some chairs and a staircase, he stutter-steps and swivels, his arms whipping jubilantly back and forth.

Local people call the bend in the big river its knee - a dramatic curve that marks the waterway's transition from an Alpine river into the throbbing artery of one of the continent's most heavily industrialized regions.
LEAD: One of the Reagan Administration's enduring legacies will be the foundation of a national industrial policy.
LEAD: If the 1925 musical ''No, No, Nanette'' has a message for the 1980's, it is the reminder that today's climate of rampant greed is hardly a new phenomenon in American history.

LEAD: Linda Hilliard Eglin, a daughter of Mrs. Thomas Wilson Eglin of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the late Mr. Eglin, was married yesterday to Cole Edmund Harrop, a son of David C. Harrop of New York and Yolanda W. McPhee of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers performed the Presbyterian service in the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson edged out Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the state Democratic convention's preferential vote today, earning seven delegates to Mr. Dukakis's six. One uncommitted delegate to the national convention was also elected.

LEAD: A correction in this space last Sunday incorrectly identified the holder of the men's world record for the 400-meter run and gave an incorrect time. The record is 43.86 seconds and it was set by Lee Evans of the United States in the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City.

LEAD: AS elements of a negotiated settlement between the state and the Long Island Lighting Company fall into place, it appears likely that Long Island's public power advocates will be forced to settle for a partial victory in their battle to take control of the beleaguered utility.

LEAD: A senior Communist Party official strongly hinted today that Prime Minister Karoly Grosz would be chosen Sunday to replace Janos Kadar as party leader. He said the Soviet Union did not have a say in the choice.

LEAD: That the leading roles of ''La Bayadere'' can be interpreted in several different but equally valid ways was made evident Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House when American Ballet Theater offered two performances of this 19th-century classic about ancient India.

LEAD: Only two American Presidents - Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford - have traveled to the Soviet Union for summit conferences since the end of World War II. Here is a look at their meetings. May 1972 Moscow - Three months after a historic trip to China, President Nixon met with Leonid I.

LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed Susan Spano Wells's article, ''Tracking Wiltshire's White Horses'' (Travel, April 10). A number of years ago, while motoring through the Berkshire Downs, I was startled by the appearance of a giant white equine on a distant escarpment. It turned out to be the Marlborough Horse, one of the hill figures mentioned.

LEAD: The delicate and beautiful balance of the game has been upset by the ease of base stealing. Pitchers should be given more, not less opportunity to hold runners on. When every single, walk and hit batter turns out to be the same as a two- or three-base hit, the game is distorted. The baserunning game should be high drama.

LEAD: HEATHERTON SINGS During more than 50 years in show business, Ray Heatherton has attracted his share of different audiences: Big Band fans who loved him when he was lead singer with Paul Whiteman (Bing Crosby was in the back-up trio); Broadway musical enthusiasts who heard him introduce ''Where or When'' in ''Babes in Arms''; radio listeners who recognized the ''Ipana Troubadour''; baby boomers who knew him as ''The Merry Mailman'' and, currently, cocktail loungers who frequent the Garden City Hotel, where he holds forth nightly.

LEAD: AMONG the books topping the list for good summer reading is ''The Politics of Inclusion'' by Thomas H. Kean (Free Press, New York, $17.95), a thoughtful and often provocative work by the Governor about himself and his political career.
LEAD: BASEBALL was never my best game.

LEAD: To the Editor: An article on April 3 described a visit to the ''smallest church in England,'' Exmoor's Culbone Church, a building 35 feet long and capable of seating 33. England evidently has more than one smallest church. In its description of Wasdale Head and Wastwater, the Ordnance Survey's Leisure Guide to the Lake District notes that of six churches that lay claim to the title of smallest, St.
LEAD: Felicia Blanche Garrow and Manuel Wilfredo Guzman-Valiente were married yesterday at the Stella Maris Roman Catholic Church in Condado, P.R. The Rev. Jose Angel Borges performed the ceremony.

LEAD: NOWHERE has the current crisis in nursing been more palpable than on Long Island, where the Nassau County Medical Center has been forced to deny admission to patients because of a dangerously low nurse-patient ratio. As the shortage of nurses worsens, other hospitals, across the state as well as the country, are being compelled to limit services and to turn away patients.

LEAD: Hundreds of paramilitary troops are being transported to Punjab state to strengthen security forces after more than 190 people were killed this week in attacks attributed to Sikh extremists, police officials said today.

LEAD: THE opening shots in a civil war of sorts have been fired over a Federal proposal to open two National Wildlife Reserves to hunting. The dispute pits resident against resident and even animal protectionist against animal protectionist.

LEAD: Harlem at the Plaza . . . May 23 - The Studio Museum in Harlem, which is devoted to the preservation and exhibition of the art of black Americans, will celebrate its 20th anniversary at a benefit at the Plaza. Bill Cosby with be the master of ceremonies, and Representative Charles B. Rangel and others will receive awards.

LEAD: In the last decade, the developer Gordon Ash has churned out mill conversions steadily. First was Roger's Mill, a locomotive erecting shop he converted into offices and a museum. Then came Ivanhoe Mill, a flax factory turned into stores, and Union Works and Argus Mill, yarn and textile factories that are now schools.

LEAD: ''We've been seeing an interesting evolution with Al D'Amato,'' a political analyst, Norman Ornstein, said the other day. ''He's moved up in the Senate, he's gained stature, he's become a lot sharper and more sophisticated.'' New York's junior Senator has indeed come some distance from the political machine in which he started.

LEAD: When the Soviet Arms negotiator in ''A Walk in the Woods,'' Andrey Botvinnik, decides to leave Geneva, his younger American counterpart, John Honeyman, reacts with the alarm of a rebuffed lover. ''Don't go,'' pleads the otherwise stiff Honeyman. ''I'm still your friend,'' the avuncular Botvinnik replies.
LEAD: FRIENDS IN HIGH PLACES The Bechtel Story: The Most Secret Corporation and How It Engineered the World. By Laton McCartney. Illustrated. 273 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: EVE AND THE APES. By Emily Hahn. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $17.95.) Intentionally bypassing famous female primatologists (such as Jane Goodall and Dian Fossey), Emily Hahn, who herself has owned a number of apes, focuses in this book on a second tier of women who have had a particular fascination with these animals.

LEAD: The marriage of Dr. Amy Hope Sherman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius J. Sherman of Great Neck, L.I., to Dr. John Gerard McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah McCarthy of Mitchelstown, County Cork, Ireland, took place yesterday in Amagansett, L.I. Shepherd Frood, a retired town justice of East Hampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at the Sea Breeze

LEAD: Mary Graves Olmsted, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Olmsted of Wayland, Mass., was married there yesterday to Kenneth Leroy Wyatt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Wyatt of White Plains. The Rev. Cassius Webb performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit. A graduate of Williams College, the bride is studying for an M.B.A.

LEAD: Two bombs exploded in the Athens suburb of Nikaia early today, and a third was thrown from a car in the port of Piraeus. There were no injuries, the police said. All three attacks were claimed by a local left-wing terrorist group, Revolutionary Popular Struggle.

LEAD: WEARING only a towel around his middle, Gary Stevens was talking about what he considered to be the moment of truth in yesterday's Preakness for Winning Colors, the filly that won the Kentucky Derby.

LEAD: To the Editor: I took advantage of your suggestion (Travel, Oct. 18) and stayed at the Hotel des Grands Hommes (17 Place Pantheon) for $75 a night in Paris. I enjoyed a view of the Pantheon and such riveting traffic noises as to be convinced that Parisian cars are not equipped with mufflers. In fact, such noises were ever present and make me wonder why this is not the case in New York City.

LEAD: I PAID a dollar for the least expensive car I've ever owned. It was the first of two Chryslers that lived at my house, and, not surprisingly given the price, it was a fairly terrible automobile.

LEAD: When American reporters and editors talk about freedom of the press, some people react skeptically. The press is self-important, they say. It exalts its own freedom above others'. At the slightest inconvenience it cries out that the First Amendment is falling.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE Jets closed down their minicamp Friday and yesterday they traded Russell Carter, a first-round draft choice out of Southern Methodist in 1984, to the Los Angeles Raiders for a conditional sixth-round draft choice in 1989. The condition is that Carter must make the Raiders. Carter the 10th player chosen over all in the 1984 draft, has been plagued by a series of injuries mainly to his legs, hamstring and calf muscles.

Spelman of Westfield, Mass. Acting Justice Robert M. Haft of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Cafe in Grand Central

LEAD: At the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y., Stacie Ann Bowman and Cary Pincus, graduates of the Georgia Institute of Technology, were married yesterday by Msgr. Donald Pryor, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Lindell Bowman Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y. Her father is an executive vice president of Doral Hotel and Resorts Management.

LEAD: IN 1971, two major musical versions of the Bible opened in New York. One, ''Godspell,'' by Stephen Schwartz and John-Michael Tebelak, was an adaption of the Gospel According to St. Matthew. The other was the rock opera ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice, about the crucifixion of Jesus

LEAD: THERE are sculptures, prints and photographs by nine artists in the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson's ''Progressions.'' But the objects are less the subject of the show than the ways in which they are made. Most of the items are backed up by drawings, molds, early impressions, written notes - whatever it takes to demonstrate the stages in a given technique.

LEAD: ''To me as a weaver, Peruvian textiles have always been humbling,'' Jack Lenor Larsen said in a walk through ''The Miracle of Ancient Peru,'' the exhibition he organized at the Edward H. Merrin Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue (at 57th Street).
LEAD: THE city's Hunters Point development project - a combination housing-retail-office complex for the Queens shoreline just above Newtown Creek - will begin its preliminary reviews in June.

LEAD: ''Slaughterhouse Rock'' brings together the usual suspects of teen-age horror films: murder, rock music, sex, low budgets. Alex, a college student, is possessed by the spirit of a cannibal-ghost buried beneath Alcatraz, released from his grave by a dead rock star. In order to exorcise the spirit from his dreams, Alex and a half-dozen of his most foolhardy friends head for Alcatraz in the middle of the night, where they stumble over skeletons, corpses and many live rats.

LEAD: Q. Two years ago we had a plank oak floor installed in our kitchen and dining room over a concrete slab. In the summer, the last 18 inches of this floor warps, even when we use a dehumidifier. In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage.

LEAD: EVEN if Alonzo Mourning is not among the 12 members of the United States Olympic basketball team that will be chosen, the teen-ager is getting a lot of experience at the Olympic trials in Colorado. He is also getting a good look from the United States Olympic coach, John Thompson, who will become Mourning's coach at

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Shlufman of Plainview, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Joy Shlufman, to Mitchell Schuster, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schuster of Dix Hills, L.I.
LEAD: Welsh Onions, Revived

LEAD: It was 4 A.M., nap time for a second-year resident who had been on duty at a Long Island hospital for 20 hours. As she dozed off, her beeper sounded. A patient was having a seizure. She gave him the drug he needed, keeping close watch on his heart monitor. To stay awake, she sang along with the radio in his room.

LEAD: Julio Iglesias was in an unusually loquacious mood Thursday evening at Radio City Music Hall, where he opened the first of nine sold-out shows. Admitting to some nervousness, the Spanish pop star spoke of his continuing eight-year struggle to learn the English language. And in a gently rueful tone, he dismissed the image of himself as an arrogant Don Juan, saying, ''You should see my skinny legs.

LEAD: REAL ESTATE, according to the old saying, is location, location, location, and now some developers are slyly cashing in on a variation of the theme.

LEAD: IN 1984, with great fanfare and great expectations, the Federal Express Corporation introduced a service called Zapmail. Customers could have their documents delivered door-to-door within two hours via couriers and high-speed digital facsimile systems - fax machines. It was a novel, ingenious approach to image transmission, and forecasters were quick to predict its rosy future.
