One hardly felt the lack as his sure fingers and firm musical sense made such a stylish thing of the opening Suite in A by Robert de Visee and traced the quickly shifting moods of Richard Rodney Bennett's short

LEAD: At the Miller Chapel of the Princeton Theological Seminary in Princeton, N.J., Dr. Claire Hughes Jacobus was married yesterday to Andrew Hewes Hildick-Smith by the Rev. John Crocker Jr., an Episcopal priest. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David P. Jacobus of Princeton.

LEAD: At St. Virgil's Roman Catholic Church in Morris Plains, N.J., Marjorie Fay McCourt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. McCourt of Morris Plains, was married yesterday to Thomas Savage Clement, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. J. Clement of Gladwyne, Pa. The bride, a graduate of the University of Rhode Island, is a medical representative in Morristown, N.J., for Abbott Laboratories.

LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has unanimously approved a license to the Commonwealth Edison Company for the second reactor at its nuclear power plant in Braidwood, Ill., near Chicago, to operate at full power.
LEAD: MOORLAND in Montauk has not been ''Graceland'' for Paul Simon, who has endured a number of setbacks since building his home there three years ago.

LEAD: THE IMAGE OF A 2-YEAR-OLD reading aloud from ''The Cat In the Hat,'' and laughing at the silly parts, warms the hearts of many young parents. Parents who are themselves intellectual and upwardly mobile want their children to have all the privileges they have had - and then some. How better to assure their children's success than to get them started early, to teach them to read during that brief shining time when kids absorb knowledge as naturally as they breathe?
LEAD: JOSEPH SLOBODA is a World War II veteran who saw action in the Pacific when his Navy Seabee unit participated in both the battle of Okinawa and the capture of Admiralty Island.

LEAD: THAI cuisine was a natural to succeed Cajun as the hot trend. As American appetites have been energized for spicy foods, the need was met by Mexican, then Sichuan and Hunan, followed by Cajun and now comes the incendiary cooking of Thailand.

LEAD: In response to the article ''Concern Growing on College Costs'' on March 20, I would like to point out that Norwalk Community College and 11 other members of the Connecticut system of regional community colleges offer low-cost alternatives to rocketing college tuition increases.

LEAD: Tacey Belden Phillips, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Gorham Phillips of Montclair, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to James Bernard Carroll, a son of Col. and Mrs. Bernard G. Carroll Jr. of El Cajon, Calif., and Lahaina, Hawaii. The Rev. Dr. J. Yorke Peeler Jr. performed the ceremony at the Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair, N

LEAD: STYLE and function have been pairing up nicely of late in the form of suits that come in contrasting colors and fabric patterns. The ensembles are at once more relaxed and more eye-catching than the traditional matching suit.

LEAD: When Bela Bartok received his training in the last decade of the 19th century, the distinction between performers and composers was not as great as it is today. Gifted students were trained in both disciplines, and Bartok, like Rachmaninoff and Prokofiev, was a piano virtuoso as well as a composer of genius.

LEAD: The marriage of Mary Elizabeth Pendley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan B. Pendley of New Orleans, to Sheldon Lavell Ray Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray of Monroe, La., took place yesterday at the St. Charles Avenue Presbyterian Church in New Orleans. The Rev. Dean Lindsey performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet's American Music Festival presented 22 world premieres, 14 earlier ballets set to music by American composers, one company premiere and the first performance at the New York State Theater of a work (danced again by students) created originally for the School of American Ballet.

LEAD: CARL SANDBURG: His Life and Works. By North Callahan. (Pennsylvania State University, $29.75.) ''A biography, Sirs, should begin with the breath of a man when his eyes first meet the light of day,'' Carl Sandburg once wrote. Adopting this philosophy in covering Sandburg's 89 years, North Callahan has written a creditable biography of the writer and the man, often using his own extensive recollections of the poet whose ''reckless ecstasies of the language'' have become part of the American tongue.

LEAD: Ray Humphrey of Georgetown University won the long jump with a last-round jump of 26 feet 10 1/2 inches, a meet record, at the IC4A track and field championships at Yale University today. Humphrey's jump carried him past Ray Hawkins, who had set a meet record of 26-6 1/2 on the previous jump.
LEAD: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today that most Soviet citizens surveyed in a poll believe that relations with the United States are satisfactory.
LEAD: THE INVENTION OF MEMORY A New View of the Brain. By Israel Rosenfield. Illustrated. 229 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.95.

LEAD: Ill-Fitting Auden It's interesting to see a famous, eccentric poet in an unfamiliar role. In ''The Poet Auden: A Personal Memoir'' (Weidenfeld & Nicolson), A. L. Rowse describes an Americanized Auden in an Army uniform.

LEAD: The dismissal yesterday of the Communist Party leaders in the neighboring Soviet republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan was preceded by repeated outbreaks of unrest in the last three months. Feb. 13 - School boycotts and street demonstrations by Armenians break out in the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Region of the Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan.

LEAD: The nation's first commercial synthetic fuels plant, a $2.1 billion complex, looms over the prairie near Beulah, N.D. Every day, 16,000 tons of lignite coal stripped from nearby mines is fed into a maze of pipes and throbbing machinery, where it is converted into enough gas to supply a city of nearly 250,000 households.

LEAD: ALL that William (Refrigerator) Perry of the Chicago Bears has to do is lose a pound a day so he can play. A slip of the lip by Coach Mike Ditka on Friday let out the previously guarded secret of Perry's weight problem. Ditka said, ''I don't want a 377-pound defensive end'' while discussing switching Perry from defensive tackle to end.

LEAD: Given the many children who follow baseball, I think strict enforcement of the balk rule sets a good example. In a broader context, may I suggest we imprison all people who double park, jaywalk or rip off tags that say ''Do Not Remove.'' JEFF VORCHHEIMER New York

LEAD: In one of the most enjoyable and peculiar career moves of the 1980's, Prince has completed two albums so far this year. The first, ''The Black Album'' (no catalogue number, cassette only), was announced and then, just before its planned release, withdrawn from the market on Prince's orders. Albums that had been pressed in Great Britain were scrapped, but not before bootlegs of ''The Black Album'' had begun to circulate.
LEAD: The Government of President Vinicio Cerezo has shut down a television station that criticized it during a news report.

LEAD: TWENTY years ago the Beatles enlivened the world with their exuberant Mersey sound, born and bred in the northern England port of Liverpool. The city had been declining since World War II but George Harrison, John Lennon, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr spurred Liverpool's rehabilitation as a cultural center.

LEAD: Former aides to Representative Gerry Sikorski, Democrat of Minnesota, have accused him of requiring them to perform personal services and to campaign for him while on the Government payroll, according to two published reports today.

LEAD: Jim Robbins's article, ''America's Red Army'' (April 17), provides strong evidence that the Pentagon is finally preparing its soldiers for the next war rather than the last one. What is not explained is why the National Training Center is located in the Mojave Desert. In every campaign of every war, topography, terrain and climate have played an important role.

LEAD: A 56-year-old Federal judge was shot and killed yesterday afternoon at his Westchester County home by an assailant who pursued him from garden to house with a blazing gun and then shot himself to death, the police reported.
LEAD: National Offers Free Waivers And Soft Tops

LEAD: New York is one of only 14 states in which voters still choose some or most of their judges in partisan elections. Bar associations and other groups are urging the Legislature to switch to a system of appointment known as merit selection. Their campaign gained the support last week of the New York State Commission on Government Integrity, created by Governor

LEAD: Twenty years ago, graduating with honors from Yale University was a mark of distinction. Barely a quarter of the graduating seniors qualified for honors. Fewer than 3 percent were awarded diplomas with the highest approbation, summa cum laude. This year, however, with grade inflation, making an A is almost as common as getting a C once was.

LEAD: Buoyed by a combination of fun and dedication that had marked their five days of spring workouts, the Giants ended their minicamp here today. They were satisfied with the play of the returning veterans, encouraged by the showing of the rookies, and, most of all, relieved that everyone had come through in one piece.

LEAD: Officials of The Bank Mart plan to redevelop a 12-acre eyesore of underused and dormant industrial buildings that is visible from their headquarters at 948 Main Street in Bridgeport, Conn. Cupped around the end of Main Street between Interstate 95, the Metro-North tracks and docks for the Port Jefferson ferry to Long
LEAD: Former Gov. Ray Blanton, who served time in a Federal prison, announced today that he is running for Congress.

LEAD: WHEN W. R. Grace & Company hired New York's former Governor, Hugh L. Carey, in December to head its new Office of Environmental Policy, the move caused barely a public ripple. But speculation has been lively among competitors and shareholders. Why, they wonder, would Grace, which has endured more than its share of depressed profits and job cuts this decade, fork over $400,000 a year to a 69-year-old lawyer with no recent corporate experience?

LEAD: I would like to respond to the recent article on the drinking problem on college campuses today [ ''Campus Drinking: Colleges Confront 'Issue of the 80's' '' ] and, more specifically, the role of public safety departments in the ''administration of penalties'' for infractions of campus alcohol regulations.
LEAD: For the 12th year in a row, cheese production in New York State rose to a record level in 1987, according to figures released this week by the New York Agricultural Statistics Service.

LEAD: To the Editor:

The only legitimate Connecticut pro sports franchise is the Hartford Whalers, who finished in fourth place. Connecticut is one of the richest states in the nation and could easily finance a beautiful arena for any sports team willing to play.

LEAD: MY MATERNAL grandmother, Annie Sparks, lived with our family during the while I was growing up. When I came home from school, after having made a detour to the kitchen to pour a glass of milk and fix a thick peanut butter sandwich on easy-to-tear white bread, I would go up to her sitting room. She would put aside her crossword puzzle - which she did in ink - and tell me stories about our family.
LEAD: Jan Blum grasps tiny green leaves in her fingers the way a jeweler might handle an emerald.

Tang, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Tang of San Francisco, took place last evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Justice Richard W. Wallach of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A memorial service for the actor Harris Glenn Milstead, who was known as Divine, is scheduled for 6:30 P.M. to 10 P.M. today at the Tunnel, 12th Avenue and West 27th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Milstead died March 7. Excerpts from some of his films will be shown. The memorial is open to the public. Donations will go to the Northern Lights Alternatives, a nonprofit organization that provides help for children with AIDS.

LEAD: An article on April 24 about school aid to Long Island incorrectly described State Senator Norman J. Levy's position on the ''save harmless'' formula, which sustains school aid despite a decline in enrollment. He favors it.

LEAD: When Beatrix Potter's achievement as a writer and illustrator of books for children was set out at the Tate Gallery in London last year, people came in the tens of thousands and stood in line forever to get into the show. Substantially the same exhibition can now be seen, through Aug. 21, at the Pierpont Morgan Library.
LEAD: THE JEALOUS POTTER By Claude Levi-Strauss. Translated by Benedicte Chorier. Illustrated. 250 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press.

LEAD: THIS is the time of year for neighborhood walks and back-street wanderings in the car. Every week brings new plants and trees into bloom. Homeowners meet nature's challenge with garden and house improvements.

Village Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Rachel Lyman Perry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Curtis Perry of Lincoln, Mass., and Annisquam, to Bruce Edward Welty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Thompson Welty of Concord, Mass., and Isle of Springs, Me. The Rev.

Erik Kolbell of the United Church of Christ and Cantor Michael
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: JAPANESE, as a rule, treat lawyers with the same affection that they reserve for trade deficits. They tend to view foreign lawyers as outright afflictions.

LEAD: Perceiving that TV docudramas exploit is much like realizing that water is wet. So what else is new? Desperate for material to fill its prime-time needs, television long ago discovered that there were fortunes to be had in ''based on fact'' dramas. Usually, these are adaptations of nonfiction books.

LEAD: ALL the while Martin Kaufman was growing up in Hewlett Harbor, he was in love with show business. At Lynbrook High School, he was a self-described ''bookish kid'' who got ''pushed into debates'' and acted in school plays.
LEAD: Oregonians have always prided themselves on their maverick streak.

LEAD: The New York State Commission on Government Integrity, in a new report, has recommended that all judges in the state be appointed, not elected. But it also conceded that an appointive system does not ''necessarily produce more qualified judges or fewer corrupt ones.''

LEAD: At St. George's-by-the River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J., Jennifer Grant Slingluff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Haines Slingluff Jr. of Rumson, was married yesterday to Patrick Malone Robinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Miller Robinson Jr. of Nashville. The Rev. George Willis performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The marriage of Catherine Huse Lilly, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Lilly of London and Essex, Conn., to Peter Osborne Frisch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Frisch of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye. The Rev. Sharon Chant performed the ceremony.

LEAD: EVERY TIME I see a red and white tourist bus cruising across Moscow, passengers staring vacantly out the window as a guide recites a numbing litany of useless facts about the city, I want to throw a roadblock in its path, jump aboard and tell the visitors they're missing one of the great dramas of their time.
LEAD: IN MAY 1982, my essay, ''Twins Through Time: A Woman and a Walnut Tree,'' appeared in this section.
LEAD: When the Israeli authorities begin reopening Palestinian schools on Monday, they may find that one major strategy for crushing the Palestinian uprising has backfired.
LEAD: WHAT, in modern times, is one to make of a play in which a middle-aged man sets standards for the perfect wife like simple-mindedness and submissiveness?

LEAD: Joan Schenkar often says she writes plays out of her dreams, and some seem born of nightmares. ''The Lodger,'' at the Theater for the New City, is a light reverie. But this nifty little number, which Ms. Schenkar wryly calls ''a comedy of menace,'' may not make everyone who wakes from it long to dream again.

LEAD: AN APOCRYPHAL STORY HAS IT THAT IN THE early 1950's, Joseph Haspel, a founder of Haspel Brothers, the New Orleans company that introduced washable seersucker, attended a business meeting in Florida dressed in one of his firm's new wash-and-wear suits. When his colleagues doubted the properties he claimed for it, Haspel strolled into the ocean fully clad.

LEAD: President Reagan has signed legislation making it easier for hundreds of thousands veterans to receive disability benefits for exposure to radiation from the World War II atomic blasts in Japan or from nuclear test explosions.

LEAD: Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Suzanne Forelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Forelli of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., to Michael Hansom Aubrey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stever Aubrey of Lyme, Conn. The Rev. John J. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: THIS season, tens of thousands of young men and women are being awarded college degrees. At their commmencements, they and their parents are listening to rhetoric wrapped in a mantle of hope to the effect that the world is their oyster.

LEAD: Citizens angered by expanded use of the nation's largest National Guard training base are pressing ahead with legal action to restrain activities at Camp Grayling here, invoking the name of a local lumber baron who donated some of the land 75 years ago.
LEAD: Despite my several points of disagreement, I was moved by Susan Jacoby's piece.

LEAD: WHEN I started working with the retarded in 1974, it was before group homes in the suburbs. Many of the retarded lived in large institutions. In those days, big gates and vast grounds kept them at a distance from the outside world.
LEAD: THE RACE to replace the late Representative James J. Howard in New Jersey's Third Congressional District could easily be the most expensive House campaign in history.

LEAD: Deborah Anne Nichols, a daughter of Mrs. Clement Nichols of Westfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Nichols, was married yesterday to John Raymond Cavanagh, the son of John J. Cavanagh of Upper Greenwood Lake, N.J., and Placida, Fla., and the late Anne Cavanagh. The Rev. Barry Andrews, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Loeb Boathouse in Central
LEAD: AN underground water source in the Pawcatuck River Basin has become the first federally protected aquifer in the state.
LEAD: After setting a course record with a seven-under-par 63 on opening day, Bob Charles of New Zealand shot a three-under-par 67 today at the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative tournament.

LEAD: A truck lost its brakes and rammed a restaurant today, injuring five people. The truck was traveling down an incline in heavy rain at 6 A.M. when the brakes failed. It crashed into Frenchy's Restaurant, caving in the front and injuring Patrolman Kenneth Racine.
LEAD: RIGHT FROM THE BEGINNING By Patrick J. Buchanan. Illustrated. 392 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: One Friday afternoon in 1973, when the Smithsonian Institution was fairly groaning under the strain of its enormous holdings, Porter Kier, the director of the National Museum of Natural History, remarked to one of his curators that he would like to decorate his office with a zoological specimen ''a little bigger'' than the stuffed groundhog perched on his desk.

LEAD: CONCRETE steps outdoors frequently crack and chip. Concrete is brittle and requires stable support from beneath as well as reinforcement within to withstand even moderate stress. Particularly damaging are rapid temperature fluctuations in spring.

LEAD: UNTIL a few years ago, getting a pizza meant going to the nearest pizzeria and ordering a flat pie, topped with cheese and tomato sauce. Product diversification? You could probably get sausage, pepperoni, mushrooms, green peppers and anchovies. And in New York and a handful of other cities, sometimes you could get a thick Sicilian crust.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Q. Two years ago we had a plank oak floor installed in our kitchen and dining room over a concrete slab. In the summer, the last 18 inches of this floor warps, even when we use a dehumidifier. In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage.

LEAD: Finally awakened by the general uneasiness about the lackluster way American art has been represented abroad, the United States Government has done what it often does after being made aware of a problem: provide more money and appoint a committee.

LEAD: Someone to Watch Over Me Starring Tom Berenger, Mimi Rogers, Lorraine Bracco, Jerry Orbach, John Rubinstein, Andreas Katsulas, Tony DiBenedetto. Directed by Ridley Scott. 1987. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 105 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

LEAD: ADDRESSING the first brigade of Soviet troops to withdraw from his country last week, President Najibullah of Afghanistan offered expressions of confidence about his Government's ability to survive. But he also appealed to Afghan Communists to ''consolidate the unity of our party.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Scott Carroll denied that he was ''the South Shore rapist'' who terrorized a wealthy section of Long Island for four years, but compelling evidence against him came from his own mouth. Mr. Carroll was convicted last week of 31 counts of rape and burglary, largely on the basis of a ''voice lineup'' in which victims identified his voice as that of the man who attacked them.

LEAD: Senator Joseph Biden was released from a hospital today after surgery to correct an aneurysm near his brain. The 45-year-old Delaware Democrat underwent surgery May 3 at Walter Reed Medical Center for his second aneurysm since February. Mr. Biden, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, dropped out of the Democratic Presidential race before the first aneurysm was discovered.

LEAD: As Congress considers new proposals for arms sales to the Middle East, debate is again growing over the merits of such deals as a way to win friends, gain influence and preserve peace in the region. American diplomatic and military experts say that arms sales have become a test of the United States' reliability as a friend and ally and a measure of its commitment to the security of other countries.

LEAD: With the cease-fire between Government and contra forces due to expire in 10 days, leaders of the two armies have announced plans to hold a possibly crucial negotiating session beginning Wednesday.
LEAD: TO ONE who has attended a half-dozen performances of '' 'Master Harold' . . . and the boys,'' it is amazing how Athol Fugard's masterpiece still has the power to startle.
LEAD: Marist College

LEAD: At the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y., Alicia Anahid Longobardo, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Guy Longobardo of Bronxville and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Lance David Langston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Langston of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Margaret Mahaney performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Diana Helene Wolff and David Emerson Chapin were married yesterday at their home in Clifton, N.J., by Judge Philip Freedman of State Superior Court in Newark.

LEAD: AS you approach Suzdal on a sunlit day, one thing stands out from afar: the dome over the entrance gate of the Convent of the Intercession, a lone patch of gold that seems to catch the sunlight and send it, shimmering, into the long, level distance.

LEAD: Behind the crusade for money that has helped push Michael S. Dukakis to the brink of the Democratic Presidential nomination are about a dozen wealthy fund-raisers drawn to him by old friendships, Greek-American pride and a desire to participate in politics at the highest level.

LEAD: ONE week from today, when President Reagan arrives in Moscow for his fourth meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the evolution of Soviet-American relations will have completed a dramatic cycle. From a surge of cooperation in the early 1970's and then into a tense period of frozen hostility, the two powers have now emerged into what may prove to be the healthiest relationship in their postwar history.
LEAD: BEFORE they scatter for summer vacations, dozens of Connecticut's finest young soloists and groups will be showcasing their talents in free concerts, two this afternoon and another next Sunday.

LEAD: ONE hundred years ago, George Eastman introduced a revolutionary idea in picture making: photography for everybody. His first roll-film camera, introduced in 1888 and called the Kodak, allowed dilettantes and duffers to take photographs easily without the bother of carting around glass plates, tripods and other paraphernalia.

LEAD: Last Wednesday the Federal Communications Commission ruled that reruns of network programs carried by cable companies must be ''blacked out'' if a local station has purchased the exclusive right to broadcast that program in the same area. How will the ruling affect local broadcasters and cable system operators?
LEAD: AFTER facing its worst siege of hepatitis in at least six years, with 74 recorded cases of the Type A virus in five months, Onondaga County in New York prepared for a return to normalcy.

LEAD: Gloria Susanne Signorelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Signorelli of Newton, N.J., and Eliot Ward Berry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rynn Berry of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., were married yesterday by the Rev. Frederick Hoesli at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

LEAD: At St. George's Episcopal Church in New York, Laura Sanxay Schwed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Schwed of New York, was married yesterday to Michael George Sirico, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Sirico of the Bronx. The Rev. Gerald G. Alexander performed the ceremony.
LEAD: A stockyard worker is free on bond after being arrested on Federal charges that he made a death threat against the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

LEAD: INTEREST rates are edging up, bringing new allure to adjustable-rate mortgages. In April, 48 percent of new mortgages were adjustable, compared with 22 percent in April 1987, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Borrowers are attracted by introductory rates that are often dramatically lower than those of fixed mortgages and by the knowledge that if rates go back down, they won't be locked into a high rate, said Ray Durn, a real estate lawyer in Cleveland with Jones, Day, Reavis &

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev will ask President Reagan to approve a joint United States-Soviet unmanned flight to Mars during their summit meeting in Moscow next week, according to an interview with the Soviet leader that appears in The Washington Post for Sunday.

LEAD: At the Presbyterian Church in Tenafly, N.J., Julia Ann Eckhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Eckhardt Jr. of Tenafly, was married yesterday to Stephen Ignatius Allen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Allen of Erie, Pa. The Rev. John D. Potter Jr. performed the ceremony.
LEAD: AS A former press aide to Assemblyman Chuck Hardwick, I was asked to speak to a ninth-grade class on the ''how-to's'' of political campaigning.

LEAD: New York State Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and his colleagues in the Legislature, circling a politically wounded Mayor Koch, seem intent on blocking his plan for new public authorities to finance and repair public works. The legislators may have reason to be vexed with a Mayor who bullied legislators over issues like school aid and municipal pensions.

LEAD: The balk rule is serving only in slowing the game without really tackling the reason for its institution. More balks appear to be called when the pitcher pitches to the batter than when he throws to first base to eradicate a troublesome man on base. The rhythm of the pitcher is unnecessarily interfered with, and the resultant confusion serves only to make the game less enjoyable.

LEAD: Haydn will play a major part in this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center. A week devoted to his music will include a daylong, eveninglong ''Haydn Marathon,'' two concerts on original instruments conducted by Christopher Hogwood, and talks by the Haydn scholar and biographer H. C. Robbins
LEAD: THE ISLAND By Gary Paulsen. 202 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts. $13.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
LEAD: IT IS NEAR THE END OF A THREE-HOUR conversation that Dr. Gerald M. Edelman leans across the conference table and looks me in the eye.

LEAD: This week's numbers did little to ease the nerves of anyone worried about inflation. The most-cited measure of inflation, the Consumer Price Index, showed a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent in April, in line with expectations. That works out to an annual rate of 5.3 percent, up from last year, but not too alarming.

LEAD: Penelope L. R. Bryant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. M. Bryant of Rockport, Mass., and Washington was married yesterday to Grady Clopton Catterall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Catterall 3d of Dallas. The Rev. Caroline S. Pyle performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in

LEAD: An Exchange of Words ALTHOUGH the summer season isn't officially here, there have already been fireworks in Westhampton. At the finale of the Westhampton Writers Festival last Saturday night, Budd Schulberg took on Dakin Williams, brother of the late Tennessee Williams.

LEAD: A SIX-YEAR zoning bonus to allow bigger skyscrapers in west midtown ended this month amid a final push by developers, who are building 15 office and hotel projects in this section of Manhattan that had rarely seen a construction crane in decades.
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation knew about Laurie Wasserman Dann. So did prosecutors in three states. So did her neighbors and her former husband and in-laws.

LEAD: ONE of the oldest rules of thumb in the game, dating back to whist, is ''third hand high.'' Whist-players, with no dummy in view to help them, followed this guideline blindly. Bridge players are better off and can recognize the obvious exceptions. At the first trick the third player usually preserves a high card that is poised over an honor in the dummy.

LEAD: NO one expected the Yankees to have the best starting pitching in the American League East; the starting pitching, in fact, was generally believed to be the one element that could prevent the Yankees from winning.

LEAD: THE Pulaski Skyway's northbound lanes will be closed today from 6 A.M. to 6 P.M. for the installation of sign posts. Also, motorists using Route 46 in Parsippany-Troy Hills will find the ramp from Route 46 East to Interstate 80 East closed until mid-June.
LEAD: THE two-year-old addition on the northern Westchester home was supposed to have been a playroom, but it is hard to play around the four cribs that fill the room.

LEAD: The affinity between ice skating and theatrical dancing came to the fore again in an unusually creative evening presented on Friday night by two Canadians, Gary Beacom and Gia Guddat. The program also featured new solos by John Curry, the former British Olympics champion.

LEAD: You start about 6,000 years ago, in the fertile plains of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, and as James C. Y. Watt, who presides lovingly over the newly installed ancient Chinese collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, can tell you, the characteristics that distinguished the art treasures of China from that of other traditions are already visible.

LEAD: EMPLOYERS in Suffolk County, contending that a bill to regulate video-display terminals in the workplace has already driven away prospective new companies, are waging a furious lobbying campaign to defeat the measure.

LEAD: TWO pros who are still competing are on the list of three players who will be voted into the PGA-World Golf Hall of Fame Nov. 3. Tom Watson and Peter Thomson will be enshrined, along with the late Robert Harlow.

LEAD: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

LEAD: NOW that the weather has finally warmed up, soft-shell crabs are coming into the market. The most common way of cooking them is simple: dust them with flour and fry them in butter. But soft-shell crabs beget a challenge to chefs, who come up with all sorts of interesting and unusual ways to prepare them.

LEAD: PETER'S INN in East Northport may look like a neighborhood bar, but the food is certainly not pub grub. First-timers are startled to find jalapeno pasta, carpaccio, Cajun shrimp with wild rice and lobster pasta on the menu. Mixed grill at Peter's breaks the mundane mold with filet mignon au poivre, rare duck breast in a green peppercorn and brandy sauce and a grilled veal chop.
LEAD: An unusually deft first mystery is DEAD RECKONING by Sam Llewellyn (Summit, $15.95). Mr. Llewellyn, a British journalist, seems to know everything about yachts and racing them.
LEAD: IT used to take at least 30 minutes to make a pizza and far longer to deliver it. So, calling pizza a ''fast food'' was a bit of a misnomer.
LEAD: Maple syrup production was up by 225,000 gallons this year, but producers did not have the banner year they had been hoped for. The auality was what counted most, a Federal official said.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: FOR more than a decade, Cardinal Industries of Columbus, Ohio, has kept on its sales map a big X scrawled across the city of Parma.

LEAD: ''Not bad at all,'' Oblonsky said, tweaking the quivering oysters out of their pearly shells with a silver fork and gulping them down one after another. ''Not bad at all.'' $ ? - ''ANNA KARENINA''
LEAD: BLUE BLOOD By Craig Unger. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: IT takes special courage to enter the videotex market, a graveyard for many bold projects of brave and strong companies. Yet the idea of videotex - a service that harnesses the power of the personal computer to bring electronic shopping, information and entertainment into the home - remains so compelling that the International Business Machines Corporation, the nation's largest computer maker, and Sears, Roebuck & Company, the largest retailer, have formed an alliance to try to resurrect the market once again.

LEAD: In the aftermath of their 11-3 belittling at the hands of the Athletics Friday night, there was a measure of embarrassment in the Yankee clubhouse. Last night, there was a measure of respect regained.
LEAD: It was the night when a high school-age friend of one of her sons showed up at her door drunk and driving his father's car that Joan Houlihan decided something had to be done.
LEAD: ARIEL By Jose Enrique Rodo. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. Prologue by Carlos Fuentes. 156 pp. Austin: University of Texas Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95.
LEAD: JOHN C. DONAHUE may be only a volunteer firefighter in Windsor Locks, Conn., but he is willing to fight for the right to volunteer.
LEAD: HOUSE OF GAMES Starring Lindsay Crouse and Joe Mantegna (in photo), Mike Nussbaum, J. T. Walsh, Lilia Skala. Directed by David Mamet. 1987. HBO Video. 101 minutes. $89.99. Rated R.
LEAD: A police lieutenant who faces demotion and a pay cut after criticizing what he said were racist attitudes here is suing town officials.

LEAD: Louise R. Hoppe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hoppe of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to John D. Finnerty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Finnerty of Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Palke performed the ceremony at the Immanuel Lutheran Church in Alexandria.

LEAD: WHEN jet lag was first named, an acquaintance of mine who affected only modish problems said that she was suffering a really bad case because she had taken the shuttle plane to Washington three times in the previous week. Of course, the worst part of jet lag - flying across time zones too fast for the body to adapt - has nothing to do with one-hour trips in the same zone.

LEAD: Less than 48 hours after being humiliated by Utah, the Lakers, rejuvenated and apparently bent on revenge, eliminated the Jazz today from the National Basketball Association playoffs, 109-98. The victory was the first seventh-game triumph in a decade for the Lakers and bailed them out of a series they'll not soon forget.

LEAD: Carole Baldoff Kerr, a daughter of Ann Baldoff of Pittsburgh and the late John C. Baldoff, and Frederick E. Guest 2d, a son of the late Helena McCann Charlton of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Winston F. C. Guest of Roslyn, L.I., were married yesterday at Old Westbury Gardens in Old Westbury, L.I., by the Rev.

LEAD: THE stock in the shops changes little from year to year. There are fanciful lacquered boxes, sunny amber jewelry, brightly painted wooden bowls, warm fur hats, vodkas of varying flavors and matryoshkas, the traditional nested wooden dolls. Even the mostly indifferent and occasionally rude service that characterizes Beriozkas,

LEAD: IT HAS been illegal for some time in New York City to discriminate against handicapped people. In January 1987 a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan extended the legal protection to the dead as well as the living.

LEAD: Closings in the week ending May 7 MANHATTAN Madison Square Area $275,000 425 Park Avenue South (29th St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. loft co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; part-time doorman, large kitchen, East River view; maintenance $865, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia)

LEAD: Paul Kilgus pitched seven perfect innings before Gary Gaetti led off the eighth with a double for Minnesota's only hit as the Texas Rangers beat the Twins, 3-0, tonight. Gaetti hit a hard line drive to left-center field on a 1-0 pitch. Kilgus (6-3) walked Gene Larkin, the next hitter, but struck out Kent Hrbek and got Tim Laudner to line into a double play.

LEAD: TYRONE GUTHRIE, the Stratford Festival's first artistic director, had a genius for publicity, and over the years he burnished his version of the festival's beginnings in 1953 to a fine sheen. In Guthrie's story, a boy from a bucolic Ontario town was fired by the proverbial high school English teacher with a passion for Shakespeare.
LEAD: The Government of Singapore last week released 3 of 11 people detained without trial since mid-April under the country's Internal Security Act.

LEAD: THERE ARE TIMES WHEN even the most devoted cook looks for a way out of the kitchen. Clearly, plenty of shortcuts exist today, but these have more to do with getting a meal on the table in a hurry than creating pleasurable dishes. Fast food, however, doesn't have to look or taste that way. It can be as simple as grilled fish, poultry or meat, or it can give the illusion of complexity.

LEAD: THE economic news was bright last week. The Government reported that surging exports cut the United States trade deficit to a three-year low in March. The dollar firmed. Factories were busier than at any time in the last eight years. The nation's purchasing agents, who order goods for their companies, predicted, by a margin of 7 to 1, that the economy would be better in 1988 than in 1987.

LEAD: Almost 3,000 graduates of the Military, Naval and Air Force Academies will toss their hats into the air in the next couple of weeks at West Point, Annapolis and Colorado Springs, after having finished educations that are among the most rigorous in the United States.

LEAD: HARTFORD has an office vacancy rate of just 8 percent, one of the lowest in the country. But this upbeat market has its down side. The city has a severe housing shortage and monumental traffic and parking problems caused by the 125,000 commuters who pour into a square-mile business district each day.

LEAD: After the Boston Bruins dropped the first two games to the Edmonton Oilers in the series to decide a Stanley Cup champion, Rick Middleton stood in a jammed locker room hallway with a faraway look.
LEAD: For 8-year-old Carlos Toro and his friends, the good times growing up in Jamaica, Queens, are usually overshadowed by fear of the neighborhood's rampant drug trade and flashes of violence.

LEAD: Basking Ridge $640,000 25 Stoneridge Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-month-old French provincial; c/a, fireplace in family room, 2-car garage; taxes $8,349. Butler $215,000 21 Western Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 63-year-old farmhouse; newly renovated, porch, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,723.

LEAD: 'The pharmacologic and behavioral processes that determine tobacco addiction are similar to those that determine addiction to drugs such as heroin and cocaine.' - C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General, in his annual report on the health consequences of smoking.

LEAD: THOSE who believe in the eventual convergence of the Soviet and American systems could take heart last week. An ''Astro Pizza'' truck from New Jersey, parked on the Moscow river embankment, was doing a brisk business selling pizzas at stratospheric prices. The score from ''Porgy and Bess'' blared from car radios Wednesday afternoon, and each evening, slick American commercials, translated into Russian, splashed across television screens promoting Pepsi-Cola and Visa credit cards.

LEAD: An increasing number of Lebanon's Shiite Moslems, among whom Iran has enjoyed wide popularity, have become hostile toward Teheran, which they blame for relentless factional fighting in the southern suburbs of Beirut.
LEAD: SCRUNCH, squeak, pop! From bursts of air into a handful of string balloons, a shy swan slowly emerges as its creator's stubby fingers work with the delicate dexterity of a surgeon.
LEAD: CHILDREN'S THEATER
LEAD: CHINTZES BLOOMING WITH CABBAGE roses, lilies or carnations have flowered into overabundance during the past few years, but decorators are now looking to quieter, more subtle patterns.

LEAD: Wendy Leigh Romanoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bernard Romanoff of Boca Raton, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to James Ross Packer, a son of Richard Packer of Norwalk, Conn., and Joan Packer of Vail, Colo. Dr. Charles Aigen, a marriage counselor, officiated at the Carlyle Hotel.
LEAD: AMONG the brightest events this spring is the arrival of a book that should spur the enthusiasm of new collectors and re-excite those for whom collecting crafts is habitual.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to Paris in the 1920's to contemporary New York.
LEAD: RENOVATION, revitalization, renewal. These three R's, the goals of the Village of Hempstead nearly a decade ago, seem closer to achievement now than they were then.
LEAD: THE GIRL FROM CARDIGAN By Leslie Norris. 164 pp. Layton, Utah: Gibbs M. Smith/Peregrine Smith Books. $15.95.
LEAD: WITTGENSTEIN'S MISTRESS By David Markson. 240 pp. Elmwood Park, Ill.: The Dalkey Archive Press. $20.

LEAD: Obviously food is the most basic human need. There is an underlying shame that in a world where some 10 million face starvation and hundreds of millions suffer malnutrition, the most abrasive trade problem is agricultural surpluses.
LEAD: An investor in a restaurant has charged that a Government witness embezzled $200,000 from the business and that the Federal authorities are blocking efforts to recover the money.
LEAD: A railroad brakeman was killed and the engine of a freight train derailed early yesterday in a head-on collision between two Conrail trains in Fair Lawn, N.J., railroad officials said.

LEAD: The marriage of Kathryn Cordes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Woglom of Norwalk, Conn., to Gianfranco Chicco, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Chicco of Kalamazoo, Mich., and Lodi, Italy, took place yesterday at the hotel Maxim's de Paris in New York. The Rev. Michael B. Easterling, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: ASK any employer about problems in the workplace and chances are the scarcity of entry-level employees will be mentioned immediately. Even as managerial and white-collar jobs disappear because of layoffs and mergers, the demand for entry-level workers at Westchester companies has never been stronger, said Richard Schaab, director of program operations for the Westchester County

LEAD: The Clippers, the ''other'' Los Angeles team, took a step yesterday toward establishing a winning identity. The troubled franchise, which last made the playoffs in the 1975-76 season when it was still based in Buffalo, won the draft lottery and the right to Danny Manning of the University of Kansas, the college player of the year.

LEAD: Julio Bocca, the young Argentine dancer who joined American Ballet Theater last year, is at only the beginning of his career. Yet an astounding ability to transform himself in every role, to understand characterization and style, bespeaks a performer blessed with inborn maturity.

LEAD: China may strain for Olympic glory, but so does the United States - with the help of ''instant Americans'' (''China Strains for Olympic Glory,'' by Trip Gabriel, April 24). Special legislation has been introduced to obtain citizenship for the tennis star Ivan Lendl in time for the 1988 Summer Games.

LEAD: When a golfer is playing for victory in a tournament, coming out of trouble to save a par on a hole can be more important than getting a birdie. A save allows the subsequent birdies to have considerably more meaning and can prevent loss of ground.
LEAD: Some topics, though by no means negligible, do not warrant lengthy discussion, and have therefore been bundled up into the following medley of short takes:

LEAD: An article on April 24 about a record-setting human-powered flight across the Aegean Sea referred incorrectly in some copies to the hometown of one standby pilot. The pilot, Greg Zack, is from Wilmington, N.C.

LEAD: FOUR months ago, after a spate of anti-Semitic vandalism in and around Westchester County, government officials met with Jewish and other religious leaders to coordinate a response to the racial and religious crimes.

Swid strolled last week through his estate-size office at the top of a skyscraper on the Avenue of the Americas and settled onto an expensive sofa. He had just become a movie potentate by buying into the Cinecom Entertainment Group, a small but growing film production and distribution company.

LEAD: A Federal district judge has temporarily blocked a Reagan Administration plan to test employees of the Federal prison system at random for drug use. The testing, which was scheduled to begin Monday, would have affected 35,000 workers around the nation.

Stanley of Pinckney, Mich., and Everett E. Stanley of Westminster, Md., took place yesterday at the Thomas Law House in Washington.

LEAD: ''I don't know how I could express hunger,'' Patricia Bennett said. ''It was not to the point where I passed out. The children always ate. Maybe I didn't. Maybe not for two or three nights. Maybe some juice during the day, but that's not eating.''

LEAD: Press secretaries for top Government officials often must perform a high-wire act. In their attempt to tell the truth while protecting their superiors, theyrisk a fall, as demonstrated when Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d dimissed his spokesman, Terry Eastland.
LEAD: The Dallas Morning News and The Dallas Times Herald have settled their lawsuits accusing each other of fraudulent circulation practices.

LEAD: The Mets completed their week's sweep through southern California today with a seven-game winning streak, a five-and-a-half-game lead and a two-round knockout over Fernando Valenzuela. And they even escaped the rage of Pedro Guerrero, who hurled his bat past the mound after David Cone bounced a curveball off his helmet.

LEAD: The British Government is considering selling British Rail, the national railroad system, the Economist reported in its latest issue. The plan is being worked on by a policy unit within Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office, the magazine said in its May 21 issue, which was made available today.
LEAD: For most of the 1980's, the $3 billion, 403-mile Trans-Gabon Railroad was the largest construction project in sub-Saharan Africa.
LEAD: The Upjohn Company will soon open its laboratory in Japan, the drug maker said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: At least 18 fishermen drowned Saturday after their boats capsized in the Bay of Bengal off the port of Chittagong, The Bangladesh Observer reported today.
LEAD: A drop of sweat slipped onto his brow, perhaps from the heat, perhaps from nervousness, as Nakambo explained how lucky he was to find a job as a private school teacher that pays $10 a week.

LEAD: Penn State won its third consecutive IC4A team championship today, but Harry Grove's Nittany Lions had to sweat out the final event - the 1,600-meter relay - before they could enjoy the victory.
LEAD: Are paintings that once decorated the offices of Nazi officials (a) works of art, (b) historical documents or (c) symbols of darkness?

LEAD: Almost desperate to come to terms with overcrowded prisons and the high cost of incarceration, many states have turned to alternative penalty programs that are similar to ideas that were tried and largely discarded a decade ago.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo greeting graduates yesterday in Amherst, N.Y., at the commencement ceremony at the State University at Buffalo. In his commencement address, Mr. Cuomo urged the graduates to shape ''a world larger than the one that ends in your own back yard.'' (NYT/Joe Traver)

LEAD: The Rev. W. Seavey Joyce, a Jesuit priest and president of Boston College from 1968 to 1972, died of cancer of the pancreas on Thursday at the Campion Center Jesuit Residence in Weston, Mass., where he lived. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: The Edmonton Oilers were right where they wanted to be throughout the game, and their discipline put them in position to attain their fourth Stanley Cup by a novel method, a sweep of the opposition.
LEAD: Andrew Gaze lived out a fantasy two years ago in the Georgetown University fieldhouse.

LEAD: ''The black family has been an issue in search of leadership,'' Eleanor Holmes Norton observed in an article three years ago in The New York Times Magazine. Even as she wrote, however, that leadership was starting to materialize in a familiar place: the black church.
LEAD: Following his conviction last week on charges of price-fixing while working for another company, James J. Harford, who is the president of the Seven-Up Holding Company, resigned yesterday.

LEAD: There was enough rain in the Northeast this week to draw comparisons with the Flood. At the Big East baseball tournament in Bristol, Conn., the man who played Noah was a groundskeeper, 59-year-old Anthony Guerriero, who will retire this year as Parks Department Group Leader at Muzzy Field. Guerriero's devotion to service may or may not have had something to do with divine instruction, but he managed to turn a swamp into the baseball equivalent of Mount Ararat.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week begin with today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by an auction of two-year notes and an auction of five-year notes on Thursday.

LEAD: The Sara Lee Corporation of Chicago has selected William Altman Advertising, a $5 million shop specializing in the arts, to handle advertising for its corporate affairs division. The agency, which also has the Metropolitan Museum account, will promote arts and philanthropic events sponsored by Sara

LEAD: Following a visit to Vietnam last month, I concluded that more than 13 years after the last American helicopters left Saigon, the United States should consider ending its isolation of Vietnam. For the first time, Congress seems ready to review American policy there.

LEAD: Karen Waddell, a daughter of Roberta W. Waddell of New York and the late Richard H. Fuller, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Riverdale Yacht Club in Riverdale, the Bronx.
LEAD: This year's college graduates were freshmen in high school when Ronald Reagan became the 40th President, and they will be in their middle 30's, or thereabouts, at the turn of the century.

LEAD: International A3-13 Karoly Grosz replaced Janos Kadar as head of Hungary's Communist Party. Mr. Kadar, whom the Soviet Union installed as party leader in 1956, was elected to a new post that is meant to be ceremonial. Page A1 Man in the news: Karoly Grosz, the new head of the Hungarian Communist Party, has shown political skill and adaptability, overcoming a reputation of stolid conservatism.

LEAD: Last fall's indictment of Manfred Ohrenstein, the New York Senate minority leader, on charges of putting campaign workers on the legislative payroll cast an embarrassing spotlight on Albany's job practices. The Legislature now magnifies the shame: It seeks dismissal of the charges.

LEAD: The current silly season for television movies keeps clip-clopping along this evening at 9 with NBC's ''CAT Squad: Python Wolf,'' an action-adventure exercise distinguished by one of the year's more incomprehensible plots. The film does carry an eye-catching credit. It was directed by William Friedkin, who won an Academy Award for ''The French Connection.

LEAD: In 1980 Paul Brady moved from Irish folk music to more personal songwriting. He came up with a style that occasionally draws on traditional Irish storytelling but more often exalts private feelings to metaphorical heights, like an Irish Jackson Browne. Two of his songs, ''Steel Claw'' and ''Paradise Is Here,'' were recorded on multimillion-selling albums by Tina Turner - his main exposure in the United States.

LEAD: A California farming town with two tiny newspapers that want to merge their non-editorial operations is becoming the center of a debate with national ramifications.
LEAD: Saturday afternoon was a time for swooning at the Metropolitan Opera House, for American Ballet Theater offered two unabashedly passionate works.

LEAD: The long-expected veto of the omnibus trade bill is likely to come Tuesday even though the House will be in session and is likely to vote to override that same day, White House and Congressional officials predict.

LEAD: As bickering flared anew today among Republicans and Democrats over the state budget shortfall, Governor Cuomo indicated that the shortfall would be larger than the $300 million figure that his administration had predicted earlier this month.
LEAD: Giorgio Almirante, who had a minor role in Mussolini's last government and was a founder and longtime leader of Italy's small but vocal neo-Fascist party, died today. He was 73 years old.

LEAD: * Spain, which ruled the Philippines for 300 years, has offered a $70 million loan to its former colony, according to the Spanish Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez. Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines started in the 16th century and lasted until the Spanish-American war in 1898. Mr. Gonzalez said Spain would cooperate with other members in the European Community to help the Philippine economy.
LEAD: Two blacks were killed and 30 were wounded, some seriously, in the township of Soweto today when explosives were hurled at the meeting of a conservative black political party, the police said.

LEAD: COMMON stockholders have generally received higher returns from electric and telephone utilities over the last 16 years than from unregulated industrial corporations, a study by the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners has found.

LEAD: A strong earthquake rocked the western Greek island of Cephalonia today and set off a landslide near the main town of Argostoli, the police reported. There were no reports of casualties or building damage. However, the quake, which was centered almost 200 miles west of Athens and registered 5.5 on the Richter scale, ''shook everybody awake this morning'' a police officer on the island said.
LEAD: THE Golden Age of auto racing continues Sunday with the Indianapolis 500, the annual event that defines a certain part of Americana.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Wall Street is worried that volatility will increase as a result of the low trading volume of recent weeks. The market's liquidity -which allows stocks to be traded without distorting prices - is at its lowest level in two years, one investment firm says. A trader described the situation as ''very dangerous,'' and others pointed out that a marketplace with low liquidity was vulnerable to shocks.

LEAD: As a senior at an exclusive New England preparatory school, George Bush saved a younger classmate from being beaten by a bully. Forty-seven years later, the events that day at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., are bringing enormous financial rewards to Mr. Bush's Presidential campaign.

Mr. Karmazin succeeds Gerald Carrus as president. The company said Mr. Karmazin's position as chief executive, a newly created position, would include responsibilities that he has held for for some time.

LEAD: A jury convicted a 31-year-old man of kidnapping and murder today in the death of a prominent businessman who was buried alive in a box as part of a $1 million ransom attempt.
LEAD: British track officials today delayed a ruling on Zola Budd's eligibility to run for Britain until she returns from her self-imposed rest period in South Africa.

LEAD: The Farm Credit Administration reopened the Federal Land Bank of Jackson, Miss., today under the supervision of a court-appointed receiver, but did so only to prepare the insolvent bank for liquidation.

LEAD: All the World Bank's 151 members have pledged funds to increase its capital. Among the big ones, only the United States has not delivered. A House Appropriations subcommittee has refused to approve America's share. Unless the Reagan Administration bestirs itself, the result will be worldwide embarrassment.
LEAD: There are some items that, when tossed into a weekend bag at the last minute, can make all the difference.
LEAD: A gunman walked into a bowling alley card room today and opened fire, killing one person and critically wounding another before fleeing and then fatally wounding himself, the police said.

LEAD: Again Mikhail Gorbachev appears both bold and cautious, determined to change his deeply conservative country yet uncertain exactly how. In an interview in The Washington Post on Sunday, he demonstrated his usual mix of candor and calculation. It's understandable that he seemed in his words, as in his leadership, to pick a path between impatience and conservatism.

LEAD: Most adults prefer the slower-paced types of computer games, leaving the fast-reflex, arcade-style amusements to younger players. Golf and baseball simulations, for instance, rely more on judgment and strategy than on lightning-quick reflexes. Even the most realistic flight simulators are positively contemplative when compared with games in which you blast hordes of aliens.

LEAD: Walter G. Stackler, a Long Island builder, died Friday at a nursing home in Delray Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 83 years old and maintained residences in Gulf Stream, Fla., and Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

LEAD: Federal agencies are outdoing one another in designing eye-catching posters to convey messages to their employees. Last month, it was the Treasury Department, which used a poster showing two spies seated on a park bench in view of the Capitol to warn employees to ''report hostile contacts'' to the authorities.

LEAD: Former Assemblyman Lloyd Everett Dickens, a self-made millionaire and veteran of Democratic Party battles, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in Harlem, which he represented in Albany from 1959 to 1964.
LEAD: General Motors has hired Shirley Young, long Grey Advertising's premier consumer researcher, as vice president of consumer market development.
LEAD: A dozen women stood on this city's main boulevard recently, handing out leaflets criticizing the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko until the security police arrested them minutes later.

LEAD: Though Mayor Edward Koch of New York likes to proclaim the importance of education, dollars haven't always followed his declamations. This year they do, partly as a show of confidence in Richard Green, the new Schools Chancellor. That's a compliment, and also a challenge.

LEAD: Iran said its jets flew five bombing missions Monday against Iraqi positions east of Basra, inflicting heavy losses on enemy troops and equipment. The Teheran radio, monitored here, said all attacking jets returned safely from the raids on the southern front. In another report, the radio said Iranian military exercises in the Gulf of Oman continued for a second day on Monday.

LEAD: Ron Oglesby figured his days as a pitcher were well behind him. After all, he's 38 years old and hadn't pitched competitively since 1973. But when called upon, he quickly came out of retirement. Oglesby, the pitching coach of the Riverside Red Wave, took the mound in the 20th inning of a California League game against the San Jose Giants in Riverside and wound up suffering the loss in the 6-hour-19-minute game, which ended early yesterday.

LEAD: The Showboat Hotel and Casino withdrew today as sponsor of the Kansas-Temple basketball game on Dec. 10 because of the controversy surrounding casino support of an intercollegiate athletic event.

LEAD: Looking toward the Democratic Party platform, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today announced detailed budget proposals that would seek to slash military spending in favor of major increases for education, drug law-enforcement, AIDS research and housing.

LEAD: In her red-silk Chanel suit, with its brass buttons and white-trimmed pockets, Debra Sharpe has snap. But take a closer look. The hardware is the give-away. There is no trademark double-C on the buttons. Ms. Sharpe, who owns the Sharpe Gallery on Wooster Street in SoHo, is a bit of a fashionable fraud.

LEAD: The crowd roared and jumped to its feet to welcome John McEnroe back to the big time today on the first day of the French Open tennis tournament. As admired here as any Frenchman, McEnroe nodded to his supporters, then went on to the serious work of defeating Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union in three uneven sets, 7-6, 6-1, 7-6.

LEAD: Mayor Koch, who has tried more diets than Heinz has varieties, disclosed yesterday that he was trying yet another, a liquid protein regimen that recently helped Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward lose 75 pounds.

LEAD: The body of the young man looks beautiful. A funeral suit covers the bullet wounds. LEAD: Q.I live in an old house with wood floors, and in one room the floor squeaks when you walk across it. Is this a major problem, or is there a simple remedy? A.It is seldom a major problem, although in rare cases it can indicate a structural defect. Squeaking is most often due to loose floorboards that move up and down when stepped on, making the edges squeak as they rub against each other.

LEAD: The circus has left town. Within 12 hours of the close of the Cannes Film Festival Monday night, most of the 20,000 or so film people have departed. The noise level has dropped by half and even the winds have stopped.

LEAD: American Ballet Theater's production of ''Don Quixote,'' staged by Mikhail Baryshnikov after choreography by Marius Petipa and Alexander Gorsky, is an unflagging swirl of toreador capes and gypsy skirts. The women all jump on point, the men flirt and quaff wine and there is even a little bravura dancing tucked into the proceedings.

LEAD: The LeFrak Organization has been formally selected to develop a housing complex, with 1,200 apartments, on city-owned land on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, city housing officials said yesterday.

LEAD: John Pietz has spent 17 years tinkering in the laboratories of Talley Industries waiting for his favorite invention to pay off. Now, two years away from retirement, the chemist responsible for a key breakthrough in the development of automotive airbags is finally seeing his discovery become standard equipment on many cars.

LEAD: Krystian Zimerman is a pianist with so much to give that one longs for him to choose his gifts more carefully. His program at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon settled into the deep ruts of familiar repertory - the Ballades and Fantasy in F minor of Chopin and the Liszt Sonata. It is territory crossed and recrossed so many thousands of times in this city and elsewhere that its beautiful prospects and startling promontories no longer startle.

LEAD: Zora Young, a blues singer from Chicago, put on a casual show at Tramps on Friday night. That worked for her and against her: her backup band, led by Eddie Lusk, spent a dull hour grinding through some blues and novelty numbers. But when she came out and wandered amid the tables, singing - and complaining about how her feet hurt -she made the audience feel as if it were sitting in on a show she was putting on just for friends.

LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company agreed in principle early today to sell the $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant for $1 to New York State, which will end more than 20 years of controversy over Shoreham by closing it.

LEAD: Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi, the largest advertising holding company in the world and the parent of a number of agencies, announced its financial results for the six months ended March 31. Revenues were up 25.1 percent, to $714.3 million, from $571 million in the 1987 period. Net income rose 23.6 percent, to $40.8 million, from $33 million, or $1.18 for each American depository receipt, compared with $1 a year earlier.

LEAD: The Collegiate Chorale celebrated two geriatric wonders among composers at Carnegie Hall Saturday night. The music was Janacek's ''Amarus'' and the Four Sacred Pieces by Verdi. Robert Bass conducted. Curtis Rayam and Karen Williams sang the solo parts.
LEAD: Banca Commerciale Italiana said yesterday that it would extend until midnight on June 8 its offer to buy 51 percent of the Irving Bank Corportion's stock at $80 a share.

LEAD: An Executive Changes listing in some editions of Business Day last Wednesday about Sun Management described the company incorrectly. It is an international business management concern. In addition, a listing in some editions on the accounting firm of Pannell Kerr Forster misidentified its former managing partner.
LEAD: A picture caption on the Education page on Wednesday about Washington University in St. Louis misidentified a campus building. The building shown in the photograph was Graham Chapel.

LEAD: Larry Polansky and John Bischoff, composers from the San Francisco area, offered six of their recent computer works at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Friday evening. Their approaches to computer composition could not be more different.

LEAD: Actors, singers and other theater professionals will take part in a tribute to the actor George Rose at 11 A.M. June 8 at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street. Mr. Rose was slain in the Dominican Republic on May 5; he was 68 years old. Those appearing at the tribute, which is open to the public, will be Joseph Papp, Graciela Daniele, Rupert Holmes, Maureen McGovern, Betty Buckley, Jack Gilford and Estelle Parsons.

LEAD: The significance to the nuclear industry of Shoreham's cancellation is like having a dying horse break a leg. Nuclear advocates say the abandonment is a waste and an embarrassment, but there is not much damage left to be done to the industry.
LEAD: Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has declared an end to the 20-year-old war in Chad and said he would recognize the current Government of that country, Libyan television reported.
LEAD: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK has become agency for Pepsi-Cola's Mug Root Beer. It will be the first soft-drink account in the 32-year career of the agency's chairman, George Lois.

LEAD: Tomorrow's opening of the Charlotte C. and John C. Weber Galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a cause for celebration. Here, finally, is a place to chart the development of Chinese art from its inception to the triumph of Chinese painting. Here, finally, is a place where people can see the Chinese gift for sculpture and consider the mystery of why, at a certain point, it was virtually thrown away, never to be fully exploited again.

LEAD: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court, mentioned as a possible Republican candidate for Vice President, said today that she was not interested. ''I most assuredly am not considering any other position in or out of government and do not expect to do so in the future,'' Justice O'Connor, who is 58 years old, said in a statement released by the Court.

LEAD: Although Carl C. Icahn said on Wednesday that he was willing to pay $60 a share for all the Texaco stock he does not own, Texaco rose only $3.125 yesterday, to $50 a share. LEAD: Conqueror of 42d Street Kaye Ballard: ''Working 42d Street at Last,'' the Kaufman Theater, 534 West 42d Street (563-1684 or 564-8038). The singer, actress, comedian and impressionist is still one of the most exuberant descendants of a post-vaudeville tradition in which a single entertainer does it all.

LEAD: The New York Youth Symphony is to play the Shostakovich Fifth Symphony, Chopin's Piano Concerto No. 2 and the premiere of Scott Everly's ''Exultation Overture'' at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. The soloist in the Chopin will be Karen Beluso, the winner of the New York Youth Symphony Concerto Competition; and the concert is to be conducted by David Alan Miller.

LEAD: The Communist Party Central Committee has approved proposals made public today that would curtail the power of the party and limit the term of party and Government officials, in most cases to 10 years.

LEAD: Back in December, the economy seemed to be falling off a cliff. The market crash colored everyone's thinking. Consumers had pulled back. Homes were hard to sell. And recession forecasts were commonplace.

LEAD: A propane truck being lifted onto a flatbed truck yesterday before being removed from the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway in Long Island. The 2,800-gallon tanker, which caught fire when the truck overturned Tuesday morning, burned itself out at 6:30 A.M. About 500 families had been evacuated from their homes over fears the truck would explode.

LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company's efforts to build a nuclear-power plant at Shoreham have covered more than 20 years and cost more than $5 billion. April 1966: Lilco announces plans to build a 500-megawatt nuclear power plant in Shoreham on the North Shore, 55 miles east of Manhattan. May 1968: Lilco applies to the Federal Atomic Energy Commission for a construction permit.

LEAD: Once again, the name of the owner of United Airlines Inc. is the UAL Corporation. Stockholders voted at their annual meeting in Chicago yesterday to change the name of the airline's parent company from the Allegis Corporation back to UAL, which, of course, draws its initials from the airline.

LEAD: They played 52 innings just to get here. But they could not have been prepared for what happened this afternoon.

LEAD: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it would extend by one week, to next Friday, its offer to buy the stock of the Irving Bank Corporation. The offer had been scheduled to expire at midnight tonight.

LEAD: Art Rooney Sr., the 87-year-old chairman of the Pittsburgh Steelers, the National Football League team he founded in 1933, underwent emergency surgery yesterday to remove a blood clot from his left arm. . . . Byron Nelson, the Hall of Fame golfer, was in good condition yesterday in a hospital in Columbus, Ohio, where he had been admitted for a disturbance of his heart rhythm.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a series of legislative proposals today that would give it the power to regulate stock-index futures and to close the nation's stock and options exchanges in the event of another market crisis.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The nation's economy grew far more rapidly in the first three months of the year than had been calculated a month ago, the Government said. The report that the G.N.P. had increased 3.9 percent reinforced some economists' fears that inflation was picking up momentum. They predicted that the Federal Reserve Board might be forced to increase interest rates, which the Republicans hope to avoid in an election year.
LEAD: A formal complaint was filed with the House ethics committee today asking for an investigation to determine if the House Speaker, Jim Wright, violated House ethics rules.

LEAD: ''Long live Islam!'' Commander Lalmohammed bellowed into his walkie-talkie as the rockets, having finally found the range, crashed directly on the Afghan Army garrison at Dakka. ''Long live the mujahedeen!''

LEAD: A Tang Dynasty court lady, a richly glazed pottery study of a serene aristocrat seated on a bamboo stool, may rewrite the $660,000 record at auction for Tang art when it comes up for sale next week at Sotheby's. The gracefully modeled eighth-century tomb figure, owned in recent years by three major collectors of Chinese art, is one of several major Oriental works to be offered at Sotheby's and Christie's next week.

LEAD: In addition to more than a dozen walking tours led by city-history buffs and nature walks conducted by the Parks Department's Urban Park Rangers, there will be a variety of other outdoor tours this weekend, ranging from a 32-mile marathon walk and a sailboat cruise of the Brooklyn waterfront to a voyage past several Hudson River lighthouses.

LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation's chairman and chief executive, A. W. Clausen, said that the bank was not ready to restore its common stock dividend, despite improving earnings. ''We are not yet at a point where we can recommend reinstatement of dividend payments in the near term,'' Mr. Clausen told shareholders at the company's annual meeting here.
LEAD: The football probation imposed on the University of Tennessee in October 1986 has been terminated, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration's position on nuclear testing verification was challenged today by a report issued by the Office of Technology Assessment, a Congressional agency.
LEAD: Among the problems the Reagan Administration will leave to its successor is a shortage of judges in Federal District Courts throughout the country.

LEAD: A map on Wednesday accompanying an article about a propane truck that overturned on Long Island incorrectly identified the area shown. It was Nassau County.
LEAD: From the customer's side of the counter, the neighborhood dry cleaner is a prosaic affair, where lost tickets and missing buttons seem far removed from international trade and finance.
LEAD: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations have agreed to share almost all of the $500 million cost of transferring 72 American F-16 fighters from Spain.

Bill Terrio, a customer, gripped a handful of aromatic coronas and didn't give a hoot who minded.

LEAD: The decision to close the Shoreham nuclear-power plant and keep the Long Island Lighting Company an investor-owned utility resolves years of uncertainty that academic and business leaders say have hampered the planning and investment strategies of Long Island businesses. .

LEAD: In a lawsuit filed in New York State Supreme Court, the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe has charged the New-York Historical Society with ''fraudulent conduct'' in obtaining a five-year loan of a collection of American silver from the art collector Samuel Wagstaff Jr. The museum rejects the charges.

LEAD: The complex deal that sealed the fate of Shoreham has been generally well received on Wall Street, even though the specific language of the agreement to abandon the $5.3 billion nuclear plant, including its financial details, have yet to be released.

LEAD: Eric Rutkowski, a 13-year-old Milwaukee boy became the youngest recipient of a Jarvik-7 artificial heart Thursday, but he died hours after the surgery when his lungs filled with fluid. Eric, a seventh-grade student at Sholes Middle School, died at St. Luke's Medical Center. The youngest previous recipient of the artificial heart was Christopher Larson, 15, of Esdaile, Wis.

LEAD: When Edward W. Barrett was dean of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism in the 1950's and 60's, he liked to give a special talk just before graduation. His advice to those about to embark on their careers: ''Start a go-to-hell fund.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Rising costs, an acute shortage of nurses and government limits on spending are combining to cause severe problems at nursing homes across the country, according to industry and government officials.
LEAD: It is the year 2000, you missed breakfast and now you're stuck in traffic.

LEAD: The Commissioner of Food and Drugs said yesterday that his agency had begun to investigate cases in which the anti-acne drug Accutane led to severely deformed babies, in hope of determining whether there was a pattern of improper prescription or misuse.
LEAD: American officials said today that Vietnam's pledge to withdraw 50,000 troops from Cambodia had raised their hopes for progress on a range of regional disputes at the Moscow summit talks.

LEAD: The Jacksonville Journal article yesterday mislocated Jacksonville, Ill., in relation to Springfield, Ill. It is west, not east, of Springfield.

LEAD: The board of Texaco Inc. yesterday turned down Carl C. Icahn's takeover proposal, and Mr. Icahn used that rejection as fodder in his proxy campaign, as the two sides began a battle for the votes of the company's 211,000 shareholders.

LEAD: Hale Irwin, who won the 1983 and 1985 Memorial Tournaments at the Muirfield Village Golf Club and finished second in a playoff with Roger Maltbie at the first Memorial in 1976, said today he did not have a love affair with this 7,104-yard course.

LEAD: William Dermott Moran Sr., former regional director of the Secrities and Exchange Commission, died of heart failure Thursday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Juan Beniquez and Nelson Liriano hit run-scoring singles in the ninth inning tonight to rally the Toronto Blue Jays over the Chicago White Sox.

LEAD: Memorial Day is Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parades: Manhattan parade starts at 11 A.M. at 72d Street and West End Avenue, goes east to Broadway, north to 86th Street, west to Riverside Drive and north to Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument. Bronx parade at 11 A.M.
LEAD: Five small non-cancerous skin lesions were removed from Mayor Koch's face yesterday morning. The 63-year-old Mayor said the procedure was painless and he would not need any further treatment.

LEAD: Bess Myerson, the former Miss America and New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner who faces trial on Federal fraud and conspiracy charges next fall, was arrested in a small Pennsylvania town yesterday on a charge of shoplifting $44.07 in merchandise.

LEAD: The Village Vanguard can be a harsh place for young musicans. The club has terrifyingly high creative standards, two or three sets a night, six nights a week, demanding deep improvisational resources and complete assurance. Without them, a musician will die a slow, obvious death in front of the baleful pictures on the wall of the great musicians who've played there.
