David Archer, the starting quarterback for the Atlanta Falcons two years ago, has signed with the Miami Dolphins.

Despite the Hudson River landscape, it is a very Russian afternoon.

LEAD: Golf Five Share Senior Lead: Bob Charles, the defending champion, shot a three-under-par 69 to move into a five-way tie for the lead after the first round of the Sunwest Bank Senior P.G.A. Tour tournament in Albuquerque, N.M. Fourteen players were within two shots of the lead before thunder, lightning and rain forced a 59-minute suspension.

LEAD: ''Espectaculo Flamenco Tap-Dance,'' presented by Casa de Espana on Thursday night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, certainly was spectacular. It would have been enough to present either Cristobal Reyes, a member of Cumbre Flamenco of Spain and a gypsy dancer of great fire and originality, or Harold Nicholas, who danced as one of the Nicholas Brothers with his brother, Fayard, in movie musicals of the 1940's.

LEAD: Until a week ago, fear was a foreign emotion in this wealthy suburb north of Chicago. Children played freely, school doors were always open and violence and murder were what happened to someone else.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Securities and Exchange Commission's vote to seek wider powers incorrectly described its position on a legislative proposal involving margin levels on stock-index futures. The agency unanimously voted to consider at a later date a revised proposal that would give the Federal Reserve Board the right to review margin levels on stock-index futures.
LEAD: Just as Scarlett O'Hara once drew strength from the rich soil of Tara, so George Bush took heart today from the tingling salt air of Walker's Point.

LEAD: All the anchors have arrived, and with them, so have the soft drinks, the staples, the copy machines, the clocks for every time zone, the camera operators, the producers, a few hairdressers and a couple of cases of Oreo cookies.

LEAD: Having been a long-running Broadway success and a Hollywood movie, ''Last of the Red Hot Lovers'' would not seem to be an ideal candidate for revival, except perhaps for an all-star summer theater package. Undaunted, John Driver has staged the 1969 Neil Simon comedy at the American Jewish Theater.
LEAD: Traveller By Richard Adams 270 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: Susan Jaffe and Kevin McKenzie took over the roles of Kitri and Basil in American Ballet Theater's production of ''Don Quixote'' on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The previously reviewed Ms. Jaffe replaced the originally announced Leslie Browne, who is recovering from an injury. Mr.

Wilde, took place yesterday at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Judge Louise Gruner-Gans of Civil Court in

LEAD: Donald J. Trump and Merv Griffin said today that they had again come to terms on a plan to divide up the assets of Resorts International Inc., ending a two-week deadlock on secondary issues that had threatened to destroy their deal.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Since interest rates have started to rise again, many people have begun purchasing certificates of deposit with shorter maturities. This strategy assumes that rates will rise still higher in the coming months. With C.D.'s, customers have a choice of maturities, usually three months, six months or a year.

LEAD: Shoreham has been the centerpiece of electricity planning on Long Island for more than a decade, and so the decision to cancel the 809-megawatt plant leaves the Long Island Lighting Company with just one way to prevent brownouts in the next few years, persuading its customers to make do with less.
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration is proposing further toughening of inspections for older Boeing 737 airliners like the one whose fuselage ripped open over Hawaii last month.

LEAD: As real-estate values rise, many homeowners are taking a new look at their insurance coverage and deciding whether to improve it. People who bought houses or apartments for $100,000 or less 15 years ago suddenly find that their homes are now valued at three, four and five times the purchase price.

LEAD: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

LEAD: Jean-Marie Le Pen was in a foul mood. He railed at a local newspaper - ''It's Pravda!'' - for asserting that French gypsies were angered when he showed up at their annual festival, and he denounced local electoral boards for challenging the intention of his National Front to run under the acronym Lepen.

LEAD: Economists for the nation's top businesses said today that they had raised their forecasts for growth in 1988 but that they still expect rising interest rates to push the country into a recession next year.

LEAD: Melvin James (Sy) Oliver, one of America's great jazz composers and arrangers and a man who had a significant impact on American popular music, died of cardiovascular complications Friday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and had been suffering from cancer for a year.

LEAD: The Air Force announced today that it had considered stripping Eastern Airlines of the right to carry military passengers but had relented because of the carrier's promise to address ''performance deficiences'' found by Air Force inspectors.

LEAD: ''Splitsville,'' Richard Dresser's nightmarish satire of American junk culture, takes its title from a theme park that is being hastily built across the street from the Florida residence of a young married couple named Roy and Wendy.

LEAD: A soldier from the Third Infantry Division placing flags on the graves at Arlington National Cemetery yesterday. Members of the unit have carried out the tradition before the last 40 Memorial Days, placing about 175,000 flags in under three hours, starting at 5 A.M. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)
LEAD: Zeke could hardly speak above a hoarse whisper, so fatigued, so drained, so sorely disappointed was he.
LEAD: Nixon in China, Reagan in Moscow. Why is it that to improve relations with Communists we have to have conservative Red-baiters in the White House?
LEAD: B. J. (Red) McCombs, the president of the San Antonio Spurs, became the team's majority owner yesterday after two months of negotiations with Angelo Drossos, the chairman.

LEAD: In a world increasingly accustomed to dire warnings about what not to eat and smoke, Argentina gives the appearance of being one of the last outposts of unfettered indulgence in beef and tobacco.

LEAD: With two outs in the seventh inning, Darryl Strawberry stepped out of the dugout to pinch-hit. Minutes later, Kevin McReynolds also emerged. Gradually, normalcy was restored to the lineup for the Mets. The laws of probability, though, would remain elusive.
LEAD: Monte Kay, a recording company president and jazz entrepreneur who was a co-founder of Birdland, a nightclub in New York, died Wednesday of heart failure. He was 63 years old.

LEAD: One day after the Williamsburg Bridge reopened, four construction workers repairing its beams were injured yesterday, none seriously, when a wooden platform they were standing on collapsed, hurtling them to a work area 30 feet below.
LEAD: Nineteen 3-year-olds, 16 grass horses and the nation's leading milers will be in action this holiday weekend in four major stakes races in New York and New Jersey.

LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices were essentially unchanged yesterday in a somnolent pre-holiday weekend session. But bill rates, after posting moderate gains early in the day, closed slightly lower.

LEAD: To the cheers of residents, several hundred Syrian troops moved into the southern suburbs of Beirut today to enforce an agreement to end 22 days of fighting between rival Shiite Moslem militias.

LEAD: Police Commissioner Kevin M. Tucker, who is credited with restoring respect and confidence in a Police Department that had been riddled with corruption and inefficiency, is resigning to take a banking position.

LEAD: Here's a proposal for President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev at the Moscow summit talks: Announce a cooperative approach toward southern Africa. Start a multinational effort to aid the states that border South Africa. Squelch the idea that the region is another arena of East-West rivalry. Expose the root problem - South Africa's destabilization of its neighbors.

LEAD: There could be advantages to having a best friend who's a vampire -all-night parties, great black clothes, contact with the afterlife. There's somthing to be said for the trendy night scene. Unfortunately, when a beautiful vampire seduces some young blood in ''My Best Friend Is a Vampire,'' he's a wholesome All-American high-school boy.

LEAD: The Rev. George Gardner Hill, a retired Methodist minister who served in churches in Connecticut, New York and Florida, died of prostate cancer May 20 at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 68 years old and lived in New Haven.

LEAD: With the trappings of rock star idolatry and more than a hint of commercialism, the Metropolitan Opera - 52 singers, 72 chorus members, 103 musicians, 50 technicians and 110 tons of scenery, musical instruments and costumes -has come to Japan.

LEAD: Albert King, the blues singer and guitarist, is appearing tonight and tomorrow at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). Tickets are $12.50; there is a two-drink minimum, and shows start at 9:30 and 11:30.

LEAD: The Centel Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement to buy United Telespectrum Inc., the cellular telephone and paging division of United Telecommunications Inc., for $763 million.

LEAD: * Affiliated Medical Enterprises, Orange, Calf., an investor-owned health-care corporation, announced that it had acquired American Health Group International Inc., Kirkland, Wash., for $100 million. The acquisition included the purchase of four acute-care hospitals and a home health company.

LEAD: A witness testifying yesterday in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi described an elaborate system of payments made by the Wedtech Corporation, by a former law partner of Mr. Biaggi and by a Bronx Democratic club to a former Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon.
LEAD: The blood of 10,000 new inmates from around the United States will be tested this summer as part of an effort to measure the spread of the AIDS virus among prisoners.
LEAD: Charles J. Cooper, who heads the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel, announced today that he was submitting his resignation to enter private practice.

LEAD: Robert Shaw is retiring in style as music director of the Atlanta Symphony, leading the orchestra in two Manhattan concerts and then embarking on a European tour, complete with the full Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Chorus. The first of his New York programs, Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, showed two related aspects of his musical personality to fine advantage.

LEAD: Louis J. Patalano packing harps yesterday as the New York Philharmonic prepared to leave on a 10-day tour of the Soviet Union. The orchestra will perform in Leningrad and Moscow and end its tour with a joint concert with the State Symphony at the Green Theater in Gorky Park in the capital. (NYT/Fred R.

LEAD: Members of the striking Writers Guild of America have voted approval of a model contract with independent television and motion picture producers, an action the union hopes will put pressure on the major studios to yield concessions to the writers.

LEAD: In a growing movement, at least 15 states are considering or have enacted legislation to regulate or ban collision-damage waivers for rental cars. The waivers, which release customers from most liability if the car is damaged, are an extra-cost option on all rental agreements, but they have been widely criticized as overpriced and unfair.
LEAD: Sandinista and contra leaders said today that their peace talks were making progress.

LEAD: Don Mattingly is out for at least a week, perhaps longer, but tonight the Yankees survived nicely without him. While the Yankee first baseman suffered a strained muscle in his right rib cage that may send him to the disabled list, the team kept its momentum alive with a 5-1 victory over the Seattle Mariners at the

LEAD: MISSILES ELIMINATED * Land-based medium-range missiles (range: 621 to 3,418 miles) and launchers are to be eliminated over three years. * Land-based shorter-range missiles (range: 311 to 621 miles) and launchers are to be eliminated within 18 months. * Under the treaty, the Soviet Union will destroy 1,752 medium- and shorter-range missiles based in its territory and Eastern Europe.

LEAD: On Wednesday nights in Shanghai, more than 70 percent of the television audience watches the American police show ''Hunter.'' This summer ''Our House'' and ''Falcon Crest'' will be added to the lives of 80 million Chinese in Shanghai and Beijing as well as Fujian and Guangdong Provinces.
LEAD: Ray Kennedy, a prominent writer for more than 20 years at Time and Sports Illustrated magazines, died of a heart attack Thursday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 54 years old.

LEAD: Nancy Elizabeth Gleason, the daughter of Mrs. John G. Azary of Modesto, Calif., and Thomas G. Gleason of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Francis Rice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Rice of Manhasset and Naples, Fla. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.
LEAD: The USG Corporation said today that it had won a proxy fight waged by Desert Partners L.P. for six seats on the company's 15-member board of directors.
LEAD: Roy Simmons Jr., the lacrosse coach at Syracuse, has seen enough David and Goliath stories to feel a little nervous these days.

LEAD: President Reagan challenged Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to improve the Soviet human-rights record by reuniting divided families, increasing emigration, ending suppression of religion and releasing political prisoners.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Cablevision Industries' acquisition of Wometco Cable TV misstated the role of Morgan Stanley & Company. The firm served as investment bankers to Wometco.

LEAD: Thomas Bird and Michael Bornholdt, prisoners at the Kansas State Penitentiary at Lansing, are aiming to set a record by playing tennis for 125 hours, breaking the mark of 120 hours 9 minutes listed in the Guinness Book of World Records.
LEAD: The Orlando Magic, the National Basketball Association expansion team, plans to hire Matt Guokas, the former Philadelphia 76ers coach, a newspaper reported yesterday.

LEAD: Hockey's playoff season may have been marked by intrusions bordering on the supernatural, but when the time came for a Stanley Cup champion to emerge, the season reached its natural conclusion. The Edmonton Oilers, the National Hockey League's most talented team, retained the title with a sweep of the overmatched Boston Bruins.

LEAD: The Israeli Labor Party held its first open election of candidates for Parliament on Thursday, and when the votes were finally counted early today, the new list showed that the party was taking a swing to the left.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The new management of Crazy Eddie Inc. has disclosed that Federal criminal and civil investigations have found that all the company's financial statements before last November are inaccurate.

LEAD: Another member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has resigned, leaving the five-member board with two vacancies and only one sitting member with a regular appointment. Commissioner Anthony

LEAD: Volkswagen United States, a unit of Volkswagenwerk A.G., said it would raise the prices of most of its vehicles by an average of 1.6 percent, or $181 each, effective June 6. The price of the 16-valve GTI is to increase the most, rising $250, to $13,245.

LEAD: The Contemporary Music Ensemble and Wind Ensemble of Oberlin Conservatory, directed by Larry Ra=chleff, came to Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening and offered polished, animated performances of four colorfully scored recent works. Three of them were New York premieres, and two of those were by composers on the Oberlin faculty, Michael Daugherty and Edward
LEAD: Fine wristwatches, traditional gifts for graduation and Father's Day, can appreciate in value but are generally expensive to maintain and repair.

LEAD: The Chicago Board Options Exchange plans to act immediately on an exemption granted earlier this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission that allows institutions to hold larger positions in some options on the Standard & Poor's 100- and 500-stock indexes.

LEAD: With parochial school enrollment showing no sign of ending a 23-year decline, a growing number of Roman Catholic educators have begun to question the church's long-standing reliance on such schools as the bedrock of religious education.
LEAD: The Kansas City Royals announced that they have placed the first baseman Steve Balboni and the outfielder Thad Bosley on waivers for the purpose of giving them their unconditional release.

LEAD: Dusan Pasek and Igor Liba, hockey stars in Czechoslovakia, have agreed to multiyear contracts with the Minnesota North Stars, said Lou Nanne, the general manager of the North Stars.
LEAD: The French Open tennis tournament rolled along predictably today with comfortable victories by the top-seeded players, including Martina Navratilova, Helena Sukova and Stefan Edberg.

LEAD: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said it had acquired a 48.8 percent stake in Australian Associated Press Ltd. for $:30.8 million, or about $57 million. The agreement gives Reuters and Rupert Murdoch's Australian-based News Corporation equal stakes in Australian Associated Press, Reuters said. The remaining shares, or 2.4 percent, are owned by two regional Australian newspapers.

LEAD: New Jersey's Commissioner of Education, Saul Cooperman, threatens to use a new state law to take over Jersey City's public schools. The law, together with Mr. Cooperman's willingness to use it, deserves the attention and support of all states worried about the decline of local schools.

LEAD: Brian Beazer, the British industrialist, and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. faced a new barrier against their $1.7 billion hostile bid for the Koppers Company when a Federal judge in Los Angeles today summoned them to a contempt of court hearing on June 6. Koppers filed papers Thursday in United States District Court in Los Angeles accusing the Beazer group and Shearson, a unit of the American Express

LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds outfielder Eddie Milner, who was suspended March 30 for admitted drug use, will be eligible to return as part of an agreement reached with the Players Association, the commissioner's office announced yesterday.

LEAD: Facing a sudden and shocking elimination at the hands of two New York teams, the defending champion Stanford Cardinal came from behind tonight to defeat Fordham, 7-5, and stay alive in the Northeast region of the national collegiate tournament.

LEAD: The marriage of Elizabeth Ellen Pitney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Pitney of Worcester, Mass., to Dr. Christopher Whidden Seidler, a son of Mrs. William D. Seidler of New York and the late Mr. Seidler, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Worcester.

LEAD: The Panamanian President who was deposed by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that the United States should allow Latin American democracies to take the lead in any new negotiations over the general's ouster.
LEAD: A cabdriver outside Boston Garden said he had heard reports that Larry Bird had undergone tests for mononucleosis.

LEAD: The Euromissile treaty that President Reagan hopes to flourish in Moscow next week is a triumph of American diplomacy. But almost all changes, even those for the better, cause heartburn in the ever-fretful military alliance between the United States and Europe. As was evident last week at a meeting of defense officials at the Wiston House conference center in England, the new pact will leave European governments with some wrenching problems.
LEAD: Juan Orol, a leading director during the golden age of Mexican cinema, died Thursday of complications from diabetes. He was 90 years old.
LEAD: A Company Briefs listing in some editions of Business Day yesterday about Cooper Industries incorrectly identified the company it is acquiring.
LEAD: An advanced new study of vigorous exercise in pregnancy indicates that moderate physical activity does not endanger the fetuses of healthy women who have a normal pregnancy.

LEAD: A Japan Air Lines subsidiary has agreed to pay about $20 million to acquire a 20 percent stake in HAL Inc., the parent of Hawaiian Airlines, the largest air carrier in Hawaii. Pan Pacific Hoteliers Inc. will purchase newly issued stock, which will represent up to 20 percent of HAL's shares outstanding, for $40 a share, HAL's chairman, John H.
LEAD: Following is the text of the condition attached by the Senate on Thursday to the resolution to approve the Treaty on Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces:
LEAD: Stock and commodity markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed.

LEAD: Besides offering a low price and extra features, Miraclean hopes that sales of its Korean-made dry-cleaning machines will be helped by the large number of Korean families who own and operate dry cleaners in this country.
LEAD: McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 49 percent stake in Nikkei/McGraw-Hill Inc., a joint-venture publishing company in Japan, for $283 million.

LEAD: The H. J. Heinz Company said it had agreed with Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. to extend their merger agreement until next Friday while they consider the Justice Department's opposition to the deal. The Government on Thursday announced plans to try to block the proposed merger of two of the nation's top three canned tuna brands.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Americans' disposable personal incomes edged up a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in April after a large 1.1 percent rise in March. But on an after-tax basis personal income fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in April, the steepest drop in a year, as tax payments took a big bite out of paychecks.
LEAD: Chuck Yeager was strapped in, gunning the throttle, his narrow eyes seeing things that are hidden from most people.

LEAD: A funeral home director was charged today with stealing more than $3,900 from the apartment of a welfare recipient whom her funeral home had been hired by the state to bury. The director, Concetta Cannici, 74 years old, of the DeLucia Memorial funeral home, was released on a written promise she appear in court to answer a charge of third-degree larceny, a police spokesman said.
LEAD: A 31-year-old man was sentenced to death today for the kidnapping and murder of a businessman who was buried alive and suffocated before his family could pay a $1 million ransom.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Guido Orlando, a flamboyant press agent, charlatan and bemedaled publicist for dozens of the wish-to-be-famous, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center in California. He was 80 years old and lived in Los Angeles.
LEAD: Media General Inc. said yesterday that it had won a proxy fight with the Hollywood producer Burt Sugarman, who had sought to elect himself and two associates to the company's nine-member board.

LEAD: An undercover detective who investigated corruption in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn in 1986 was arrested Thursday night and charged with possessing and intending to sell drugs, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: The president of the Alabama chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has been charged with taking $10,000 to use his influence as a state legislator in an effort to help a convicted murderer win early parole.
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz paid an emotional visit to the Jewish Community Center here tonight and pledged that the United States would never abandon the cause of Soviet Jews.

LEAD: The Justice Department's civil rights chief has criticized Congress for exempting itself from civil rights laws and has denied that he lied to senators last year about a Republican challenge of voter registrations in Louisiana.

LEAD: After enjoying two games against Dallas that looked like highlight films, the Los Angeles Lakers ran into a wall this evening. The Mavericks, reeling after two straight lopsided losses in Los Angeles, waged a desperate fight this evening and defeated the Lakers, 106-94.

LEAD: Frank L. Mingo Jr. is accustomed to charting his own path in a fast-rising advertising career. He is charting his own path in politics, too, by becoming a rare black professional who is doing volunteer work for Michael S. Dukakis rather than for the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

LEAD: The two American women with the best chance of winning Olympic gold medals in track and field in Seoul, South Korea, will head the field Saturday in the Bud Light Bruce Jenner Classic, the first of 17 events on the Mobil Grand Prix circuit.

LEAD: An article on Thursday about acid fumes at a hospital in the Bronx misidentified the hospital because of information supplied by The Associated Press. It was the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Center.

LEAD: A major exhibition of the Ptolemaic period of Egyptian art, from 305 B.C. to 30 B.C., will be shown at the Brooklyn Museum this fall, from Oct. 7 to Jan. 2. The exhibition, entitled ''Cleopatra's Egypt: Age of the Ptolemies,'' will contain approximately 150 works from over 40 public and private collections in the United States and Europe.
LEAD: Scheduling conflicts next week will make life difficult for eight women who are leading players from the New York metropolitan region, including six who have won world titles.
LEAD: Franklin Lane Kauffmann, a novelist whose works include the 1964 best seller ''An Honorable Estate,'' died of emphysema in Glen Arm, Md. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: IN 1638, a boatload of English settlers arrived in New Haven seeking religious liberty. Eventually the 500 Puritans purchased the land that now makes up the city, plus some of its surrounding towns, for 12 coats of English cloth, four cases of knives, 12 hatchets, 12 hoes, 12 porringers and other utensils.
LEAD: A HIGH-RISK business venture, begun here with $2 million in Government money, appears headed for success after only seven months of operation.
LEAD: BRACE yourself for an alphabet attack. We're going on a tour of computer graphics standards, which are usually described in letter triplets such as M.P.A., C.G.A., E.G.A., V.G.A. and so on.

LEAD: The novelist D. Keith Mano began to write his first play -''Resistance,'' which opens Friday at the Judith Anderson Theater -on a dare from his wife, the actress Laurie Kennedy. ''I know nothing about writing plays,'' says the 46-year-old author of ''War Is Heaven!,'' ''Take Five'' and five other novels.

LEAD: SCHOOL buildings had been put up in the village of Harlem as early as the 1840's. But by the 1870's the arrival of the elevated lines on Second and Third Avenues encouraged tenement and rowhouse construction, and in 1879 the Board of Education filed plans for a school stretching along the entire blockfront on the west side of Lexington Avenue from 105th to 106th Streets, the first such in the city.

LEAD: THE camera pans slowly through a softly lit living room. From atop a grand piano, a gray-striped tabby cat mews in response to a car horn, then pads down the keyboard, setting off a soundtrack of Chopin. He runs to a windowsill to greet the family - who arrive in a Volvo.

LEAD: A philosophical dispute has developed between the United States Olympic Committee and its fund-raising arm, the Olympic Foundation, over the foundation's indirect investments in South Africa. This has led to a conflict among members of the two bodies over what type of moral statement, if any, their investment strategies should make about South Africa's policy of apartheid.

LEAD: When a jarring burst of thunder interrupted Michael S. Dukakis's talk at a Cranford, N.J., day care center the other evening, the normally staid Democratic Presidential candidate quipped, ''Bush is at it again.''

LEAD: The article entitled ''Giving the Proper Credit for Child Care'' (Opinion page, April 24) calls attention, properly, to the lack of credit given to child care givers. Far more serious, I feel, is the lack of credit and support given to today's full-time mothers.

LEAD: It was a bad cause - plowing under the $5 billion Shoreham, L.I., nuclear power station - that brought out Governor Cuomo's mastery of politics. Mastery is the only word to describe his accomplishment, but it is unlikely to be the last word.

LEAD: Elizabeth Jane Baer's engagement to Mark Robert Wilson, a son of Anne Y. Wilson of Nantucket, Mass., and Peter M. Wilson of Green Valley, Ariz., has been made known by her parents, Justice and Mrs. Harold Baer Jr. of New York and Fire Island Pines, L.I.

LEAD: WHILE the theater in Stratford, the state's traditional spring and summer home for Shakespeare, suffers a silent season, Stamford is taking up the slack by offering 21 hours' worth of the Shakespeare's historical plays.

LEAD: In the heart of this capital, behind a large monument built by the British to commemorate the dead of World War I, stands an elegant cupola that once housed a statue of King George V. Because of a continuing controversy about the structure's imperial origins, there is still no sign of the statue of Mohandas K.
LEAD: Montana's race for Governor, muddied by the withdrawal of the incumbent and the unexpected death of his principal opponent, has left the state with more candidates than it has seen in 16 years.
LEAD: NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS By Richard Wilbur. 393 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $27.95.

LEAD: Regular concert-goers often find that listening to music through loudspeakers is a mixed pleasure, and their cavils are usually of a particular kind. It isn't that they have unreasonable expectations of reproduced music being anything like the real thing. They are willing to make allowance for the inherent and irreducible discrepancies between the music and its reproduction.

LEAD: Jacob Sebag, who is renovating two adjacent East 105th Street shells, can chart the rise in East Harlem property values from his own experience. His buildings are both four stories with brownstone facades. But Mr. Sebag, along with a partner, Enrique A. Ochoa, bought one of them, at 229, in 1985 for only $50,000; the other, at 231, the partners purchased early in 1987 for $185,000.

LEAD: Charles R. Morris's otherwise excellent discussion of our carrier-minded Navy has one serious flaw (''Our Muscle-Bound Navy,'' April 24). He fails to discuss the Navy's long-stated intention, in the event of war, of operating two to four carriers in a single battle group. Adapting the author's figures, this means that the battle group could launch 48 to 96 F-14 fighters carrying 288 to 576 Phoenix missiles to meet the oncoming Soviet bombers - not the 24 fighters carrying 144 missiles, which Mr.

LEAD: Charles Morris laments the aircraft carrier's vulnerability to small antiship missiles, such as the French-made Exocet and its larger Soviet counterparts. He ignores the fact that the U.S.S. Stark (pint-sized and lightly armored, compared to a carrier) absorbed two Exocets and lived to fight another day.
LEAD: The Long Island Guide last Sunday gave an incorrect telephone number for the Sea Cliff Chamber Players' Long Island Mozart Festival. Its number is 671-6263.

LEAD: Amid cries of censorship, the Afro-American studies department at the University of Massachusetts here has forced out a prominent black professor for criticizing the black novelist James Baldwin.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency has designated more than 100 additional counties that must be counted as part of larger urban areas that fail to meet Federal standards for clean air. The counties are generally in suburban areas farthest from cities.

LEAD: When first blockbuster insider-trading cases were brought almost two years ago, they were hailed as a breakthrough in the effort to stop white-collar crime on Wall Street. But now some securities lawyers maintain that the Government may be endangering its goals with an overzealous pursuit of such cases.

LEAD: Robert Shaw was one of this country's most renowned choral directors when he accepted the directorship of the Atlanta Symphony, his first symphonic post, in 1967. LEAD: Performing musicians do not like to talk about memory slips, even those of successful rivals. Artists are not superstitious, but why tempt fate? You do not walk under ladders unless you really want to be hit by falling pianos. And yet everyone who plays an instrument or sings or conducts knows and fears these mysterious moments of blackout.

LEAD: IN true musical comedy fantasy, Meredith Willson's ''Music Man,'' now at the Westbury Music Fair, takes a mean-spirited, fast-talking, womanizing con artist and transforms him through the power of love. The musical is on a 14-city tour and, like many of Westbury's big touring shows, is first-class all the way.

LEAD: President Reagan's trip to Moscow, the first by an American President in 13 1/2 years, is the latest in a series of milestones that have marked Mr. Gorbachev's passage from the orthodox, anti-American outlook of a provincial Communist Party boss to the non-ideological pragmatism that has shaped his policies since he became Soviet leader in March 1985.

LEAD: NEIGHBORHOOD historic preservation projects - used by local governments in part to revitalize their inner cities - have become another source of work for historians. Local officials need them to verify the historic significance of properties and design renovations. Private owners with historic properties need to know what home improvements qualify for a tax credit.

LEAD: Shortly before the Portuguese flag came down in 1975 when Angola was granted independence, three Cuban ships filled with soldiers and arms arrived to help a Marxist guerrilla army beat its rivals in civil war. Thirteen years later Cubans are still in Angola, defending the Marxist Government against attacks by many of the same guerrilla rivals, supplied by South Africa and the United States.

LEAD: There are three reasons why N.B.A. champions do not repeat. One is that when a team becomes the champion, a competitive fire is lit in other very well-equipped and prominent teams who feel that they have just as much ability as this champion. Second, N.B.A. champions either lack the zeal or the same strong physical ability of the previous season.

LEAD: On the wooden steps of a cabin porch, Denise J. Ford and her four children sat and pondered some items they had collected in a scavenger hunt: a piece of white birch bark, a cup of pond water, a pine cone and a yellow dandelion.

LEAD: I often travel on the parkways from Heckscher Park to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, and I must disagree with Kenneth Marion [ ''Parkways, Once Pretty, Now Pathetic,'' Opinion Page, April 17 ] . While it is, indeed, a crowded and messy world compared with the 50's, the parkways remain a highlight of modern life.

Bank of New York, which was asking Irving shareholders to support its hostile bid for Irving, countered with gold ballots - a color often chosen to appeal to investors' greed.

LEAD: FOR a variety of reasons, including climate, East Germany does not enjoy a reputation as a vacation paradise. The idea of becoming ill or sustaining a serious injury in a foreign country is daunting for travelers.

LEAD: Even as the United States opened the golden door to millions of unregistered aliens this month in a historic amnesty program, Federal immigration officials threatened to slam it shut on thousands of foreign nurses working in this country's hospitals. LEAD: ''My dear Noel,'' the letter began. ''I don't know what to write to you today, so I shall tell you a story about four little rabbits whose names were Flopsy, Mopsy, Cottontail, and Peter.'' Written in 1893, it was from Beatrix Potter to Noel Moore, the 5-year-old son of her former governess. Miss Potter, then 27, illustrated it with drawings now familiar to generations of children around the world as ''The Tale of Peter Rabbit.

LEAD: Veterans' Salute May 31 - The Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company will hold its annual awards dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria with a salute to Joseph Papp; Michael Fuchs, the chairman of Home Box Office; and Michel Roux, the president of Carillon Importers Ltd. Cocktails at 6:30 followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment by the comedian Robert Klein will benefit the company's theatrical programs at veterans' hospitals and shelters for the homeless.
LEAD: Larry Bowa was dismissed yesterday as manager of the San Diego Padres and replaced by Jack McKeon, the club's vice president of baseball operations.

LEAD: ENTERTAINING GUESTS OVER A summer weekend is an undeniable pleasure, and often a considerable effort. Those hosts who tackle the challenge with grace and good will always have a strategy. Some insist on the simplest of meals. Others are sure to have at least one lunch or dinner at a local restaurant.

LEAD: Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's ''Concerto Grosso 1985,'' which opened the New York Philharmonic's final subscription concert of the 1987-88 season on Friday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall, was written to honor the 300th anniversary of Handel's birth, but its hat tips also to Stravinsky and the Neo-Classical tradition he fostered.
LEAD: The Pentagon plans to build an experimental rocket that would be launched from an airplane to put military satellites into space, Government and industry experts say.

LEAD: GEN. MANUEL ANTONIO NORIEGA does not often wear the uniform of the Panama Defense Forces. When he appears in public these days, he prefers to dress in pastel leisure suits or white guayabera shirts, the better to obscure his soldier's origins and show off his collection of gold chains, rings and watches.

LEAD: Belgian colonists found this paradise of terraced hills and sparkling lakes so enticing that when the Nazis overran Europe in 1939 and began talking of a 1,000-year Reich, some of the colonists began talking about building a Belgium-in-exile here in what they called ''the Switzerland of Africa.''

LEAD: As a solo theatrical performer, Mary Louise Hickey has never shared the stage with props, scenery, costumes or other actors. Instead, she draws upon her dramatic training and on the imagination of her audience.

LEAD: If asked to nominate the one contemporary pop star most likely to be as successful 10 years from now as today, I'd cast my vote for George Michael. The 24-year-old English singer, songwriter and producer is currently enjoying his third consecutive No. 1 single, ''One More Try,'' from a debut solo album, ''Faith,'' that has already sold more than 5 million copies.

LEAD: The race that annually redefines America's love for the automobile, the Indianapolis 500, will have its usual 33 cars on Sunday, its usual crowd of about 400,000 intense fans, and its usual contingent of Roger Penske-owned race cars.

LEAD: In his efforts to change New York City's troubled schools, the new Chancellor, Richard R. Green, can still capitalize on political good will in the State Legislature. But with its session expected to end early in July, he will have to hurry if he seeks solutions for many of the serious problems - from the bloated, unresponsive bureaucracy to filthy, crumbling buildings.
LEAD: AFTER almost a decade of heady growth, store rents in many Manhattan neighborhoods are beginning to decline as landlords sitting with large blocks of space grow nervous.

LEAD: SUMMER visitors often find Florence's high temperatures and humidity enervating. The city's beauty more than makes up for the discomfort but travelers who need a break from the sweltering streets and crowded museums might consider renting a car and heading for the hills that surround the ancient city.

LEAD: When Gordon Bunshaft and Oscar Neimeyer were named the joint recipients of the Pritzker Prize in Chicago last week, the event marked the end of the first decade of existence for the prize, at this moment the most celebrated architecture award there is. The decision of the Pritzker family of Chicago and its Hyatt Foundation to offer $100,000 each year to a notable architect gave the prize immediate credibility upon its initiation in 1979, not to mention cachet.

LEAD: Along the border between science and commerce strange things happen. Crossing that shifting line, valid scientific concepts sometimes lose their character and change into promotional catchwords. A recent case of this kind occurred in video and involves what is known as the horizontal line count.

LEAD: TAKE Edward Hayes's brown crocodile shoes. Well, actually you can't take them, because he won't part with them. It's not that he wears them; he hasn't had them on in years. But there they are, in a prominent place in his bedroom, where he can look at them and reflect.

LEAD: ORANGE has a low profile, and that is just what many residents like about it. The assets of this southern Connecticut town lie in a profusion of well-tended homes and gardens and old working farms sprawled across the hilltops. Three of its schools have won awards for excellence from the United States Department of Education in the last few years.
LEAD: Charges of ethics violations against Speaker Jim Wright have set off a bitter exchange in the House of Representatives.

LEAD: The New Jersey Constitution says the state must provide each child with a ''thorough and efficient'' education. Last week, state education officials were trying to do just that when they moved to take over the Jersey City schools.
LEAD: THE owners of the Shawmut Inn will soon begin a $20 million project to renovate and expand the historic inn beside the Atlantic Ocean.

LEAD: THREE years ago, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi introduced a sweeping program of economic changes more in tune with Ronald Reagan's supply side gospel than the decades of socialist orthodoxy he had inherited in India. He slashed regulations, import barriers and taxes and demanded that Indian industry modernize and learn to compete, to hasten the nation's march into the 21st century.

LEAD: A CONFIDENT Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi made it official last week, announcing that he was seeking re-election to Congress, the ''new career'' that the former accountant said ''feels comfortable to me.''

Although he likes New York City, he says he would rather live where there are fewer police cars and the air is cleaner.

LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union have failed to complete one and possibly two of the three modest new arms control agreements that American officials hoped would be signed at the Moscow summit meeting, senior Administration officials said today.

LEAD: IN 1761, the London artist Thomas Pownal visited the New World and sketched ''A View of the Falls on the Passaick [ sic ] in the Province of New Jersey.'' He showed a pristine wilderness, one with vast pine trees climbing up the sides of a ravine bisected by an cataract ending in a churning river.

LEAD: THE volatility of living in New York City on a shoestring visited Clara Jimenz early. LEAD: President Reagan is on his way to his fourth spectacular summit conference with Mikhail Gorbachev. It is a stunning completion of a full cycle since the last Presidential visit to the Kremlin, when Richard Nixon and Leonid Brezhnev launched detente in 1972.

Gorbachev, too, has made a remarkable passage, from anti-American Communist boss to pragmatic leader willing to make compromises that will help him change his country's course.

LEAD: More and more, the voice at the other end of the telephone line is mechanical. Automatic devices dial numbers, play recorded messages, receive orders and take surveys.

LEAD: There were plenty of real stars on hand, including Clint Eastwood, Robert Redford and Jean-Paul Belmondo. The sometimes dangerously huge crowds pushed and shoved to catch sight of even the mini-celebrity (a would-be star) who appeared at the Redford gala in a topless and nearly bottomless evening dress.

LEAD: THE golf coach at Tulsa, Dale McNamara, earned an unusual distinction yesterday in Las Cruces, N.M. Her team and her daughter won National Collegiate Athletic Association women's golf titles. Melissa McNamara shot a four-under-par 70 and captured the individual title with a 72-hole total of 287 as she led Tulsa to its second National Collegiate Athletic Association women's golf crown.

LEAD: ON the green hills that encircle Florence, like a giant Romantic frame for the trim Renaissance architecture of the city below, there lies an ethereal village called Settignano, which has left an indelible mark on the art and literature of the Western world.

LEAD: Economic growth is exceeding expectations. The gross national product expanded at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the first quarter, a sharp revision from the 2.3 percent initial figure that was reported a month ago. The Administration had forecast that the economy would expand 2.4 percent in 1988.

LEAD: The talks that ended the 22-year impasse over the Shoreham nuclear power plant - negotiations that succeeded where a host of others had stalled -began with a newspaper article more than nine months ago.

LEAD: The fatal shooting this week of an unarmed black fugitive by a white police officer has stirred a community outcry and a call by a group of black ministers for Governor Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor in the case.

LEAD: New York was slightly confounded last January when Thomas Krens, a farm-team player who heads the Williams College Museum of Art, was named to the prestigious post of director of the Guggenheim Museum. ''Tom who?'' was the puzzled query at Pleiades, Da Sylvano, the Canal Bar and other art eateries around town.
LEAD: WITH florists, dry cleaners, liquor stores, even a pawnshop, operating drive-in establishments in Houston, why not an immigration drive-in?

LEAD: The marriage of Dr. Martha Ellen Moss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert M. Moss of Huntington, Conn., to Dr. David Charles DiBenedetto, a son of Mrs. Joseph DiBenedetto of Belmont, Mass., and the late Mr. DiBenedetto, took place yesterday at the Glen Magna historic site in Danvers, Mass. The Rev.
LEAD: ''The Government has accepted every single point on the contras' list. I consider this to be a very historic moment.'' - Paul Reichler, of the Sandinista negotiating team. [ 3:4. ]
LEAD: SINCE the end of March, when the Pentagon announced it was ready to begin issuing medals to former prisoners of war, more than 900 applications have been received from New Jersey veterans.

LEAD: JOE KLECKO, the former Jet Pro Bowl nose tackle, made his annual pilgrimage to Indianapolis to visit his friend A. J. Foyt before today's Indy 500 . This time, Klecko also is in Indianapolis looking for a place to live. He is now a Colt.

LEAD: It is shocking that Nassau County District Attorney Denis Dillon does not recognize that blocking a person's way to prevent access to a building is a form of violence and should be prosecuted [ ''Dillon's Abortion Stand Roils Party,'' May 15 ] .

LEAD: One of the first signs of spring in Minnesota usually appears in early April, while ice is still on the ground - convertibles full of college students cruising with tops down, eating ice cream cones and pretending they don't have the car heater on full blast.
LEAD: IT looks as if the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport is finally coming out of its shell.

LEAD: I have to respond to Brenda Corbin's and Jane Feder's responses [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, April 17 ] to Steven A. Meyerowitz's article ''Garbage In, Garbage Out'' [ Opinion Page, March 31 ] . While all their suggestions sound easy and wonderful, the practicality of recycling is not always as simple as it seems.

LEAD: As Susan Seidelman calmly sips her cafe au lait in a SoHo patisserie, she resembles a college student who has just cut a class rather than a director who has finished filming her latest caper.

LEAD: Thousands of New Hampshire residents who work in Maine say they are angry that Maine offers them no benefits while it forces them to pay millions of dollars each year in income taxes. They have begun lobbying officials of both states and the Federal Government for changes.

LEAD: CHARLES LAUGHTON: A Difficult Actor. By Simon Callow. (Grove, $18.95.) Henry VIII, Captain Bligh, Quasimodo, Inspector Javert, Tiberius Claudius - the common denominator, of course, is Charles Laughton, one of the more respected midcentury stage and screen actors on both sides of the Atlantic. In a biography that focuses almost exclusively on the modes and motivations behind Laughton's acting technique, Simon Callow, an English actor and author, theorizes that Laughton's success with such roles ''consisted of driving himself relentlessly to reveal unpalatable aspects of his personality.

LEAD: ''Remember, when we came out with the 2.4 percent, how all you guys in the press called it a rosy forecast?'' - Beryl W. Sprinkel, the Administration's top economist, on the 3.9 percent rise in G.N.P.

LEAD: In a salutary step, the Soviet Union has agreed in principle to the opening of a rabbinical school, the first in 50 years, under the direction of a distinguished Israeli rabbi, Adin Steinsaltz. That the Russians let this be announced in Jerusalem the other day was doubtless a bit of pre-summit public relations, but the step is welcome nonetheless.

LEAD: When it comes time to select new members, some of the undergraduate eating clubs at Princeton University have a drinking ritual that they do not take lightly. After 45 underage students drank themselves sick at Princeton this spring, a New Jersey judge decided not to take the matter lightly either.

LEAD: Apple Computer executives keep popcorn machines in their headquarters lobbies and meet in rooms named after television soap operas. Owens-Corning Fiberglas executives hand out Fiberglas business cards.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: By the fourth day of a rafting trip down the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon, Franz Lidz found things ''a little dull'' and by the fifth day he ''started wishing for an escape helicopter.''
LEAD: An article on May 1 about Brighton, England, misstated the route of the miniature Volk's Electric Railway. It runs between the Palace Pier and the Marina at Black Rock.

LEAD: IN the old Manchester factories where workers once toiled to produce the rolls of material that gave the town its nickname as ''The Silk City,'' swimmers now do laps in a pool. In Stamford, where rolls of wallpaper once were produced, diners now eat duck liver pate. In Deep River, residents relax in cozy apartments, carved out of a building where piano keyboards once were assembled.
LEAD: To the Editor: For two years in a row, The New York Times has published items which tell of gathering wild fern fiddleheads for food in spring.
LEAD: MEETING THE COMMUNIST THREAT Truman to Reagan. By Thomas G. Paterson. 317 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE KGB Police and Politics in the Soviet Union. By Amy W. Knight. Tables. 348 pp. Winchester, Mass.: Allen & Unwin/Unwin Hyman. $34.95.

LEAD: Anna Petricevic of Yugoslavia, the 15-year-old daughter of an Olympic champion, won the women's 200-meter individual medley today in 2 minutes 16.90 seconds as the three-day Sundown Swim to Seoul began.

LEAD: A 50-year-old roofing contractor was ordered held on $100,000 bail yesterday in connection with the slaying of his wife in their Queens home earlier this month, and authorities reported that he is under investigation in the death of a previous wife last November.

LEAD: Ann Elizabeth Argabright, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Argabright of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Thomas Adam Seclow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Seclow of Westport, Conn., were married last evening at the bride's home in Orinda, Calif. Rabbi Charles Familant performed the ceremony.

LEAD: N.B.A. champions do not repeat because of the resiliency and grudge-bent determination of their archrivals. Of the five champions since 1969 who have reached the N.B.A. finals in their following seasons, four were rematched against their runnerup foes from the previous seasons. The only exception being last year's Celtics team which was dethroned by the Lakers, their longtime rivals, rather than the Rockets whom the

LEAD: Marvin and Judy Patterson and their three sons are farmers in southern Missouri's craggy Ozarks hills. Galen Miller runs a farm in central Iowa's fertile rolling plains. But all of them have much in common.

LEAD: IN HITLER'S GERMANY: Everyday Life in the Third Reich, by Bernt Engelmann. Translated by Krishna Winston. (Schocken, $8.95.) Not all Germans acquiesced to Nazi rule, Bernt Engelmann discovered in his interviews. Many citizens actively supported Hitler; some bravely resisted. Last year in The Times, John Gross called this book ''an unusual blend of memoir and oral history.

LEAD: Last Wednesday, Carl C. Icahn made a $60-a-share bid for Texaco's outstanding stock, but the company's management is fighting him. Mr. Icahn, who holds 14.8 percent of Texaco's stock, will have to raise $12.4 billion to purchase the remaining shares. Although he has put $100 million in escrow as a guarantee that he will raise the money, some still doubt that he can.

LEAD: ART AUCTION The artists on the East End are a generous lot; show them a good cause, be it social or political, and they usually respond wholeheartedly. The Retreat, a nonprofit, nonsectarian organization that provides counseling, emergency shelter and guidance to local victims of family violence, gains from this traditional attitude today via an auction of works donated by more than 50 painters and sculptors.
LEAD: ''She allowed only verbs and adverbs in her notebook.'' So said Dorothy Bird of Martha

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has begun laying the groundwork for what aides say will be a vigorous offensive aimed at clearing his name and repairing any damage that his problems have caused his party, specifically the Presidential candidacy of Vice President Bush. At the same time, officials have denied suggestions that the department's effectiveness has been impaired by Mr.

LEAD: AS Grace Razukas tells it, her son, Peter, and his Fresh Air Fund friend, Darryl Connor, used to spend summer evenings catching lightning bugs in jars. According to Peter, however, they caught them in their hands.

LEAD: Ana Aslan, a controversial gerontologist whose clinic in Rumania attracted thousands of people from around the world in search of renewed youth, died May 20 in Bucharest, according to reports from that city and Paris. She was in her early 90's.

LEAD: STILL bothered by back spasms that have apparently been complicated by a torn muscle in his rib cage, Rick Sutcliffe was placed on the 21-day disabled list by the Chicago Cubs yesterday. The move was made retroative to May 21 and the Cubs replaced Sutcliffe with another right-hander, Calvin Schiraldi, who came off the 15-day disabled list.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Jane Marie Daly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Daly of Floral Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Richard Michael Potocki, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Potocki of Hilton Head Island, S.C. The Rev. Regis Duffy performed the ceremony.

LEAD: INTENSIVE use of the existing housing stock is an important strategy for Westchester in combating its housing crisis. The basic dimensions of the problem are well known. The average sale price of single-family homes has soared to more than $357,000 and average condominium units sell for more than $170,000.

LEAD: AS the gap between housing costs in different cities widens, corporate relocation officials are meeting stiffer resistance to transfers from employees who fear the move will leave them paying more money for less house.

LEAD: At 3 o'clock this morning, Hale Irwin was jolted awake by the pain of a stomach attack that would leave him weak and ill through the entire third round of the 13th annual Memorial Tournament today.

LEAD: Times are local. Helsinki is seven hours ahead of Eastern daylight time; Moscow is eight hours ahead. 10:50 A.M.: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, leave Government guest house in Helsinki en route to airport, where they will say goodbye to President Mauno Koivisto and his wife, Taimi, and to the United States Embassy staff.
LEAD: My good friend Senator Daniel J. Evans explained why he is leaving the Senate (''Why I'm Quitting the Senate,'' April 17). I would like to explain why I am staying.
LEAD: LAKEWOOD REMEMBERS An Army helicopter will drop a wreath on Lake Carasaljo in Lakewood tomorrow as the town honors four servicemen killed in Vietnam, as well as all American war dead.

LEAD: The Indian Government has banned the use of shrines for political and armed purposes and stiffened penalties for the possession and use of illegal weapons, as part of its strategy to fight extremism in the Punjab region.
LEAD: HOW much leadership can a school principal be expected to provide when he is not allowed to shape his teaching staff, let alone tell a custodian to mop a floor?

LEAD: Something led customs agents to suspect that Rigoberto Regalado Lara, the Honduran Ambassador to Panama, was not on a diplomatic mission when he arrived in Miami earlier this month. They took a look through Mr. Regalado's luggage and reported that they found 26 pounds of cocaine. Honduras, whose military is headed by Mr.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Maison Francaise at New York University celebrates its 30th anniversary with nonstop music from 1 to 11 P.M. today. Many musicians who have performed there over the years will play, with a new soloist or group every half-hour. Admission is free, and the audience may enter or leave at the breaks in the program.

LEAD: A COUPLE in the Midwest recently faced a difficult time when a playground accident left their 4-year-old child severely disabled. Compounding the trauma of the accident was the need to review the family's finances to make sure that the child's expenses would be covered.
LEAD: The latest round of peace talks between the Sandinista Government and the contra rebels ended tonight after significant progress had been made in the negotiations.

LEAD: LUPE CAVAZOS HAS A PROBLEM with a P-82 Twin Mustang. Cavazos is director of maintenance for the Confederate Air Force, an organization in Harlingen, Tex., whose stated purpose is to preserve the combat aircraft of World War II. There are 140 planes in the C.A.F. fleet, known as the Ghost Squadron, nearly 70 different kinds, most of them American.

LEAD: HE'S out of the major leagues now, but apparently Cesar Cedeno is not out of trouble. The former outfielder with the Houston Astros was arrested Friday in Webster, Tex., on charges of assault, causing bodily injury and resisting arrest after the police said he attacked a woman they identified as Pam
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Janice Lee Cleveland and Dana Stanley Washburn, who are to graduate next Sunday from the University of Massachusetts Medical School in Worcester, took place yesterday at the Wellesley Hills (Mass.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Victoria Guest, assisted by the Rev. Jamie Gustafson, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Mary Stuart Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Johnson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Andrew Neely, a son of Gaby Neely of Palo Alto, Calif., and the late C. Webb Neely. The Rev. Avery Manchester, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill.

LEAD: LIKE Londoners or New Yorkers, Parisians sometimes long to flee the noise, traffic and sheer intensity of life in their city. One of the unremarked delights of Paris is how easy it is to leave. Barring a revolution or a metro strike, it's possible to get from the Place de la Concorde to a wheat field in less than an hour.
LEAD: Surrogate motherhood contracts should be declared void and unenforceable in New York and payments to surrogates and brokers should be made illegal, a state panel has recommended.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For the best part of three years, as Ronaldo Caiado traveled the length and breadth of Brazil fanning the fears of farmers that their land could be expropriated, he came to personify right-wing resistance to social change under Brazil's new civilian Government.

LEAD: SHOOTING FROM THE LIP: Essays, Columns, Quips, and Gripes in the Grand Tradition of Dyspeptic Sports Writing. By Mike Lupica. (Bonus, $15.95.) Mike Lupica, whose sports columns appear regularly in The Daily News and Esquire, is a master miniaturist. He has perfected the art of using a single mood or moment to dramatize an entire season or career.
LEAD: A PROPOSAL by Governor Kean to raise minimum teachers' salaries to $22,000 for the 1988-89 school year may be in trouble.

LEAD: A pair of bald eagles has built a nest in Massachusetts for the first time since early this century, an occurrence that wildlife officials call a major step toward restoring a breeding population in the state. The nest was spotted in a red oak tree near the Quabbin Reservoir in central Massachusetts.

LEAD: MY husband and I bought our last car locally, without comparison shopping, because the dealer assured us he could transfer the plates himself at the Department of Motor Vehicles. We would not have to set foot in the place. He was as good as his word, and we breathed a sigh of relief.
LEAD: A 19-year-old man has been charged with killing a mother of four who had befriended and sheltered him and whose body was found today on the side of a road, authorities said.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. David Lindsay Mitchell of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Beatrice Hunnewell Mitchell to Paul Scott Sperry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Sperry of Newtown Square, Pa.
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration has announced tighter restrictions on sightseeing flights over the Grand Canyon to reduce noise levels and improve safety.

LEAD: The marriage of Tracey Gail Moore, the daughter of Lillian Moore Branch of Hackensack, N.J., and Kevin Howard Matthews, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Matthews of the Bronx, took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y. The Rev. Harold A. Young performed the ceremony.
LEAD: REFORMING THE SOVIET ECONOMY Equality Versus Efficiency. By Ed A. Hewett. Tables. 404 pp. Washington: The Brookings Institution. Cloth, $36.95. Paper, $16.95.

LEAD: I GRADUATED from college 25 years ago this week. It was a simpler time, when a young man (if not yet a woman) could aspire to live better than his parents, when the word ''Vietnam'' lacked emotional content and when ''civil rights'' was only a noble goal, uncomplicated by the politics of empowerment.

LEAD: No matter what happens to President Reagan or to American drug-enforcement policy, Panama is now in a crisis that will not end soon and that carries far-reaching consequences for the United States and the region.
LEAD: Several thousand Syrian troops took control of the rest of Beirut's southern suburbs today in the second phase of their deployment to end a street war between rival Moslem Shiite militias.
LEAD: HISTORY is making a comeback.

LEAD: Andover $166,900 2 Scenic Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old contemporary; wall-to-wall carpeting, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,688. Belleville $125,000 112 Mill Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, two-year-old condominium town house; 4-zone heating, garage; monthly maintenance $127, taxes $3,069.

LEAD: THEY work in a highly charged environment, stadiums and arenas that are cauldrons of emotion, capable of boiling over in an angry outburst whenever the whistle blows or a voice bellows, ''Out!'' And when the judgment and integrity of the officials - the men in blue or gray or black and white zebra-striped shirts - is questioned, it is often done in a manner so vile that it would be considered uncivilized behavior anywhere but on a playing field.
LEAD: GREAT books are lately a matter of politics.

LEAD: THE untimely deaths of Len Bias and Don Rogers two years ago focused our attention on the tragic role that substance abuse plays in the lives of performing athletes. The tremendous pressures placed upon them to perform to expectations that are often unrealistic have created circumstances in which athletes frequently turn to drug use either to escape from these pressures or to enhance performance.
LEAD: For the second year in a row, the Hastings High School Madrigal Choir has brought home the gold.
LEAD: A judge has ordered a woman to stop smoking, saying that she cannot afford it because she has five children and no job.

LEAD: Susan Walker Ladd's engagement to William Prescott Rogers 3d, the son of Mrs. William P. Rogers Jr. of Dedham, Mass., and the late Dr. Rogers, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Delano W. Ladd Jr. of Greenwich and Madison, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Tooth Ferry Gets the Brushoff IT'S one thing to have a boat tied up in your backyard. It's another to have a 125-foot fishing trawler floating next to your house, especially a 125-foot fishing trawler in major need of repair.

LEAD: AHEAD of me on the Avenue of the Americas, a woman in her 70's, frail and holding herself up with a walker, her face lifted to the cold Manhattan rain, pleaded, ''Somebody help me, ple-e-ase. I'm hungry.''

LEAD: Courtney Bliss McNeil, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robin McNeil of Weston, Mass., was married there yesterday to Peter Thomas Hatswell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Hatswell of Adelaide, Australia. The Rev. David Van Dusen performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Marjorie Fay McCourt to Thomas Savage Clement misidentified the bridegroom's mother. She is Mrs. T. Williams Roberts Jr. of Villanova, Pa.

LEAD: More than a river divides New York from New Jersey. The Empire and Garden States have often competed, quarreled and quibbled over a range of issues from Federal grants to garbage, the current topic in serious dispute. Now, however, some House members say they want to extend their hands across the Hudson.

LEAD: ''The Wonder Years,'' an innocuous little revue that attempts to satirize the collective experience of the baby-boom generation, reduces more than three decades of cultural history to a cheery musical game of Trivial Pursuit.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A former firefighter and a snake trainer have been sentenced to 90 days in jail each for putting three rattlesnakes in a woman's apartment.

LEAD: A textile exhibition entitled ''The Miracle of Ancient Peru,'' at the Edward H. Merrin Gallery (724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street), has been removed because of flooding on the gallery walls. The show, organized by Jack Lenor Larsen, a textile designer and president of the American Craft Council, is to be re-installed in early fall, Mr.
LEAD: Come, Citizen Dog, we have chosen the short straw. - Henri Coulette, ''The Blue-Eyed Precinct Worker,'' from ''The War of the Secret Agents''*
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: SIGNIFICANT literary or literary-related events will take place around the state in June.

LEAD: Jennifer Elizabeth Gant, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald C. Gant of New Hartford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Massey Tovell, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold M. M. Tovell of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Wilferd Hansel, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony aboard the sightseeing vessel Rip Van Winkle on the Hudson River off Kingston, N.Y.

LEAD: CONNECTICUT is facing a garbage paradox. Although the state has one of the most ambitious trash-to-energy programs in the nation, landfills are filling so fast, officials say, they will be topped off before incinerators for more than half the towns are ready.

LEAD: WHILE all war memorials list the names of those who died, or who fought in a conflict, I have never heard of a structure for any war commemorating the families of the deceased. Surely their suffering was almost as great as that of those who gave their lives or saw combat. I know because I belonged to one of those forgotten families.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a veteran of three 18-day trips through the Grand Canyon on dories, I was pleased to see Franz Lidz's article (Travel, March 27). I hope it keeps others who share his need for artificial means of stimulation out of the canyon. Those of us who will never find this ''infinity of dry red rock'' boring will be left to enjoy the incomparable beauty of the voyage.

LEAD: Empires can sow wondrous musical hybrids. At the moment, emissaries from across France's past and present domains - Zaire and Senegal and Cameroon in Africa, Martinique and Guadeloupe in the Caribbean - are getting together in state-of-the-art studios in Paris, using American electric guitars and Japanese synthesizers and digital tape decks to assemble pop songs heard around the world.

LEAD: IN 1944, the small industrial town where I lived, Mansfield, Ohio, was totally unified toward the war effort. Whether the idea came from the government or someone local, I do not recall, but, in any event, Mansfield rallied those of us left behind and donated enough funds to purchase a landing craft.
LEAD: In a $3-a-night flophouse, as younger men share a quart bottle of malt liquor, Alberto Gonzalez is asked what he has to show for a half-century of bone-aching labor on America's farms.

LEAD: The Montreal Expos thrive on working overtime. ''These guys think they can't be beaten in extra innings,'' Manager Buck Rodgers said after his team had defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2, in 10 innings today.
LEAD: HOUSES OF IVORY By Hart Wegner. 241 pp. New York: Soho Press. $15.95.

LEAD: To the Editor: Samuel G. Freedman's ''A Surrender, of Sorts, to Vacation'' (Travel, April 10) rang true to my experience. I am a stockbroker and had the ''fortunate'' experience of flying to Egypt the Friday before last October's market crash. Abetting my lack of news was the fact that I sailed on a Nile River cruise on Black Monday and did not arrive in Luxor until Thursday evening.

LEAD: Q. I have a problem with moss growing on the bricks on my patio. I've tried using weed killer. It works, but only temporarily, and it poses a threat to the surrounding shrubs. Can you suggest anything else?

LEAD: 'America is moving backward - not forward -in its effort to achieve the full participation of minority citizens in the life and prosperity of the nation. In education, employment, income, health, longevity and other basic measures of individual and social well-being, gaps persist -and in some cases are widening - between members of minority groups and the majority population.

LEAD: Students at the University of California at Los Angeles overturned ballot boxes, upended polling booths and exchanged blows with workers Thursday to protest the disqualification of a Hispanic candidate for student body president.
LEAD: Just when he thought it was safe to go back into the dairy barn, Marc Goldman heard a rustling in the hay. It was the old New York City milk cartel, and its fangs were longer than ever.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The U.S. steel industry's rebound may have peaked after nearly two years of rising shipments and profits, some industry executives and economists say. A downturn is predicted for the second half of this year because of weaker demand from the auto, appliance and home construction industries.

LEAD: * China will soon allow foreign banks to open branches in large coastal cities, Li Guixian, the governor of the People's Bank of China, said. Currently, foreign banks can open new branches only in special economic zones in south China. The New China news agency quoted Mr. Li as telling a meeting of bankers that China should reform its foreign exchange system, letting coastal cities borrow more short-term foreign exchange, allowing a limited number of individuals to deal in foreign exchange and allowing companies to open foreign exchange accounts.
LEAD: James Aloysius Hickey
LEAD: A small plane crashed into a house east of downtown today, killing four people, including a 12-year-old girl who had been in a swimming pool at the residence, the authorities said.

LEAD: For years the cervical cap has been a cause celebre for a relatively small group of American feminists and health professionals. But this thimble-shaped birth control device has been little known beyond its circle of enthusiasts.

LEAD: Under a sky a few shades shy of Mets blue, Gary Deutch and his friends began a time-honored pre-game ritual in the Shea Stadium parking lot yesterday: They gathered at the rear of their Ford Fiesta and popped open a few cans of beer.

LEAD: Before getting down to business in the Kremlin yesterday, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev added to their summit anthology of Russian folk wisdom. Mr. Gorbachev seemed to have some trouble with Mr. Reagan's contribution, rendered in fractured Russian.

LEAD: The collapse of the United States effort to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to step down as leader of Panama resulted from a series of miscalculations and a lack of coordination among the agencies responsible for policy toward Panama, according to American officials and diplomats.

LEAD: Alex Chilton, the singer and guitarist, opened his show on Thursday night at the Knitting Factory by saying, ''Let's boogie.'' Few phrases have been as ironic. Launching into a blues medley - ''Te Ni Nee Ni Nu'' and ''Tip On In'' - by the guitarist Slim Harpo, Mr. Chilton proceeded to sing lines like ''Lay it on me, baby'' without any of the black affectations a listener expects from a white performer.

LEAD: Twenty years ago, a Presidential commission warned that America was ''moving toward two societies, one black, one white - separate and unequal.'' Two decades of substantial progress in civil rights changed that course but America remains a long way from full integration. Now a new commission, headed by two former Presidents, makes clear the importance of persevering.

LEAD: NEW YORK Parades: Manhattan parade starts at 11 A.M. at 72d Street and West End Avenue, goes east to Broadway, north to 86th Street, west to Riverside Drive and north to Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument. Bronx parade at 11 A.M. at Grand Concourse and Van Cortlandt Avenue East. Brooklyn parade at 11 A.M.

LEAD: When the editor of one of France's leading newspapers is reminded that two decades ago he was a Maoist firebrand, he recalls by way of riposte that a young man named Michel Rocard was so swept up in the student upheaval of 1968 that he proclaimed it ''a genuinely revolutionary situation.''

LEAD: The blues guitarist and singer Albert King doesn't play a note so much as he worries it. He'll create an entire line by bending the strings of his guitar instead of moving his fingers, creating liquid solos dripping with passion. Onstage, Mr. King passes himself off as an avuncular, happy figure; in contrast, his solos sound anguished.

LEAD: SWIMMING Canadian Sets World Record: Allison Higson of Canada set a world record in the 200-meter breast-stroke yesterday at the Canadian Olympic trials in Montreal. Higson, 15 years old, was timed in 2 minutes 27.27 seconds, breaking the mark of 2:27.40 set in 1986 by Silke Horner of East Germany.(AP)

LEAD: South Korea's current account surplus rose 41 percent in the first four months of this year from its level of a year earlier, the Bank of Korea reported Friday. The current account measures trade in merchandise and services. The surplus for January through April was $3.89 billion, up from $2.76 billion one year ago.

The recall includes 1987 Buick Electra, Oldsmobile Delta 88 and Ninety-Eight, and Pontiac Bonneville models, the company said Friday.

LEAD: To train an Air Force or Navy fighter pilot to the point where he is fully ready for combat in his high-powered airplane takes more than five years and, depending on the aircraft, an investment of $5.3 million to $7.5 million.

LEAD: Charla Doherty, a television actress who appeared on the soap opera ''Days of Our Lives'' for more than two years in the 1960's, died Sunday, her publicist said. She was 41 years old.

LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega portrays himself as the champion of Panama's poor and black, but in this large working-class municipality favored by the regime there is little affection for the general.
LEAD: Michael Bregman, a young Toronto entrepreneur who runs a muffin chain, has teamed up with the Belzberg family to buy a hefty chunk of the stock of the International Multifoods Corporation.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two experts who first played together as graduate students 30 years ago captured the prestigious Goldman Pairs Championship at the Eastern Regionals on Sunday.

LEAD: An official news weekly has echoed protesters' complaints that conservatives are influencing the selection of delegates in order to blunt Mikhail S. Gorbachev's effort to enact new policies at a Communist Party conference next month.

LEAD: Anatoly N. Rybakov, author of a novel about life under Stalin (''Children of the Arbat,'' published in this country by Little, Brown) that has been a best seller in the Soviet Union since Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed it to come out there last year, received an invitation to dinner today in Moscow from President Reagan.
LEAD: BRITISH and American researchers are experimenting with what they hope will be the first reliable predictor of which breast cancers will recur or spread.
LEAD: THE new George Lucas film, ''Willow,'' has been out for little more than a week, and here's Willow: The Computer Game, an adventure-fantasy that parallels the movie's plot.

LEAD: From his sunny office in this bayside village north of San Francisco, Eric Schrier, the editor of Hippocrates, acknowledged that the work involved in starting the bimonthly health and medical magazine meant that he and his employees frequently had to ignore their own advice.

LEAD: When a statewide business magazine listed the most powerful Texans not long ago, it included familiar businessmen like H. Ross Perot and T. Boone Pickens and politicians like Senator Lloyd Bentsen and Mayor Henry Cisneros of San Antonio.
LEAD: * Allen Adamson has been named senior vice president at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York.

LEAD: In a concert Sunday that left no hips unmoved, Kassav' defined zouk and zouke, the noun and verb in French Antillean Creole, for the band's first Manhattan audience. Zouk (which rhymes with ''juke'') is the Caribbean's most up-to-date dance music; it comes from the cross-pollination of ritual and carnival music from Guadeloupe with other Caribbean and North American dance music and French pop, delivered with modern instruments and recording-studio precision.

LEAD: Michael Gifford, a longtime press agent, died of a heart attack Saturday while driving to the East Hampton, L.I., airport to meet her husband, Edwin. She was 53 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in East Hampton.
